– Waterway View Playground
– Bukit Canberra Forest Gym Playground
– Anchorvale Village Playground
– Sengkang Riverside Park Playground
– Rivervale Shores Playground
– The Oval @ Seletar Aerospace Park
– Buangkok Square Park Playground
– Punggol Point Cove Playground
– Punggol Waterway Playgrounds

Outdoor Playgrounds in the West:
– Jurong Lake Gardens
– Yung Ho Spring @ Taman Jurong Park
– Boon Lay Glade Playground
– Choa Chu Kang Mega Playground: The Arena @ Keat Hong
– West Coast Adventure Park Playground
– Bukit Batok Playground
– Yew Tee Lifestyle Corridor Playground
– Tengah Insect Playgrounds
– Tengah Fruit Playgrounds

Best Free Outdoor Playgrounds In Singapore: Central

1. NEW! PropNex Family Zone: New playground at Gardens by the Bay

There’s a new playground at Gardens by the Bay and it’s built with inclusivity in mind! The new PropNex Family Zone at Gardens by the Bay features two 9-metre-tall towers inspired by none other than the Supertrees. They even light up once the sun goes down! Kids will love the sandpit, which has light projections at night, as well as the Becky Bunny Families for Life mascot. There are slides, lots of climbing nets, swings and even a market as well!

Playground location: Active Garden, Gardens by the Bay
How to get to PropNex Family Zone at Gardens by the Bay: The nearest carpark is at the Bayfront Plaza Carpark and Main Entrance Carpark, and the nearest MRT is Bayfront MRT.

2. COMO Adventure Grove: Outdoor playground at Singapore Botanic Gardens

The COMO Adventure Grove outdoor playground is inspired by the distinctive parts of trees found within the Botanic Gardens. A 10m banyan tree structure made with steel posts hand-painted to look like bark texture, takes pride of place at COMO Adventure Grove playground. Climb to the top of the 5.8m banyan tree tower via netted ropes for ace views, have a go on the swings and hammocks! Then zoom down two long tube slides at 4m and 2.1m long, designed for speed and thrills! Head to a cafe within the Botanic Gardens for refreshments afterwards.

Playground location: COMO Adventure Grove, 5 Gallop Road, Singapore 258960
How to get to COMO Adventure Grove Playground: By car – park at the Gallop Extension or if driving via Tyersall Avenue from Holland Road, choose the car park on the left which is the closest parking to COMO Adventure Playground.

3. Jacob Ballas Children’s Garden: Outdoor playgrounds at Botanic Gardens

You can only access the Jacob Ballas Children’s Garden playgrounds in Bukit Timah if you’re coming with kids, making this a super safe space. There is so much to love about this corner of Singapore Botanic Gardens, from the classic giant treehouse slides within the outdoor playgrounds (set in a giant sand pit with lots of lush shade), to the kid-friendly fare at Little Spot, to all of the new additions including a zip line, an accessible trampoline, and an educational canopy walkway. In fact, at four hectares, Jacob Ballas is officially the largest children’s garden in Asia! Plus, it’s newly revamped water play area has a new water splash bucket, rainbow arch and more, giving you more reason to visit this outdoor playground! Opening hours are 8am to 7pm (last admission is at 6:30pm – entry is free of charge), but do note this playground in Bukit Timah is closed on Mondays.

Playground location: Singapore Botanic Gardens, 481 Bukit Timah Road, Singapore 259769
How to get to Jacob Ballas Children’s Garden Outdoor Playgrounds: By car – park at Jacob Ballas car park. There’s additional parking across the street at NUS and Evans CCAB Sports Complex. It’s a 10-minute walk from Botanic Gardens MRT.

            Read more: Singapore Botanic Gardens: What to See, Do & Where to Eat

4. Far East Organization Children’s Garden: Gardens by the Bay free outdoor playground

The Far East Organization Children’s Garden at Gardens by the Bay serves up a combination of water play with fun fountains and a shady adventure outdoor playground with treehouses, rope walks and a 130m nature trail. This outdoor playground is definitely one to bring your swimsuit along to (there’s a water playground for older kids and one for toddlers, too). The park is closed every Monday (except public holidays); opening hours are Tuesday to Sunday: 9am – 9pm.

Playground location: The Far East Organization Children’s Garden, 18 Marina Gardens Drive, Singapore 018953
How to get to Far East Organization Children’s Garden: By car – park at Main Entrance Parking lot. Bayfront MRT is about a 20-minute walk away.

5. Toa Payoh Dragon Playground: Iconic playground in Singapore

Toa Payoh Dragon Playground has to be one of THE most iconic outdoor playgrounds in Singapore! The dragon head is tiled with terrazzo and tiles while the body is made of colourfully painted steel rings, which children can climb through. It’s the use of these terrazzo tiles that gives this playground its mosaic aesthetic that has become a trademark look depicting old Singapore. This free outdoor playground offers some climbing fun, a slide and a sandpit to dig around in. We reckon it’s worth heading here for some selfies for nostalgia’s sake!

Playground location: Blk 28 Toa Payoh Lorong 6, Singapore 310028
How to get to Toa Payoh Dragon Playground: By car – park at Block 29 Lorong 5 Toa Payoh. It’s a 20-minute walk to Toa Payoh MRT station.

6. Toa Payoh Lorong 4 Playground: Playground in Toa Payoh

Nestled in the middle of HDB blocks, this playground features four different slides, a tube slide, a play tower and unique shadow play elements. The Shadow Play creates different shadows depending on how bright the sun is. There are swings and a seesaw for kids too.

Playground location: Toa Payoh Lorong 4 Playground, 81 Lorong 4 Toa Payoh, Singapore 312080
How to get to Toa Payoh Lorong 4 Playground:  by car – park at CBM Parking (66 Lorong 4 Toa Payoh, Singapore 310066)

7. Toa Payoh Crest Playground: Spacious playground in Toa Payoh

Toa Payoh Crest Playground is located in the heart of  Toa Payoh’s latest housing estate, and you’ll immediately fall in love with the spacious play areas. While there are only two slides, kids can enjoy climbing ropes, a hammock, netted rope bridges, and more exciting obstacles. Watch our video here.

Playground location: 131 Lorong 1 Toa Payoh, Singapore 312131
How to get to 131 Lorong 1 Toa Payoh Playground:  By car – park at 131 Toa Payoh multi-storey carpark

8. Bidadari Park: Bird’s nest-themed adventure playground

This bird’s nest-themed playground is super fun for kids aged 7 to 12 years old. With towering climbing nets and steep slides, this playground is sure to help your child get sweaty while loading up on vitamin D. There’s also a flying fox so the kids can get an adrenaline rush. Parents can rest and keep an eye on the kids while staying cool in the shaded area. Just be sure to put on sunscreen and bring lots of water to stay hydrated!

Playground location: Bidadari Park Drive
How to get to Bidadari Park’s Adventure Playground: By car – set your GPS to The Woodleigh Mall and park in their underground carpark, then head to level 2 and cross the bridge to get to Bidadari Park. By MRT – take the MRT to Woodleigh Station and walk through level 2 of The Woodleigh Mall to get to the park.

9. Play@Heights Park Playground: Outdoor playground with shower facilities

Play @ Heights Park is an outdoor playground and water play area set within the HDB of Toa Payoh Lorong 2. The water playground consists of a ship structure with water jets that kids can aim and ‘fire’ (so don’t stand too close, parents!). There’s a fun water channel to navigate the water with mini sliding gates – bring your own toy boats to sail! There’s also a sand pit with swings, a zipline/flying fox, and if you walk further down, there are a few more connecting playgrounds. There’s a toddler playground with a soft padded floor, a race track for scooters and tricycles, a large climbing structure with slides, which is the main outdoor playground and a trampoline area! The Toa Payoh Water Play Park and the outdoor playground have some outdoor shower stalls where kids can rinse off before and after going to the water play area.

Playground location: Heights Park playground is located in front of Block 144 Toa Payoh Lorong 2.
How to get to Play @ Heights Park Toa Payoh Playground: By car – park within Toa Payoh Lorong 2.

10. Gillman Barracks: Outdoor playground in Singapore

Visiting Gillman Barracks for brunch with the kids? Make a pitstop at this playground beside Carpark A, in front of Block 9. Climb the tower via the climbing wall or cargo net, zoom down two slides, or come down via the fireman’s pole! Then navigate the balancing beam and have a go on the swings. See our video here.

Playground location: 9 Lock Road, Gillman Barracks, Singapore 108937
How to get to Gillman Barracks playground: by car – you can park at Carpark A or via bus, stopping on Alexandra Rd and from there it’s a 12-minute walk.

Read more: Guide To Mandai ZooSchool

11. Jubilee Park Outdoor Playground: Fort Canning Park playground

This outdoor playground at Jubilee Park in River Valley is conveniently located right next to Fort Canning MRT Station and within walking distance of the CBD, Orchard and Clarke Quay. Highlights include multiple swing sets, a see-saw, a log scramble and sand pits, a “treehouse” and climbing nets, and two big slides (one of which is long and tall enough to be a bit scary for toddlers). Do note that there is no shelter from the sun, and the outdoor playground can get extremely hot and sunny at midday. There’s lots of kid-friendly food in nearby Robertson Quay!

Playground location: Jubilee Park, Corner of River Valley Road & Clemenceau Avenue
How to get to Jubilee Park playground: By car – park at Fort Canning Jubilee Car Park. Fort Canning MRT Station is adjacent to the playground.

12. Tiong Bahru Train Outdoor Playground: Tiong Bahru Park playground

This old-school adventure outdoor playground is a total classic! Kids of all ages will go crazy for the tilting train that features a series of climbing tunnels (it can be a bit scary for kiddos under 3, though). You’ll also find multiple slides, swings, a flying fox, and a spinning merry-go-round. Be sure to bring buckets and spades, as there’s lots of sand play area for digging and sand castle building, too. The outdoor playground is in the middle of Tiong Bahru Park, which is fairly compact but has a lovely gazebo, some big steps for climbing, and a few paths that are perfect for scooting. Watch our video here.

Playground location: Tiong Bahru Park, 1 Henderson Road, Singapore 159561
How to get to Tiong Bahru Train Outdoor Playground: By car – park at Tiong Bahru Park Carpark. Tiong Bahru MRT is a 10-minute walk away.

13. Tanjong Pagar Eco Outdoor Playground: Open-ended play space

Discover Tanjong Pagar Community Green has an Eco Outdoor Playground within its sprawling 1,650sqm space. This outdoor play area doesn’t have the traditional climbing structures, swings or play equipment, but it’s more of an open expanse for kids (and furkids) to run around in with some fun structures available for open-ended play.

Playground location: Tanjong Pagar Eco Playground, Discover Tanjong Pagar Community Green in the middle of Tras Link, Wallich Street and Peck Seah Street.
How to get to Tanjong Pagar Eco Outdoor Playground: By car – roadside parking available at Wallich Street. Tanjong Pagar MRT is right across the street.

14. Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park: Outdoor playground in Singapore

Bishan-Ang Mo Kio has a spacious outdoor playground nestled between the Kallang River and a little pond featuring lots of sand, six big kids’ swings, a climbing frame and two tunnel slides. There’s also a pirate-ship playground structure that’s fun for littlies. Thumbs up for the fact that this outdoor playground is mostly shaded, too! NB: There are actually multiple outdoor playgrounds within the park; the inclusive outdoor playground is on the eastern side of the park.

Playground location: Bishan Ang Mo Kio Park Outdoor Playground, 510 Ang Mo Kio Avenue 1, Singapore 569983
How to get to Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park Outdoor Playground:
By car – park at Bishan-Ang Mo Kio Park Carpark B
By bus – Buses 71, 133, 136, 262 all stop near the park
By MRT – Ang Mo Kio MRT is a 30-minute walk away

15. Great World City Playground: Hot air balloon playground

Ever seen a hot-air-balloon-themed playground? This is not just a fun place for kids to unwind, but it also sparks the kids’ imagination as they get to role-play through various modes of transport like a ship, mini train, and of course, the hot air balloon! This exciting playground is not totally outdoors – it is attached to Great World City shopping mall however, it is still open air (and may be closed in bad weather).

Playground location: Great World City Playground, 1 Kim Seng Promenade, Singapore 237994
How to get to Great World City Playground: by car – park in Great World City’s carpark; by MRT – Great World City is a 7-minute walk from Great World station

16. Wonderland Playground at Dawson Vista: Alice in Wonderland playground

Wonderland Playground at Dawson Vista is probably one of the most colourful playgrounds we’ve seen! This playground, inspired by the popular children’s story ‘Alice in Wonderland,’ features whimsical designs for traditional playground elements like slides, seesaws, climbing platforms, and a trampoline.

Playground location: Wonderland Playground, 80 Strathmore Ave, Singapore 141080
How to get to Wonderland Playground: by car – park at Wilson Parking (78A Dawson Road, Queenstown, Singapore 141078). By MRT – 8-min walk from Queenstown MRT

17. SkyResidences @ Dawson: Playground in Queenstown

The playground at SkyResidences @ Dawson has something for everyone! Older kids can test their balance on the trampoline, while little ones can climb up and down the undulating play hills. There are also plenty of climbing ropes, rings and structures, where kids can test their strength, coordination and endurance as they swing their way through the obstacle courses. This playground also features a Treehouse that sits under an Angsana tree that is almost 10 storeys high!

Playground location: 38 Margaret Drive, Singapore 141038
How to get to SkyResidences @ Dawson playground: by car – park at the multi-storey carpark nearby (37 Margaret Drive, Singapore 143037); by MRT – 5-minute walk from Queenstown MRT station

18. St George’s Tower Playground: Climbing nets & trampolines

This playground in Singapore is located in a public housing estate, and we must say, this is one for the climbers! Your little adventure sprouts can explore the netted trampolines and climbing nets that are safely constructed with support from the green anchors. The playground also has other climbing obstacles, including a hammock and a swing!

Playground location:26A St George’s Ln, Singapore 321026
How to get to St George’s Tower Playground: by car – park at the St George’s Tower carpark; by MRT – 10-minute walk from Boon Keng MRT station

19. Whampoa Park Playground: Obstacle course playground

Located in the heart of Whampoa, the Whampoa Park playground features a slew of exciting activities, including an exciting Ninja Obstacle course for the older kids, swings, see-saws, and a pet park for the doggos. This forest-themed playground in Singapore also includes a Treehouse where kids can head up to the canopy level through different obstacles, from a ladder to a climbing net. The treehouse also features mini rock-climbing stations and massive slides from its canopy, so be sure to look out for the little ones here!

Playground location: Along Whampoa Road, between the Whampoa Community Club and St Michael’s Bus Terminal
How to get to Whampoa Park playground: by car – you can park at St Michael’s Bus Terminal.

20. Sentosa Cove Village Playground: Pirate-themed playground

Ahoy Matey! It’s all hands on deck at this outdoor playground in Singapore! Head down to Sentosa Cove Village and let kiddos explore this pirate-themed outdoor playground with the beautiful backdrop of the Marina. With swings, slides, climbing equipment and more, little ones are sure to have a blast. Once the kiddos are done playing, be sure to take a walk along the pier or head down to one of the many kid-friendly restaurants nearby.

Playground location: Sentosa Cove Village, 1 Cove Avenue, Singapore 098537
How to get to Jubilee Park playground: By car – park at Sentosa Cove Village. Take the MRT to Harbourfront MRT Station before taking the monorail or bus into Sentosa.

21. Playgrounds near Bird Paradise: Free outdoor playgrounds at Mandai Wildlife West

Did you know there are free playgrounds near Bird Paradise? Located at Mandai Wildlife West, these play areas – Pangolin Hideout, Pangolin Adventure, and Forest Stream Trail – feature climbing structures, swings, and slides. You’ll find them near the scenic waterfall and kid-friendly F&B outlets. Need a break? Stop by the Mandai Wildlife West retail area, where you can enjoy free wildlife-themed board games at the Mandai Wildlife Shop!

Playground location: Mandai Wildlife West
How to get to the playgrounds near Bird Paradise: The playgrounds are located near the top of the waterfall, close to the F&B area and restaurants like Luke’s Lobster.

22. Woodleigh Village: Hot air balloon-themed playground

Just a short walk from Woodleigh MRT and located above the Woodleigh Village Hawker Centre, this new hot air balloon-themed outdoor playground in Singapore is a new must-visit spot for little adventurers in the area. Kids can climb ropes and nets in a giant balloon basket, zoom down a tall slide, and explore additional play structures, including swings and a toddler-friendly zone with gentle slides.

Playground location: Woodleigh Village
How to get to the Woodleigh Village Playground: Just a short walk from Woodleigh MRT

Read more: Best Educational Games & Apps For Kids

23. Labrador Park Playgrounds: Seaside playground (temporarily closed)

Your kids want to visit a playground, but the parents just want to enjoy a weekend walk by the sea? Do both at this outdoor playground in Labrador Park. Enjoy the beautiful coastal views while the little ones run around the small play area near the Dragon’s Tooth Gate, which has swings, a see-saw and even a merry-go-round. On the other side of Labrador Park, if you continue to follow the path along the water (past the restrooms and vending machines) you’ll come to a newer, bigger playground with slides, a fireman’s pole, a maze and fun tunnels to crawl through. Read our comprehensive guide to Labrador Park here.

Playground location: Labrador Park, 91 Labrador Villa Rd Singapore 119190
How to get to Labrador Park playground: by car – you can park at Carpark B, which is closer to the playground and restrooms; by MRT – 15-minute walk from Labrador Park MRT

Best Outdoor Playgrounds In Singapore: East

24. Coastal PlayGrove: Outdoor playground with free water play

Coastal PlayGrove is a free outdoor playground located at the former Big Splash East Coast Park. Coastal PlayGrove is located near the Marina Cove Playground and boasts the tallest outdoor play feature in town – it’s 16 metres high – with fun climbing net challenges for older kids (13 years+), a nature playgarden with sandpits and teepees, and a water play area. There are two slides at this playground, the first slide is 7.3 metres tall but the second slide is a whopping 11.9 m tall with a little loop in it (best for 13-year-olds and above).

Playground location: Coastal PlayGrove, 902 E Coast Park Service Road
How to get to Coastal Playgrove East Coast playground: By car – park at Car Park B2.

25. East Coast Park Playground: Marine Cove Playground

East Coasters rejoiced when this huge outdoor playground opened in East Coast Park in 2016. At Marine Cove Playground, there are both big kids and toddler play areas, and all manner of cool climbing structures, swings (including multiple accessible swings) and slides. The highlight at this playground is the 8-meter high lighthouse tower that’s accessed by various rope ladders (and features 3 slides to get down). We also give a thumbs up for the handy kids’ toilets and showers on the premises, and have a feeling your children will love the adjacent McDonald’s… Fair warning though, this outdoor playground can get very crowded on weekends!

Playground location: Marina Cove Outdoor Playground, 1000 East Coast Parkway, Singapore 449876
How to get to East Coast Park Marine Cove Playground: By car – park at East Coast Park Carparks C2 & C3. Closest MRT is Eunos.

26. Dakota Breeze: Aeroplane-themed Playground

Take the kiddos to the free playground at Dakota Breeze for its aeroplane-themed climbing structure, slides, seesaw and heliport fun with its padded ‘runway’. Read more about the playground at Dakota Breeze here.

⁠Playground location: Dakota Breeze, 92A Jln. Satu, Singapore 392092⁠
How to get to Dakota Breeze: Dakota Breeze playgrounds are approximately 3 minutes (100m) walk from Dakota MRT Station.

27. PLQ Parkside Outdoor Playground: Playground at Paya Lebar

The Parkside outdoor playground is located between PLQ3 and the residences, and is right next to kid friendly cafe Jimmy Monkey – perfect for enjoying a coffee and nibbles while the kids climb, enjoy the swings and run around at the padded playground! It gets pretty hot at midday, but becomes shaded from about 3pm. Highly recommend for playdates so mamas can chat over coffee without worry while the kiddos play nearby!

Playground location: PLQ Parkside Playground, 2 Tanjong Katong Road
How to get to PLQ Parkside Playground: By car – park at PLQ Mall. Directly connected to Paya Lebar MRT Station.

28. Tampines Green Forest Park: Cargo net playground

Tampines Green Forest Park is a massive outdoor playground in the East! The high-up cargo nets are the highlight of this play area surrounded by Tampines Green Forest Residences. There are three sections – a large outdoor playground structure, a tall tower with cargo nets and a huge slide plus another outdoor playground with a sandpit and smaller climbing structures and slides for younger kids.

Playground location: Tampines Green Forest Park, 879A Tampines Ave 8, Singapore 521879
How to get to Tampines Green Forest Park Playground: By car – park at Tampines Green Forest Residences.

29. Tampines GreenDew Playground: Green themed playground

This unique Cactus-themed playground is located in a residential estate in Tampines, where kids can have fun exploring the cactus-shaped towers and climb the textured surfaces while learning about the different species of cacti! The playground, which is more suited for the older kiddos, aims to promote physical activity and coordination and has different difficulty levels for a safe and fun time!

Playground location: 647A Tampines St 62, Singapore 521647
How to get to Tampines GreenDew Playground: Take bus 298 and stop at bus stop 75549, along Tampines St 62.

30. Tampines Boulevard Park (West): Playground with climbing elements and sandpit

Tampines Boulevard Park (West) is a massive 4.78-hectare park that has plenty of space for kids to run around. The playground is located in the middle of the park. While it’s not the largest, it’s got plenty to keep the kids entertained. There are plenty of rock walls for kids who love to climb, as well as a sand pit that comes with a manual excavator. Watch our video here.

Playground location: The park has multiple access points and sits between the Tampines North HDB Blocks and Tampines Street 61 HDB Blocks
How to get to Tampines Boulevard Park (West) Playground: The nearest parking is at Block 632B HDB Tampines North or around Block 626A Tampines Street 61. You can also take buses 15, 129, 298 or 969 to Bef Blk 631b bus stop.

31. Tampines Boulevard Park (East): Climbing structures, swings, sandpit

There’s a brand-new outdoor playground at Tampines Boulevard Park (East)! This nature playgarden is great for younger kids, where you’ll find two sand pits: one with a swing and another with kid-sized wooden climbing structures. Around the sand pits are a couple more wooden structures and flowers young kids will absolutely love exploring!

Playground location: The park has multiple access points and sits between the Tampines North HDB Blocks and Tampines Street 61 HDB Blocks
How to get to Tampines Boulevard Park (East) Playground: The nearest parking available from the playground is at Block 413 Tampines Street 41.

32. Our Tampines Hub: Level 2 Sky Terrace sheltered outdoor playground

10/10 points for free outdoor playgrounds that are sheltered! The Sky Terrace open-air playground at Level 2 Our Tampines Hub is a blessing for rainy days or extra-sunny days. There are so many things to love about this free playground: the giant fruits, the random dinosaur, the old-school garden swings and lots of seating areas for the parents. We’d say that the Sky Terrace playground is more suitable for younger kids, with a toddler-friendly slide and plenty of exploration stations. There’s also a trampoline and some spinners. However, rest assured that older kids will still have a ball of a time running around this spacious area!

Playground location: Sky Terrace, Level 2, Our Tampines Hub
How to get to Sky Terrace playground @ Our Tampines Hub: Take the escalator or elevators next to the hawker centre to Level 2. Exit the elevators and the Sky Terrace outdoor playground will be on your right.

33. Pasir Ris Park: Massive pirate-themed outdoor playground

This outdoor playground is for nature lovers! Pasir Ris Park outdoor playground is a firm fave due to the combination of its idyllic waterfront setting, its huge range of play equipment – including a climbing pyramid, rope bridge, zip lines, long slides, swings and more – and other nearby attractions within the park, like fishing and pony rides. The playground is massive, with plenty of sections. There is a lot of well-shaded playground equipment for kids of all different ages, including plenty of roomy sand pits. We love that the playgrounds are also pirate-themed! Watch our video here.

Playground location: Pasir Ris Park Outdoor Playground, Pasir Ris Road near Elias Road
How to get to Pasir Ris Park Playground: By car – park at Pasir Ris Carpark D. Pasir Ris MRT is about a 20-minute walk.

34. Pasir Ris Mall Playground: Overlooks the MRT

Pasir Ris Mall is the newest mall in the east, and it’s already buzzing as the new go-to spot for hangouts! Their free outdoor playground on Level 2 gives families with little ones just another reason to head down here. There is plenty to do here, from a sensory wall and hammock swings to seesaws and trampolines; big and little kids will have a ball of a time! Plus, since it’s located right next to Pasir Ris MRT, kids can also watch MRT trains come and go. Watch our video here.

Playground location: Pasir Ris Mall, Level 2 Central Greenway
How to get to Pasir Ris Mall Playground: By car – park at Pasir Ris Mall.

Best Free Outdoor Playgrounds In Singapore: North

35. Admiralty Park: Outdoor playground in Woodlands

With a whopping 26 slides – as well as swings, climbing structures, and separate areas for toddlers and big kids – Admiralty Park outdoor playground in Woodlands is hands-down one of the coolest outdoor playgrounds in Singapore. You could easily spend a few hours here (we certainly have!), and there are also convenient amenities like kiddie sinks and toilets, nice wide paths for scooting, and a Shiok Garden grill buffet adjacent to the parking lot (in case the kiddos get hungry).

* Some areas may be closed for improvement works.

Playground location: Admiralty Park Playground, 6A Admiralty Road, Woodlands Singapore 732006
How to get to Admiralty Park Playground: By car – park at Admiralty Park West, enter via Riverside Road. Closest MRT station is Woodlands MRT.

36. Sembawang Park: Battleship outdoor playground

Reflecting the rich naval history of Sembawang (there are also lots of gorgeous black and white houses in the ‘hood to admire en route), this super cool battleship-themed outdoor playground rates for its expansive sand pit and challenging climbing activities (there are lots of ropes and ladders – perfect for aspiring pirates!). Facing the Straits of Johor, Sembawang Park has a small beach and you can even see Malaysia in the distance.

Playground location: Sembawang Park is located at the end of Sembawang Road
How to get to Sembawang Battleship playground:
By car – park at one of two parking lots, one by Tuah Road and one by Sembawang Road.
By bus – take bus 882 from Sembawang Bus Interchange or 169 from Woodlands Bus Interchange.
By MRT – Sembawang MRT/LRT station is about 7 minutes away by car/30 minutes on foot.

           Read more: Kid-friendly Guide To Sembawang With Natural Hot Springs & More

37. Marsiling Park Playground: Nature Play Garden

Formerly named Woodlands Town Garden, Marsiling Park now boasts a one-of-a-kind butterfly-shaped playground! There are nets, climbing structures, slides and a fitness corner, overlooking the picturesque Marsiling Park pond with accessible boardwalks for a nice stroll. There’s Teh Tarik Cartel on site if you get peckish – think local dishes, with a huge drinks menu (perfect for quenching your thirst after some playground time!).

Playground location: Woodlands Centre Road, Singapore 738930
How to get to Marsiling Park Playground: By car – park right at Marsiling Park’s car park. It’s a 9-minute walk to Marsiling MRT station.

38. Champions Green: Sports-themed Woodlands outdoor playground

Woodlands is where it’s at for little sports fans! There are three delightful sports-themed playgrounds at Champions Green. First up, a soccer playground comprising lots of climbing and two slides for the little ones. There’s also a basketball playground–complete with a giant “hoop”, as well as a rugby playground, all with plenty for kids of all ages to explore.

Playground location: Champions Green, 568A Champions Way, Singapore 731568
How to get to Champions Green sports playground: The playground is just a 6-minute walk from Woodlands South MRT station.

39. Circle Green Park: Outdoor playground at Woodlands Circle

Circle Green Park in Woodlands Circle is a stretch of greenery and playground sandwiched among HDB blocks. If you simply drove past you’d never guess that it’s home to one of the biggest net outdoor playgrounds in Singapore! This playground is about 3 storeys high with a massive slide, bridge and climbing nets, so it’s best suited for older kids. There are also two other outdoor playgrounds nearby that are great for younger ones. For food, walk down for about 10 minutes to Woodlands Mart (768 Woodlands Ave 6, Singapore 730768) where there are two food courts, a few convenience shops and a McDonald’s.

Playground location: Circle Green Park, Woodlands Circle
How to get to Woodlands Circle Green Park Outdoor Playground: By car – parking available at Woodlands Mart, Blocks 737A, 739A and 728A. Admiralty MRT Station is about a 15-minute walk away.

40. Woodlands Waterfront Park Playground: Views of the Johor Strait

On the chance that Admiralty Park is crowded, drive a little down the road and you’ll find Woodlands Waterfront Park around the corner! Woodlands Waterfront Park is a lovely coastal park in Woodlands that offers amazing sea views and is so close to Johor, Malaysia (you can even see the Singapore-Malaysia border from the jetty!). We love coming here at sunset! The Woodlands Waterfront Park playground has two-storey high climbing nets, playground swings and small slides for younger ones. There’s Rasa Istimewa Restaurant on site (halal) offering Malay and fusion food, delicious satay and icy desserts.

Playground location: Woodlands Waterfront Park, Admiralty Road West, Singapore 759956
How to get to Woodlands Waterfront Park Playground: By car – park right at Woodlands Waterfront Park. Bus 856 from Woodlands Bus Interchange stops right at the park. It’s a 30-minute walk to Woodlands MRT station.

41. 852 Woodlands Playground: Dragon playground in Woodlands

You’ll likely see this dragon playground in Woodlands from the street, before you even reach it. A neighbourhood icon, the Block 852 Woodlands Playground is home to another iconic dragon! It’s got plenty of ropes for kids who love to climb and scope out the street below. There are also Chinese zodiac animal sculptures in the vicinity, which the young ones will love.

Playground location: 852 Woodlands Street 83, Singapore 730852
How to get to 852 Woodlands Playground: By car; park at Blk 852 Woodlands, 10-minute walk from Woodlands MRT

42. Fu Shan Garden Playground: Dinosaur-themed playground in Woodlands

Who knew that Stegosaurus and Triceratops could be spotted in the heartlands, disguised as one of the cutest playgrounds in Singapore? Located in Woodlands, this cosy dinosaur-themed playground houses life-sized structures of the dinosaurs with climbing stilts and fireman slides, making it a suitable play space for toddlers.

Playground location: Fu Shan Garden Playground, 81 Woodlands Street 81, Singapore 730827
How to get to Fu Shan Garden Playground: 8-minute walk from Woodlands MRT

Read more: Where To See Dinosaurs In Singapore: Dino Museums, Parks & More

43. The Playground @ Northpoint City: Playground with water play area

Northpoint City has wet water park and dry playgrounds at Level 4, water slides and a water-dunking machine perfect for beating the tropical heat. The little ones will love the water features, jets and fountains in this aquatic-themed playground in Singapore. When you’re done having fun, there are shower facilities to get the kids cleaned up after a day of splashing good time! Do note that the playground is closed every first Monday of the month for maintenance works.

Playground location: Northpoint City, Level 4, 930 Yishun Ave 2, Singapore 769098
How to get to The Playground @ Northpoint City: 5-minute walk from Yishun MRT

44. Yishun N8 Park Playground: Near Khatib MRT

This playground is a short walk from Khatib MRT station – you’ll spot it from its colourful houses built on stilts. There are two sets of playhouses with fun slides, tunnels, climbing nets and swings, where little ones can burn off their energy. There are even mini trampolines built into the ground that kids will love. While the kids run around, parents can sit back and enjoy the view of an open football field and the lush greenery.

Playground location: Yishun N8 Park, No. 809, Yishun Ring Road, #04-4229, Singapore 760809
How to get to Yishun N8 Park playground: 5-minute walk from Khatib MRT

Best Outdoor Playgrounds In Singapore: North-East

45. Waterway Point: Happy Park Playground

Happy Park playground at the top of Waterway Point is massive, with multiple slides and climbing nets and even a water play area! Make sure to bring an extra change of clothes and keep your eye out while the kids play. Since the dry and wet play areas are right next to each other it’s all bound to get wet and the playground may be a bit slippery.

Playground location: Waterway Point, 83 Punggol Central, Singapore 828761
How to get to Happy Park Playground at Waterway Point: By car – park at Waterway Point.

46. Waterway View Playground: Ship-themed playground

This playground in Singapore boasts a ship theme, with activities for the little ones on both the upper and lower deck, ensuring a spacious and adventurous playspace for the younger and older kids. There are climbing features and slides, including creative features that imitate a ship, so the little ones can get imaginative during their play!

Playground location: Waterway View, 682C Edgedale Plains, Singapore 823682
How to get to Waterway View Playground: By car – park at Waterway View carpark.

47. Bukit Canberra: Forest Gym outdoor playground

Tucked away in the Bukit Canberra integrated sports and community centre is the Forest Gym, a free outdoor playground that’s perfect for adventurous kiddos. It’s got rock walls, balancing beams, climbing nets and so much more! We also love that almost everything is built with natural materials and is surrounded by beautiful landscaping and greenery, allowing families and kids to be one with nature.

Playground location: Bukit Canberra sports and community centre
How to get to Forest Gym at Bukit Canberra: Bukit Canberra is a six to seven-minute walk from Sembawang MRT Station. Head to Level 2, then up the stairs towards the Forest Gym.

48.  Anchorvale Village: Mall outdoor playground

Anchorvale Village features two playgrounds where kiddos can run around, climb and burn off their energy. Sadly, the outdoor playground on level 3 for kids aged two to five is exclusively for the Unicorn Preschool. However, the outdoor playground on level 4 is for kids aged six to 12 and has a super cool climbing net that leads to a birdwatching patio. There are five slides here, so kids don’t have to fight over who gets to whizz down the slide first!

Playground location: Anchorvale Village, 339A Anchorvale Rd, Singapore 541339
How to get to Anchorvale Village playground: By car – park in the underground carpark of Anchorvale Village; by public transport – hop on the Sengkang West LRT train and ride two stops to Farmway. Anchorvale Village is a short two-minute walk from Farmway LRT station.

49. Sengkang Riverside Park Playground: Punggol Reservoir playground

Sengkang Riverside Park has the Punggol Reservoir running through it, making it a lovely spot for an early morning or late afternoon stroll. The Sengkang Riverside Park playground (also called Kidzpatch playground) is a great size for younger kids, with a few slides, swings, bridges and climbing structures. There’s also a sandpit!

Playground location: Sengkang Riverside Park, Anchorvale Street, Singapore 544834
How to get to Sengkang Riverside Park: By car – park right at Sengkang Riverside Park or at the nearby HDB blocks. The Kupang and Farmway LRT stations are nearby.

Read more: Guide To Sengkang Grand Mall

50. Rivervale Shores Outdoor Playground: Birds nest play pods

Nestled within one of the newer HDB estates in the northeast is a bird-themed outdoor playground. Rivervale Shores features three exciting playgrounds for kids aged two to 12 years old, featuring plenty of climbing nets, slides, swings and in-ground trampolines. Kids can climb into a pod that resembles a bird’s nest and whizz down the slide at the speed of light, while younger ones can build sandcastles at the sand pit. Watch our video here.

Playground location: Rivervale Shores, 175A Sengkang East Way, Singapore 541175
How to get to Rivervale Shores Outdoor Playground: the closest bus stop is at 158C Sengkang East Drive, then it is an 8-minute walk into the HDB estate where you can find the outdoor playground. Alternatively, Bakar is the closest LRT station, and the outdoor playground is a 10-minute walk away.

51. Seletar Aerospace Park: Airplane themed outdoor playground

If your kiddo is obsessed with aeroplanes, Seletar Park outdoor playground is perfect for its combination of aeroplane-themed play equipment and the opportunity to watch aircraft landing and taking off at the adjacent private jet airport. On top of all that, you’ve got some great dining options and plenty of open space to play at the nearby Lower Seletar Reservoir. Make sure to check out the water playground at Lower Seletar Reservoir too! Watch our video here.

Playground location: Seletar Park Outdoor Playground, 2 Park Lane, Singapore 798386
How to get to Seletar Park outdoor playground: By car – park at The Oval @ Seletar (free!). Jalan Kayu MRT is a 20-minute walk away.

52. Buangkok Square Park Playground: Kampung-inspired playground

This playground in Singapore takes inspiration from Kampung Lorong Buangkok, which is actually Singapore’s last remaining kampung village! Here, kids can explore the little houses perched on bouncy springs. There are also rabbit burrow holes, perfect for playing hide and seek. If you look closely, there are large brown structures, which are used to mimic fishing poles. The brown structures also hold hammock swings for kids who prefer to lounge after playtime!

Playground location: Buangkok Square Park, Buangkok Crescent
How to get to Little Houses @ Buangkok Square Park Playground: By car – park at Buangkok Square Mall.

53. Punggol Point Cove: Animal-themed & pirate ship outdoor playgrounds

Overlooking the ocean and the entrance to Coney Island, you’ll find adorable tiger and elephant-themed playgrounds featuring slides, climbing opportunities and a merry-go-round for littles. Further inside the estate, there is a pirate ship playground for tots and a fun wooden treehouse playground for older kids.

Playground location: Punggol Point Cove, 446A Punggol Way, Singapore 821446
How to get to Punggol Point Cove outdoor playgrounds: Take the MRT to Punggol Coast and exit via Exit 2. Walk towards black and white HDB buildings to find Punggol Point Cove.

54. Punggol Waterway Outdoor Playground: Crocodile playground & sand play

There is more reason to spend the day in Punggol! Punggol Waterway now has three new outdoor play spaces for kids. Designed by local artists, this Play@Punggol installations feature a crocodile playground and sand play area for kids aged 2 to 12, a giant pencil installation with chalkboards to inspire creativity and a Flora and Fauna Kinetics Playscape where nature comes to life.

Playground location: Pencil Installation: Outside Waterway Point; Crocodile Outdoor Playground: Near Adventure Bridge; Kinetic Playscape: Near SAFRA Punggol
How to get to the Punggol Waterway outdoor playgrounds: Pencil Installation: Closest MRT is Punggol MRT; Crocodile Outdoor Playground: 500 metres from Waterway Point; Kinetic Playscape: Sam Kee Punggol LRT station

Best Outdoor Playgrounds In Singapore: West

55. Jurong Lake Gardens Outdoor Playground: Forest Ramble Playground

The nature-inspired outdoor playgrounds at Lakeside Garden have fun structures to climb on, swing from and slide down – there’s so much for kids of all ages. Officially this outdoor play area is for kids aged 5 to 12 years old, but younger kids will have fun here too. Clusia Cove is the park’s water play area and when you’re hungry there’s Fusion Spoon cafe for casual Western and Asian food. Do note that Forest Ramble playground and Clusia Cove are closed on Mondays.

Playground location: Jurong Lake Gardens, 100 Yuan Ching Road, Singapore 618662
How to get to Jurong Lake Gardens Outdoor Playground: By car – park at Jurong Lake Gardens North Carpark. Closest MRT station is Lakeside MRT.

56. Yung Ho Spring @ Taman Jurong Park: Eco-friendly playground

This playground in the west of Singapore was revamped in 2019 as part of the neighbourhood renewal programme, and we can’t deny how this playground instantly adds colour to this mature estate! This playground is also the 2017 LIAS award-winning Play Curl playground, and kids can explore through the different crawling, climbing, sliding features and more. This playground in Singapore is also located near Jurong Lake Gardens. Check out our guide here!

Playground location: 157 Yung Ho Spring, 157 Yung Loh Rd, Singapore 610157
How to get to Yung Ho Spring @ Taman Jurong Park playground: By car – park at Block 157 Yung Ho Spring.

57. Boon Lay Glade: Fire station tower playground

Kids who love their fire trucks will have a field day at the Boon Lay Glade playground. Built at a refurbished fire station tower that spans seven storeys high, this playground is all about firetrucks and emergency vehicles. There are three playgrounds in total, with play structures suitable for kids of all ages. We love that it also has a mini fire station tower with two spiralling slides older kids will be happy to camp out at! Watch our video here.

Playground location: 238 Boon Lay Dr, Singapore 640238
How to get to Boon Lay Glade Playground: By car – park at Blk 237 Boon Lay Dr. The closest MRT stations are at Boon Lay and Lakeside.

58. Choa Chu Kang Playground: The Arena @ Keat Hong

Choa Chu Kang Playground, also known as The Arena @ Keat Hong, makes waves for its three amazing outdoor playgrounds in one sprawling space. With a stunning treehouse-like tower, massive slides, pirate ship play equipment and swings, there’s something fun for children of all ages in each of the three playgrounds. The first outdoor playground is pirate-themed with slides and lower climbing structures suitable for kids aged two to five. Look out for merry-go-rounds and also parent-child swings at this playground. The other two playgrounds at The Arena @ Keat Hong are more suitable for older kids with massive slides, towers, cargo nets and climbing equipment. You’ll also find lots of sports facilities at The Arena @ Keat Hong from Pétanque to volleyball, basketball and more!

Playground location: The Arena is located between Choa Chu Kang Avenue 4 and 5.
How to get to The Arena @ Keat Hong playground: By car – park at Block 428 Choa Chu Kang Ave 4. It’s a 9-minute walk from Choa Chu Kang MRT station.

59. West Coast Park Playground: Huge outdoor playground in the West

West Coast outdoor playground is huge with lots of different subsections to play at – kiddos highly rate the giant climbing pyramid at its centrepiece! There’s also a pirate ship playground with swings and a sandpit, a separate inclusive outdoor playground, and no less than four flying foxes. The park also has a nice wide-open expanse for kite flying, bicycling tracks and even karting! Consider yourself warned that there’s a McDonald’s nearby (decent for coffee!).

Playground location: West Coast Park, 70 West Coast Highway, Singapore 126978
How to Get to West Coast Park Playground: By car – park at West Coast Park Carpark 3. Haw Par Villa MRT Station is about a 30-minute walk away.

60. Bukit Batok Playground: Long tube slide & climbing nets

Bukit Batok outdoor playground has bright yellow swirling tube slides to whizz down, and a smaller green outdoor playground geared towards preschoolers with its short slide, easy climbing structure and shaded mini den. Also look out for the small balancing obstacle course where kiddos can try to navigate while hanging on the ropes! When the kids have finished playing, take a stroll along the stunning elevated boardwalk that leads towards the summit point at the peak of Bukit Batok Neighbourhood Park.

Playground location: Bukit Batok Neighbourhood Park outdoor playgrounds are along Bukit Batok Central road.
How to get to Bukit Batok outdoor playground: By car – park at Bukit Batok Central near Block 225. It’s a 10-minute walk from Bukit Batok MRT station.

61. Yew Tee Lifestyle Corridor: Unique oil drum design with climbing elements

Yew Tee’s Lifestyle Corridor just got an upgrade, featuring a unique oil drum-themed playground, a nod to the area’s history as an oil storage village during World War II. Perfect for older kids aged six and up, this playground offers plenty of climbing elements. Just a short walk away is the water play area, complete with fountains, a slide for the little ones, and more.

Playground location: Next to Yew Tee MRT
How to get to Yew Tee Lifestyle Corridor outdoor playground: It’s a short walk from Yew Tee MRT

62. Tengah Garden Court & Garden Terrace: Insect playgrounds

One of the newest housing complexes in the North has the most adorable outdoor playgrounds in Singapore. Enter: the insect playgrounds of Tengah. Between the Garden Court and Garden Terrace housing estates, you’ll find six adorable playgrounds: The Leaf Insect Playground, Praying Mantis Playground, Ladybug Playground, Spider Playground, Beetle Playground and the Bee Playground. These playgrounds take the shape of said insects, and comprise slides, swings, climbing structures and lots of room for running around.

Playground location: Garden Court @ Tengah and Garden Terrace @ Tengah
How to get to the insect playgrounds at Tengah: Buses 992, 991 and 871 head to the area. The nearest MRT stations are Chinese Garden MRT, Bukit Gombak MRT and Bukit Batok MRT which are a 20-30 minute bus ride from the neighbourhood.

63. Plantation Grange: Tengah fruit-themed playgrounds

When it comes to imaginative playgrounds, Tengah is where it’s at. Over at the Plantation Grange HDB estate, you’ll find a series of adorable fruit-themed playgrounds–there are seven in total! Explore the area and you’ll find a durian and pineapple playground, treehouses, and lots of fruit and farm-themed play structures.

Playground location: Various locations around Plantation Grange, Tengah Garden Avenue, Singapore
How to get to the Tengah plantation playgrounds:  The nearest MRT station is Chinese Garden MRT, from which you can take a 30-minute bus ride plus walk to the estate. Buses 674, 870, 871 and 992 also service the area.

Tag us on @sassymamasg to let us know which outdoor playgrounds you visit! 

Read more:

The post UPDATED: 63 Best FREE Outdoor Playgrounds In Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: What’s New In June: NEW Jurassic World, Mandai ZooSchool, FutureWorld’s Reopening & More
item.dc:creator: Cherilyn
item.description:
This June, check out new kids’ activities, a free play space, a kid-friendly exhibition and revamped spaces including SuperPark Singapore and ArtScience Museum. New month, new finds! This month, there are two new openings to make a beeline for, including a dinosaur park at Cloud Forest, a free interactive play space at Asian Civilisations Museum […]

The post What’s New In June: NEW Jurassic World, Mandai ZooSchool, FutureWorld’s Reopening & More appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
This June, check out new kids’ activities, a free play space, a kid-friendly exhibition and revamped spaces including SuperPark Singapore and ArtScience Museum.

New month, new finds! This month, there are two new openings to make a beeline for, including a dinosaur park at Cloud Forest, a free interactive play space at Asian Civilisations Museum and the revamped SuperPark Singapore. Plus, Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 is back with baby-friendly installations, SuperPark Singapore gets a revamp, and ArtScience Museum‘s acclaimed Future World reopens along with a new collaborative artwork exhibit.

Click here for past What’s New Mama finds!

Disclaimer: These are external events not owned or managed by Sassy Mama. Always check with the organiser for changes or cancellations.

Mandai ZooSchool: Singapore’s first wildlife adventure school

Keen to give your kids a learning experience like no other? Check out ZooSchool‘s exciting adventure programmes, specially designed for kids aged 3 to 12. Choose from a two-hour programme where kids can join an exciting card game challenge to learn fun facts about animals, or a full-day programme that includes wildlife interactions, basic first aid training and zookeeper talks. Plus, keep an eye out for their upcoming parent-tots nature-play sessions that are in the works!

Deets: Mandai ZooSchool, 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, www.zooschool.mandai.com

Jurassic World At Cloud Forest: Life-sized dinos & petting zoo

Got a dino fan at home? Get tickets to Cloud Forest’s newest addition–Jurassic World: The Experience. Here, dino fans can marvel at life-sized animatronic dinosaurs while soaking in the cool and relaxing atmosphere of the Cloud Forest at Gardens by the Bay. Watch the prehistoric world come to life with an 8.5-metre tall Brachiosaurus that’s almost three stories high, a terrifying Tyrannosaurus rex, and more. Look out for tiny Composognathus hidden within the pathways, plus get up close with baby dinosaurs at the Petting Zoo area.

Deets: Jurassic World: The Experience, Cloud Forest at Gardens by the Bay, 18 Marina Gardens Drive, Singapore 018953, www.gardensbythebay.com.sg

Read more: Where To See Dinosaurs In Singapore

Singapore Symphony Orchestra: Exciting family concerts

From 10am on 10 June 2025, you can book your tickets to Singapore Symphony Orchestra’s upcoming family concerts because there’s something for every music lover! Embark on a symphonic space adventure and navigate a galaxy of planets at Young Spacefarer’s Guide to the Orchestra (6 September 2025, 11am & 2pm), perfect for families new to the orchestra. Bring babies along for SSO Babies’ Proms (13 & 14 September 2025, 11am & 2pm), an energetic and engaging session where you and your little ones can move freely during the concert.

For Halloween, check out SSO’s Temasek Foundation × SSO: Halloween Spooktacular! (1 November 2025, 11am & 2pm; 2 November 2025, 11am), a spine-tingling concert with ghoulish giggles, mysterious melodies and plenty of Halloween flair. Next year, Wild Symphony with Maestro Mouse and his animal friends (21 March 2026, 11am & 2pm; 22 March 2026, 11am) will bring Dan Brown’s bestselling children’s book to life with poetry, animated visuals and enchanting melodies. Plus, come an hour before the show for pre-show activities, including the ever-popular Instrument Petting Zoo, so little ones can try playing the harp, cello and trumpet!

Note: Concerts for Children shows are recommended for children aged 5 and above, and SSO Babies’ Proms are recommended for children aged 6 and below. For SSO Babies’ Proms, admission is free for children under 2 if they are accompanied by an adult with a ticket.

Deets: Singapore Symphony Orchestra Family Concerts, Esplanade Concert Hall & Victoria Concert Hall, www.sso.org.sg

Read more: Must-Watch Kids’ Theatre Shows & Concerts

Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025: Eight art installations for kids

Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 is back at National Gallery Singapore with eight interactive art installations for kids of all ages. The theme of this edition is “Tomorrow We’ll Be” and spotlights four core values: Joy, Kindness, Dream and Love. For the first time ever, all of the installations are baby-friendly so they can explore the world through multi-sensorial art installations and engaging programmes like storytelling workshops, adventure trails, craft activities and more.

Deets: Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025, National Gallery Singapore, 1 Saint Andrew’s Road, Singapore 178957, www.nationalgallery.sg

ACM & ME: New play space at Asian Civilisations Museum

ACM & ME is a new family-friendly space at the Asian Civilisations Museum that invites the young and young-at-heart to discover who they are through hands-on activities, sensory experiences and plenty of play! Explore three thematic zones to answer these questions: “Who am I?”, “What’s my story?” and “What can I create?” Each zone encourages you to unleash creativity through art, music and play–the sky is the limit!

Deets: Asian Civilisations Museum, 1 Empress Place, Singapore 179555, www.nhb.gov.sg

Read more: Must-Visit Kid-Friendly Museums & Exhibitions In Singapore

Mandai: New wildlife experiences & promos

Celebrate SG60 at Mandai with new wildlife experiences and fabulous deals and promos for family memories this June holidays! From 7 June 2025, Hello from the Wild launches with 20-minute experiences that will give you up-close encounters with the gentle capybara at River Wonders and fennec foxes and ring-tailed lemurs at Singapore Zoo. Plus, Backstage Pass: Penguin Encounters gives you the chance to meet adorable penguins at Bird Paradise. Plus, there are great deals to cop! Get two admission tickets to Singapore Zoo or River Wonders at $60, while seniors can enjoy the “Friends of Mandai” five-park membership at a special rate of $60.

Deets: Mandai Wildlife Group, 80 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729826, www.mandai.com

SuperPark Singapore: Revamped with 13 new attractions

SuperPark Singapore reopens its doors, and it’s bigger and bolder than ever before! Look forward to 34 exhilarating activities, including 13 brand-new installations and an in-park café. Spanning 25,000 square feet, this indoor playground in Singapore is one that your kids will want to come back to for more unstoppable fun. From an interactive games arena to an adventure zone with a climbing wall and a new Airbag Donut Slide, this indoor playground promises fun for the whole family!

Deets: SuperPark Singapore, 3 Temasek Boulevard, #01-488 Suntec City Mall, Singapore 038983, www.superpark.com.sg

ArtScience Museum: New installation & revamped exhibition

Head to ArtScience Museum to explore a new installation created by renowned South Korean artist Do Ho Suh and his two daughters. Sculpted from colourful clay, Artland features fantastical plants, creatures and landscapes, inviting the young and old to contribute their own clay creations to this collaborative artwork. Plus, don’t miss the revamped Future World: Where Art Meets Science which features major new installations by teamLab that explore the beauty of nature.

Deets: ArtScience Museum, 6 Bayfront Avenue, Singapore 018974, www.marinabaysands.com

Retykle: Pre-loved pop-up shop at Plaza Singapura

Check out Retykle’s pop-up shop at Plaza Singapura where you can get 50 to 90% off over 2,500 preloved and new designer kids’ fashion brands. From Bonpoint to Ralph Lauren, Jacadi, Moncler and more, you’re sure to find cute kids’ fashion to update the kids’ wardrobe. They add fresh pieces every week, so you’ll always have a reason to visit again. Plus, your pop-up (and online) purchases are also saved to your Retykle Virtual Closet so you can easily resell them when the kids have outgrown them!

Deets: Retykle at Plaza Singapura, 68 Orchard Road, #04-14, Singapore 238839, www.retykle.sg

Read more: Best Flea Markets, Fairs & Farmer’s Markets In Singapore

Raffles Sentosa Singapore: New luxury all-villa resort opens

If you fancy a luxurious getaway from the hustle and bustle of city life, retreat to Raffles Sentosa Singapore, the first all-villa resort on Sentosa Island. Here, you’ll be surrounded by lush greenery, and you can unwind in a villa that will make you feel like royalty with expansive floor-to-ceiling windows. Each villa comes with a private pool and outdoor terrace, and you can enjoy the legendary Raffles Butler service for ultimate comfort and convenience. For a holistic experience, indulge in a relaxing massage, hit the gym or enjoy a science-backed facial.

Deets: Raffles Sentosa Singapore, 4 Bukit Manis Road, Sentosa, Singapore 09947, www.raffles.com

Read more: Kid-Friendly Guide To Sentosa 

The post What’s New In June: NEW Jurassic World, Mandai ZooSchool, FutureWorld’s Reopening & More appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Primary 1 Registration 2025: Key Dates For Registering Your Child For Primary School In Singapore
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
The Primary 1 Registration Exercise for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents begins on Tuesday, 1 July 2025. Find out how to register your child for P1, key P1 registration dates, what each phase means and all the must-knows for parents. Primary 1 is a big year for families, but it all starts the year before, […]

The post Primary 1 Registration 2025: Key Dates For Registering Your Child For Primary School In Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
The Primary 1 Registration Exercise for Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents begins on Tuesday, 1 July 2025. Find out how to register your child for P1, key P1 registration dates, what each phase means and all the must-knows for parents.

Primary 1 is a big year for families, but it all starts the year before, when the Primary 1 registration exercise begins. Fret not, our comprehensive guide has all you need to know about the P1 registration exercise for local primary schools. Families interested in registering their children born between 2 January 2019 and 1 January 2020 (both dates inclusive) can now mark their calendars for the P1 registration exercise that begins on 1 July 2025, for the academic year of 2026. All 2025 P1 registrations will be conducted online, as it was in the past years, and there will not be any in-person registration at schools.

The Primary 1 registration exercise is conducted over several phases. Phase 1, 2A, 2B and 2C Supplementary apply to children who are Singapore Citizens (SC) and Permanent Residents (PR). Phase 3 is for international students. If your child is Singaporean or Permanent Resident and has an older sibling already enrolled in a local primary school, parents are required to submit an application directly to the school from 9am on Tuesday, 1 July 2025 to 4:30am on Thursday, 3 July 2025 (Phase 1 of the 2025 P1 registration process). The primary school where the older sibling is currently studying will provide parents with more details on how to register their younger child.

For Phases 2A, 2B and 2C, the link to the online form and user guide will be available on the MOE P1 Registration website during the registration periods of the respective phases. Read on for all the key Primary 1 registration dates to note down in your calendar, as well as must-knows for parents.

Jump to:
– Primary 1 Registration Key Dates & Deadlines
– P1 Registration for international students
– Frequently Asked Questions for Primary 1 Registration

Key dates for P1 Registration 2025

You may be wondering, “Which phase can I register my child for Primary 1?” There are six phases in total, with specific criteria and deadlines. Refer to the handy table below for the one that your child qualifies for:

Phase 1: 1 July, 9am to 3 July, 4.30pm
Phase 2A: 10 July, 9am to 11 July, 4.30pm
Phase 2B: 21 July 9am to 22 July, 4.30pm
Phase 2C: 29 July 9am to 31 July, 4.30pm
Phase 2C Supplementary: 18 August, 9am to 19 August, 4.30pm

Two schools with a cap on intake of PR kids for P1 Registration 2025

MOE announced in 2020 that there will be a 25 to 30% cap on the intake of PR children at select primary schools, for Phases 2C and 2C Supplementary only so as to “encourage interaction between Singapore citizens and PR children, and facilitate the integration of PR children into Singapore.”

For the 2025 P1 Registration Exercise, there is a PR cap for the following schools:

– Bukit Timah Primary School
– Cantonment Primary School

Are international students eligible for 2025 P1 registration?

If you are neither a Singaporean citizen nor PR, note that all non-PR foreigners are required to complete an “online indication of interest,” which will only be live on the MOE website from 9am on Tuesday, 27 May 2025 to 4.30pm on Monday, 2 June 2025, otherwise you will not be able to register in Phase 3 of the P1 Registration Exercise. Info on documents needed here.

International students (IS) can only register for P1 during Phase 3 of the P1 Registration Exercise, after all Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents have been allocated a place under the earlier phases. You will be notified by October 2025 whether your child can be offered a P1 place. Check out the Ministry of Education’s specific instructions here.

  Read more: Why we chose local Singapore schools for our expat kids

FAQs for Primary 1 Registration 2025

1. After registering interest in June 2025 what comes next?

In October 2025, families selected by MOE as eligible to register will be contacted to bring ALL original documents listed below in person to a designated school for verification. Take note that both parents’ original passports and identity cards will be required so manage travel plans accordingly. More info on documents needed here.

2. How can I update my child’s vaccinations and check what is required?

Regarding vaccinations: To update all vaccination records, you can scan and email all vaccinations along with the child’s FIN number, full name to the Health Promotion Board at hpb_nir@hpb.gov.sg.

Click here to see the Singapore vaccination schedule

3. How can I improve my odds of getting a spot in a local school?

Admission to local schools for foreigners (children without PR or citizenship) is decided at the discretion of the Ministry of Education. All families can do is follow the process by the deadline, submit the required documentation, and hope for a favourable outcome.

4. I hear that even if I am PR, I won’t get a spot in a local school.

This is untrue. All children holding PR or citizenship are guaranteed a spot in a local school. Be sure to review the registration by phases to learn the steps required if your child is not a foreigner.

5. How do I get into a “good school” as a foreigner?

Admission to local schools and choice of schools for foreigners (children without PR or citizenship) is decided at the discretion of the Ministry of Education.

Read more: Expat Reflections after a Year in Local Singapore Primary School

6. I am PR but my child is not, what do we do?

You register during the Phase 3 registration as a non-PR foreigner. The immigration status of the child signals the phase of registration, regardless of the status of the parent.

7. What if our application is denied?

This is a likely outcome. All decisions are final and appeals are not considered. All families should prepare a backup plan for the education of their child should the local school application not succeed.

Read more: Guide to International Secondary Schools in Singapore

8. Can I register next year?

Foreigners wanting to register outside of the P1 registration phases will have to take a rigorous standardised test called the AEIS and admission is at the discretion of the Singapore government. For more information consult the Ministry of Education. Click here to read about one mama’s experience when her son took the AEIS.

9. I want to register my child for a local school, but they were not born between 2 January 2019 and 1 January 2020 

Outside of the P1 registration, all foreign children applying for a local school must take the AEIS exam. Admission to the school is at the discretion of the Singapore government. For more information, consult the Ministry of Education!

10. What happens if I missed the phase my child is eligible for? 

You can still register your child in the next eligible phase, but there will be no priority given. If you missed the 2025 P1 Registration Exercise completely and do not have approval from the MOE for deferment, you can contact the MOE to enrol your child into a school with vacancies.

More Resources:

  • Singapore Expats in Local Schools Facebook Group
  • Singapore Expat Schooling Forum Facebook Group
  • Kiasu Parents (for school ranking)

Read more: 

The post Primary 1 Registration 2025: Key Dates For Registering Your Child For Primary School In Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: ArtScience Museum In Singapore: Family Guide, Revamped Future World Exhibit & More
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Step into a whole new world at ArtScience Museum Singapore, known for its otherworldly and inspirational exhibits. Don’t miss the kids’ favourite exhibition, Future World – which just got a stunning revamp! – and check out the ArtScience Museum ticket promos where kids enter for free on Fridays! One of Singapore’s best things to do […]

The post ArtScience Museum In Singapore: Family Guide, Revamped Future World Exhibit & More appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Step into a whole new world at ArtScience Museum Singapore, known for its otherworldly and inspirational exhibits. Don’t miss the kids’ favourite exhibition, Future World – which just got a stunning revamp! – and check out the ArtScience Museum ticket promos where kids enter for free on Fridays!

One of Singapore’s best things to do with kids, the ArtScience Museum at Marina Bay Sands boasts interactive exhibits, captivating displays, and engaging artworks, making it a go-to museum for families. It’s home to the iconic permanent exhibit, Future World: Where Art Meets Science, known for its whimsical light projections and Instagrammable spots. The much-loved exhibit just reopened its doors on 31 May 2025 and now features stunning new installations, just in time for the June holidays. 

The museum also plays host to seasonal exhibits, most of which blend technology with art. This family-friendly attraction in Singapore also has plenty of kid-friendly programmes. Intrigued? Read our guide to ArtScience Museum for your next weekend outing. 

Future World: Where Art Meets Science is temporarily closed for revamp works. Scroll down for more things to do at ArtScience Museum.

Read more: Guide to Science Centre Singapore with Kids: Top 10 Tips for Families

Jump to:
– ArtScience Laboratory at ArtScience Museum
– Future World: Where Art Meets Science
– Slide at ArtScience Museum
– Best Photo Spot at ArtScience Museum
– Other Exhibits at ArtScience Museum
– Food at ArtScience Museum
– ArtScience Museum Opening Hours
– ArtScience Museum Tickets & Promos
– How to Get to ArtScience Museum

Highlights at ArtScience Museum In Singapore:

Future World: Where Art Meets Science at ArtScience Museum (NEW installations!)

Undoubtedly, the Future World: Where Art Meets Science permanent exhibition comes to mind when one thinks of the ArtScience Museum. This stunning gallery was made in collaboration with teamLab Singapore–a well-known art and technology collective – and features engaging and enchanting digital installations crafted by combining art and technology. This digital wonderland aims to create a space for all ages where imagination knows no boundaries. Yes mums and dads, there’s fun for the adults too!

The exhibition just reopened its doors on 31 May 2025 after undergoing a revamp, and now features a more expansive space with new interactive installations! Starting with the very first installation you’ll see upon entry — Continuous Life and Death — you’ll be greeted by a breathtaking floral display that shifts with the light of day. The immersive experience extends to the digital floor, where flowers bloom and water trails follow your every step as you interact with the exhibit! Just be sure to save some space in your camera roll because there are plenty of photo-ops throughout the stunning exhibits of ArtScience Museum!

Slide at Future World: Where Art Meets Science

As you continue exploring the Future World exhibition, be prepared to have your little ones (or yourself, we don’t judge!) jump with excitement as interactive installations are introduced. For one, there is a giant slide that you can take your shoes off and zoom down! The Sliding Through the Fruit Field now features an extension of Waterfall Droplets, Flowing Down a Slope, which depicts water cascading down a slope and breaking apart into single droplets that bounce when kids climb up the steps to reach the slide!

Immersive drawing at Future World, ArtScience Museum

For the little artists, the ArtScience museum features immersive drawing activities that allow you to get creative with your artwork and have it appear on the screen! This one’s a big hit with the kids, so it might be difficult to get a spot for them to colour their artwork. But don’t worry, there are three different drawing themes available throughout the gallery to ensure every little Picasso gets a chance! We especially love Sketch Flight, which provides an added experience for you to control your artwork on the screen. This exhibition at the Future World, ArtScience Museum also got an upgrade, and now lets you experience the world from the perspective of aeroplanes and living creatures, including butterflies, hawks, and dolphins!

Read more: Kid-friendly Guide to the National Gallery Singapore & Keppel Centre for Art Education

Crystal Universe at Future World: Best photo spot at ArtScience Museum (temporarily closed)

The last installation at Future World is its highlight, the Crystal Universe at the Future World exhibit. This installation enjoys its publicity on Instagram feeds and TikTok for its mesmerising display of light points that create an illusion of an infinite starry universe. This installation at the ArtScience Museum proves itself as the best place in the museum to take photos, so dress accordingly and snap quickly before you have to move along for the next group to come through

Read more: Guide to Children’s Museum Singapore (CMSG): Interactive Exhibitions & Playspaces

Important things to note when visiting Future World at ArtScience Museum Singapore:

The ArtScience Museum is indeed a treat for the young and old, but here are some of our top tips when visiting the ArtScience Museum. 

  • The Future World: Where Art Meets Science exhibition goes by a time slot entry, where visitors are required a timed entry ticket to enter ArtScience Museum.
  • The Future World: Where Art Meets Science exhibition also holds weekly tours every Monday at 4pm! So pre-book a slot for the whole fam.
  • As the gallery sees plenty of visitors daily, strollers are not permitted because of space constraints and safety reasons. For families with strollers, the museum has prepared a designated parking space for strollers near the entrance of the gallery.
  • Be sure to look out for the museum’s latest announcements before you plan your visit!

Other programmes & exhibits at the ArtScience Museum

The ArtScience Museum offers more things to do for the whole family beyond its Future World exhibition. Visitors can also check out the ongoing non-permanent exhibitions. Take a look at the ongoing exhibitions and ticket details here to better plan your family day out! Here are some highlights that you can bring the kids for:

Artland: Build, shape, and play with clay!

Artland is a new hands-on exhibition tucked inside the ArtScience Laboratory, created by South Korean artist Do Ho Suh and his daughters, Aami and Omi Suh. Here, kids can sculpt their own animals and plants using colourful clay, then add their creations to a vibrant, ever-growing ecosystem!

These ecosystems take the form of whimsical clay “islands”, AKA the colourful clay creations located in the exhibition. Each one of these islands are flown in from different parts of the world, where others have contributed their own creative creatures too!

When: 31 May – 14 September 2025
How much: $6 per pax. Purchase your tickets here.

Mirror Mirror: Journey Into the Mind

Illusions, colours, soundscapes and lots of photo-worthy moments–that’s what you can expect at Mirror Mirror: Journey Into the Mind at ArtScience Museum. This ArtScience Museum exhibit comprises eight rooms that’ll allow you to journey through interpretations of the human mind, with plenty of interactive experiences kids can also enjoy.

When: 1 March – 6 July 2025, Friday – Saturday, 10am – 9pm; Sunday – Thursday 10am – 7pm
How much: From $22/adult & $18/child; Free for ArtScience Friends – Get tickets here.

ArtScience Laboratory: A creative learning space

The newly launched ArtScience Laboratory is an exciting learning space for kids (and grown-ups) of all ages! Integrating art, science and technology, visitors will get to discover how they can tap into technology to express their creativity. Look forward to hands-on activities that will explore diverse themes and encourage visitors to learn new skills.

The programmes at the ArtScience Laboratory will feature one of five themes: inspiring workshops, creative activities, engineering explorations, sustainability initiatives and wellness sessions.

When: Friday – Saturday 11am – 9pm; Sunday – Thursday 11am – 7pm
How much: Free and ticketed programmes available

Mind and Body: The Art of Being Human

This exhibition at ArtScience Museum invites visitors to rediscover what it means to think, feel and exist as human beings. The artworks and programmes here are designed to investigate the mind-body relationship and draw attention to the remarkable capabilities of the human mind. Discover unique insights from neuroscience, performance art, radical fashion and technology to learn what makes us human and how we are evolving.

When: Till July 2025
How much: From $40/adult & $32/child – includes access to the ‘Mirror Mirror’ and ‘Iris van Herpen’ exhibits.

Food at ArtScience Museum Singapore

Miracle Coffee: In-house cafe at ArtScience Museum

For a quick bite to fill your tummies before your visit, head to the in-house cafe at the ArtScience Museum called Miracle Coffee, opened by award-winning global superstar, JJ Lin! It now also features an all-new food menu featuring sandwiches, salads, pastries and bakes inspired by local flavours, created in collaboration with Marina Bay Sands’ Executive Pastry Chef Hoi Kuok I.

Miracle Coffee: ArtScience Museum Lobby, 6 Bayfront Ave, Singapore 018974, opening hours: 10am – 7pm daily

There are also plenty of kid-friendly restaurants at Marina Bay Sands for an F&B pitstop after your visit!

ArtScience Museum Singapore opening hours

The ArtScience Museum is open daily from 10am to 7pm, last entry at 6pm. Be sure to plan a day to take the kids and be inspired to creativity as art meets science at the ArtScience Museum.

ArtScience Museum Singapore tickets & promos

Tickets to the ArtScience Museum Singapore cost $30 per adult and $25 per child for Singapore Residents and $35 per adult and $30 per child for tourists. Get tickets here.

ArtScience Museum ticket promo: Up to four children (below 12 years old) can enter the ArtScience Museum for free with every adult ticket purchased every Friday! More info here.

So, what are you waiting for? Get your tickets for a fun family day out!

How to get to the ArtScience Museum Singapore

Getting to the ArtScience Museum is a breeze. Located in Marina Bay Sands, you can opt for various means of transportation, such as trains, buses, taxis and private car hires.

By train: Board the MRT (Mass Rapid Transit) and alight at Bayfront MRT Station (CC6/DT17). The ArtScience Museum Singapore is a 7-minute walk from here.

By bus: The following buses will take you to the ArtScience Museum Singapore: 97, 97E, 133, 133M, 502, 518 or 106. You can alight at any of these bus stops – Marina Bay Sands Theatre Bus Stop (8-minute walk to ArtScience Museum), Bayfront Station Exit B/Marina Bay Sands Bus Stop (12-minute walk to ArtScience Museum).

By taxi/private car hires: Inform the driver to drop you off at the The Shoppes/Casino drop-off point. The museum is a 7-minute walk from here.

By car: Parking facilities are available at Marina Bay Sands. For hassle-free convenience, park at the nearest car park, the North Car Park. The cheaper car park to park at is at the Marina Bay Open Car park (but it’s an uncovered 7-minute walk to the ArtScience Museum).

Read more: Best Free Museums in Singapore

ArtScience Museum Singapore, 6 Bayfront Ave, Singapore 018974, www.marinabaysands.com

Read more: 

 

The post ArtScience Museum In Singapore: Family Guide, Revamped Future World Exhibit & More appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Fun Kids’ Theatre Shows & Musicals In Singapore 2025: Puppet Shows, Circus Acts & More
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
There are plenty of great kids’ theatre shows and kids’ musicals in Singapore! We’ve listed some fun circus acts, energetic live concerts, puppet shows and even FREE concerts for kids. Read on to find all the best kids’ plays and shows in Singapore. We have an abundance of kid-friendly activities, but there’s nothing quite like […]

The post Fun Kids’ Theatre Shows & Musicals In Singapore 2025: Puppet Shows, Circus Acts & More appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
There are plenty of great kids’ theatre shows and kids’ musicals in Singapore! We’ve listed some fun circus acts, energetic live concerts, puppet shows and even FREE concerts for kids. Read on to find all the best kids’ plays and shows in Singapore.
