Designed after the landscape of the New Guinean, you’ll see big birds like the Southern Cassowary, as well as smaller birds like the Nicobar Pigeon, critically endangered White Cockatoo and Blue-eyed Cockatoos.

8. Bird Paradise: Australian Outback aviary

This is home to the second largest living bird in the world – the Emu. Look out for the Laughing Kookaburra (you may hear it before you see it!) and keep your eyes peeled for the master of disguise, the Tawny Frogmouth, as it camouflages as a tree branch (we were so delighted to catch a sight of it! There’s also rumoured to be Red-necked Wallabies in this aviary.

9. Bird Paradise: Winged Sanctuary

Drop by the winged sanctuary to find beautiful birds like the Oriental Pied Hornbill. The birds here are kept in an enclosure, so you won’t have to worry about them perching on your little one’s shoulder.

Penguins at Bird Paradise Singapore

Ocean Network Express Penguin Cove

This state-of-the-art, multi-level indoor Ocean Network Express Penguin Cove is where the flightless birds live – four penguin species – the Gentoo Penguin, King Penguin, Humboldt Penguin and Northern Rockhopper Penguin. Get ready for a magical sub-Antarctic experience at this penguin cove.

We love the landscape of the beach and the projection of Aurora Australia (the southern lights!) that make us feel like we truly are in Antarctica. Plus, don’t miss the Penguin Keeper talk where you’ll get to learn more about these adorable flightless birds and how they are taken care of at Bird Paradise Singapore.

Bird Paradise animal shows

Bird shows/presentations at Bird Paradise happen twice daily at the Sky Amphitheatre, plus there’s a new digital screen that was not previously available at Jurong Bird Park. This huge space has been designed for raptors like the White-bellied Sea Eagle to make longer flights, while other species can take off from higher platforms to showcase flights from heights that were not previously possible at Jurong Bird Park.

Each bird show lasts for 15 to 20 minutes. See the bird trainers in action, and learn about these awesome birds. Pssst! Prep the kiddos to be ready to volunteer if they are up for it – the bird trainers often ask little ones to get on stage to help, and it’s quite a fun experience!

Bird Paradise show times

1. Bird Paradise: Predators on Wings
This bird show stars birds of prey at the top of their food chain, so you’ll get to marvel at fierce and majestic creatures like the White-bellied Sea Eagle, the Turkey Vultures and the Harris’s Hawk.

Show Time: 10:30am & 2:30pm
Bird Show Location: Sky Amphitheatre, Bird Paradise

2. Bird Paradise: Wings of the World
Wings of the World features the most popular birds from parrots to pied hornbill pals Sunny and Vicky. You’ll get to watch a friendly duel between the parrots as they show off their speed, showmanship and agility. Plus, you or the kids can join in the fun by holding a knotted rope with goodies for the parrots.

Bird Show Time: 12:30pm & 5pm
Bird Show Location: Sky Amphitheatre

*Timings are subject to change – always check the website for latest info.

Bird Paradise: Keeper talks schedule

Learn some interesting facts about the gorgeous birds at Bird Paradise from the bird keepers themselves! At this interactive session, the kids will also get to watch the majestic birds enjoy their afternoon snack.

12pm: Macaw Keeper Talk at Hong Leong Foundation Crimson Wetlands
1:30pm: Penguin Keeper Talk at Ocean Network Express Penguin Cove
3pm: Hornbill Keeper Talk at Kuok Group Wings of Asia
4pm: Songbirds Keeper Talk at Songs of the Forest

*Timings are subject to change – always check the website for latest info.

Bird feeding at Bird Paradise

Kids will be able to sign up for bird feeding sessions at Bird Paradise just like they can at the Singapore Zoo. The bird feeding sessions are based on a first-come-first-served basis at a cost of $8. Make sure you book your preferred bird feeding session online and arrive 15 minutes before the feeding time.

1. Bird Paradise: Starlings Feeding
Hand-feed starlings and weavers with mealworms, and colourful turacos with fruits.
When: 9:30am & 2pm
Where: Nyungwe Forest Heart of Africa, Bird Paradise

2. Bird Paradise: Shorebird Feeding
Head to the pavilion overlooking the paddy fields at Kuok Group Wings of Asia, Bird Paradise, and you’ll get to feed the pelicans and storks with fish.
When: 10am & 4:30pm
Where: Kuok Group Wings of Asia, Bird Paradise

3. Bird Paradise: Lories and Lorikeets Feeding
It’s quite a sight to see so many lories all flocking for food – pick up your cup of homemade nectar and feed the birds at Lory Loft, Bird Paradise.
When: 11am & 3:30pm
Where: Lory Loft, Bird Paradise

4. Bird Paradise: Cassowary Feeding
Hand-feed the huge flightless cassowaries – admire their size and their bright blue necks!
When: 1pm
Where Mysterious Papua, Bird Paradise

*Timings are subject to change – always check the website for latest info.

Bird Paradise: Wildlife experiences

1.Bird Paradise: Bird Discovery Tour
If you want to really get up close and personal with the residents of Bird Paradise Singapore, book a Bird Discovery Tour. Walk through Bird Paradise with your very own wildlife guide, who will give you all the inside scoop about their feathered friends.
Wildlife Experience Timing: 10:30am – 12pm & 3:30pm – 5pm
Wildlife Experience Price: From $320 (Mon to Fri) & $400 (Sat, Sun & PH) for up to 8 pax

2. Bird Paradise: Backstage Pass
Want to learn more about how the bird keepers keep the birds healthy? Get behind the scenes to meet the vet at the Avian Hospital and learn how the nutritionists prepare meals for their residents.
Backstage Pass Timing: 1:45pm – 3pm
Backstage Pass Price: from $94.72 per person (Mon to Fri) & $118.40 per person (Sat, Sun & PH)

Bird Paradise: Glamping with the Penguins

Bird Paradise had Glamping with the Penguins in May and June 2024, which gives visitors a chance to stay overnight at the park. The package entailed a one-night stay in a bell tent for four pax at the Ocean Network Express Penguin Cove, park admission to Bird Paradise, a guided tour and bird interactions and lunch at Crimson Restaurant.

The cost for the glamping experience at Bird Paradise was from $1,699 per tent and was available for participants aged 5 years old and above. Stay tuned to see if Glamping with the Penguins will make a return in the future!

Kids’ playgrounds at Bird Paradise

There are a few playgrounds for kids within Bird Paradise that you can access only with a Bird Paradise entry ticket. The first playground that you’ll come to is right next to Starbucks before the entrance of Bird Paradise (so it’s technically part of Mandai West, and as such is free to enter as it’s before the ticketing area of Bird Paradise).

Within Bird Paradise bird park, the main play areas are a dry playground called Treetops Play and a water play area called Egg Splash.

1. Playground inside Bird Paradise: Treetops Play

The dry playground is located near Crimson Restaurant and consists of netted climbing structures with mini trampolines on the second level. Scale the nets like the birds at Bird Paradise!

Where: near Crimson Restaurant and below Food Central (Central Plaza of Bird Paradise)

2. Wet Play inside Bird Paradise: Egg Splash 

Kiddos, get excited because after a morning admiring the birds at Bird Paradise, you can cool off at Egg Splash! This egg-themed water playground offers wet play zones with water slides, sprays and shallow pools. Parents, you can sit in the shade at the sheltered pavilion or Egg Splash café. The water play area offers a perfect chance to cool off for toddlers and little kids.

Where: next to Central Plaza at Bird Paradise
Open: 9:30am – 5:30pm

Food outside Bird Paradise park

There are dining options both inside and outside the bird park. Within Bird Paradise, there are seven F&B outlets, which range from casual eateries to themed dining restaurants.

At Mandai Wildlife West, the public entrance node for Bird Paradise and the upcoming Rainforest Wild, options include Luke’s Lobster, Leckerbaer, COLLIN’S, Han’s Union and Mr Holmes Bakehouse, plus fast food chain A&W, Western restaurant Collin’s, Han’s, Indian restaurant Pavilion Banana Leaf, Coffee House by Old Chang Kee, Starbucks, Cheers and ice-cream parlour Birds of Paradise.

Food within Bird Paradise

1. Bird Bakery (Park Entrance, Bird Paradise)
Coffee, pastries and sandwiches.

2. Penguin Cove Café and Shop (Ocean Network Express Penguin Cove, Level 2, Bird Paradise)
Munch on penguin-themed pastries and watch the penguins in their enclosure.

3. Penguin Cove Restaurant (Ocean Network Express Penguin Cove, Level 1, Bird Paradise)
Buffet spread, featuring iconic local and international flavours – you can see the lower level of the penguin enclosure from here as they dive to a depth of 7m in two aquatic tanks.

4. Food Central (Central Plaza, Bird Paradise)
Casual dining with local favourites like Hainanese chicken rice to Western dishes.

5. Tram Kiosk (Shuttle Station 2, Bird Paradise)
Wide range of premium ice cream flavours and beverages

6. Egg Splash Café and Shop (at the kids’ play area, Egg Splash within Bird Paradise)
Egg dishes prepared in a variety of ways — fried, boiled, poached and more.

7. Crimson Restaurant (Hong Leong Foundation Crimson Wetlands, Bird Paradise)
This restaurant is set against the backdrop of the scenic waterfall and serves a specially curated menu by local celebrity chef Eric Teo.

Sassy Mama Tips for Bird Paradise

  • The aviaries are not covered, so bring hats and wear sunscreen.
  • It gets hot, so we really enjoyed the many hubs between each aviary. These indoor educational spaces have air-con, which provides some relief from the heat and also offers kids loads of information on the birds, including lots of fun hands-on interactive elements.
  • Bird Paradise has lots of covered walkways and is largely stroller-friendly, but there are also kids’ carts, wagons and trikes to rent if you have kids who aren’t big on walking.
  • Bring swimmers for the water play inside Bird Paradise.

Conservation Efforts at Bird Paradise

With nearly half of the global bird populations declining, Bird Paradise aims to help conserve avian species outside of their natural range to prevent extinction. There are breeding programmes for threatened bird species with the aim of maintaining healthy and sustainable populations. Proceeds from all animal feedings go into the conservation projects supported in Singapore and across the region.

Getting to Bird Paradise

MRT: If you’re taking the MRT to Bird Paradise, you can take the train to Khatib, Choa Chu Kang, Ang Mo Kio, or Springleaf MRT stations and then get a connecting bus that will take you straight to Mandai Wildlife Reserve. Find out more here.

Bus and car: For bus schedules and routes plus driving directions to Bird Paradise, click here.

Bird Paradise opening hours

Bird Paradise is open every day of the year from 9am to 6pm (last entry at 5pm). Weekends, public holidays and school holiday periods will likely be the busiest.

Ready to plan your day at Bird Paradise?

Bird Paradise 20 Mandai Lake Road, Singapore 729825, ww.mandai.com

Read More:

The post Bird Paradise Singapore Review & Guide: Bird Feeding, Show Times & Tickets (+ Up To 26% Off Tickets!) appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: FREE Stitch-Themed Carnival At Gardens by the Bay Children’s Festival 2025
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Get ready for Gardens by the Bay’s Children’s Festival (24 May to 15 June 2025) featuring Disney’s Stitch! Read on to find out what’s in store for kids. Looking for things to do during the June school holidays? Children’s Festival at Gardens by the Bay is back from 24 May to 15 June 2025, with […]

The post FREE Stitch-Themed Carnival At Gardens by the Bay Children’s Festival 2025 appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Get ready for Gardens by the Bay’s Children’s Festival (24 May to 15 June 2025) featuring Disney’s Stitch! Read on to find out what’s in store for kids.

Looking for things to do during the June school holidays? Children’s Festival at Gardens by the Bay is back from 24 May to 15 June 2025, with large-scale Stitch-themed installations play areas and fun activities. Just in time for the release of Disney’s Lilo & Stitch, which opens in cinemas on 22 May. Children can explore the value of friendship and family as they discover how to appreciate and accept themselves just as they are.

Here’s what you can expect at Children’s Festival 2025 at Gardens by the Bay.

Children’s Festival 2025

Gardens by the Bay’s signature Children’s Festival is an annual kids’ event that takes place during the mid-year school holidays. This year marks its 11th edition, and Stitch from Disney’s Lilo & Stitch is the main character for this outdoor carnival for the first time ever. Families can snap tonnes of photos with large-scale installations and most of the activities are free!

Read more: June School Holiday Camps

Large-scale installations at Children’s Festival 2025 (FREE!)

Here are some fab installations to look forward to at Children’s Festival 2025.

The Great ‘Ohana Wave: A nearly 7-metre-tall slide for adventurous kiddos to “surf” down from the top, giving them a confidence boost!

Forest of Belonging: An inflatable forest where visitors can uncover hidden messages.

Space Adventure: Hop onboard a swing car to power up light beams and complete missions.

Stitch’s Mischief Makers: The little ones will love this one; this “beach” has kinetic sand for sensory and tactile play, where kids can get creative.

Performances & carnival games at Children’s Festival 2025

Besides its fun installations, Children’s Festival 2025 is back with lots of entertainment for the kids. Stick around for Disney’s Lilo & Stitch meet and greet sessions, as well as dance performances with games and lots of laughter. There’s also a special-edition Garden Rhapsody light and sound show titled ‘The Way to Ohana’!

There are also some fun workshops the kids will loved–all Stitch-themed. Look forward to cosmic and floral crafts such as lanterns, slime, leis and more. Note that all workshops come with a fee of $15/pax and take place on various dates and timings here.

Meet & Greet sessions:
When: 7 & 8 June, 3.45pm, 4.45pm, 5.45pm & 6.45pm
Where: Supertree Grove Lawn
How much: Free entry with limited passes (first come, first served)

The Great Island Series performance:
When: 24, 25, 31 May & 1, 14, 15 June, 5pm – 7pm
Where: Supertree Grove Lawn
How much: Free!

The Way to ‘Ohana light show: 
When: 24 May – 15 June, 7.45pm & 8.45pm
Where: Supertree Grove
How much: Free!

 Read more: Ultimate Guide to Summer in Singapore: Activities + Things to Do

Gardens by the Bay Children’s Festival 2025

Overall, we love that Children’s Season 2025 makes for a fun thing to do over the weekend in Singapore, as well as a free June holiday activity with the kiddos! Plan your day out with the fam here:

When: 24 May – 15 June 2025, 10am – 9pm (installations close at 7pm)
Where: Supertree Grove, Gardens by the Bay
How much: FREE to look around. Some activities are ticketed. More info here.

The post FREE Stitch-Themed Carnival At Gardens by the Bay Children’s Festival 2025 appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 At National Gallery Singapore
item.dc:creator: Aisyah Amin
item.description:
Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 at National Gallery Singapore is free to enter! It’s themed ‘Tomorrow We’ll Be…’ and it features 8 kid-friendly art installations – including baby-friendly artworks for the very first time!” The fifth edition of the Gallery Children’s Biennale, themed ‘Tomorrow We’ll Be’ is back at National Gallery Singapore. This year’s edition is […]

The post Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 At National Gallery Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 at National Gallery Singapore is free to enter! It’s themed ‘Tomorrow We’ll Be…’ and it features 8 kid-friendly art installations – including baby-friendly artworks for the very first time!”

The fifth edition of the Gallery Children’s Biennale, themed ‘Tomorrow We’ll Be’ is back at National Gallery Singapore. This year’s edition is in conjunction with the Gallery’s 10th anniversary and the nation’s 60th birthday, and you can look forward to a showcase of eight art installations by local and international artists that spotlight four core values: Joy, Kindness, Dream and Love.

For the first time ever, all artworks at the Gallery Children’s Biennale are baby-friendly, inviting kids of all ages (and the young at heart!) to explore eight interactive and larger-than-life artworks that stimulate their auditory and visual senses in a safe environment. Visitors are encouraged to think of the endless possibilities of their future through multi-sensorial art installations and engaging programmes.

 Read more: Must-Visit Kid-Friendly Museums & Art Exhibitions In Singapore

Gallery Children’s Biennale: 8 art installations for kids

The Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 invites little ones to dive into eight fun, kid-friendly art installations filled with hands-on play and sensory surprises. To kick things off, kids can grab a Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 Art Pack, which is a colourful kit packed with art supplies, easy-to-follow instructions, and creative prompts inspired by the artworks. With baby-friendly installations featured for the first time, the Art Packs now come in two versions: one for ages six and under, and one for seven and up! Check out full details of each installation below.

1. Embracing the Future with Joy

Some of the installations at the Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 are by local artists, including Embracing the Future with Joy by Fern Wong. This vibrant installation features Fern’s signature papercut art and invites children to explore what happiness means to them through bright hues, playful textures, and patterns. Kids can help complete a giant magnetic wall design adding their own creative touch to the artwork. For the smaller ones, there’s a dedicated corner with a sensorial “busy board” filled with sound makers, mazes, and textured panels designed to support early development while keeping little hands engaged!

Where: Spine Hall

2. Dance Dance Chromatics

At Dance Dance Chromatics, local artist Wyn-Lyn Tan invites children to experience art in motion. This installation is set against a stunning AI-generated video wall inspired by two decades of the artist’s paintings and transforms movement into colour and emotion. Kids can jump, twirl and step on four-floor pads that trigger visual changes in the digital landscape. With motion sensors, little ones get to explore how movement and colour can express joy.

3. Empowering the World through Kindness

Kindness Garden is a sensory-filled installation by Japanese artist Hiromi Tango that encourages children to explore empathy through sight, sound, touch, and smell. Surrounded by oversized flowers, kids can discover messages of kindness written in braille, offering a glimpse into how the visually impaired experience the world. At the heart of the garden is a “sound flower” that invites playful interaction through sound and movement. Designed with inclusivity in mind, the installation also features calm domes filled with lavender-scented plushies, creating a quiet, soothing space especially thoughtful for neurodivergent children.

4. Lessons in Being Kind

Lessons in Being Kind features a stop-motion film by Laotian artist Souliya Phoumivong, where kids can explore themes of identity, self-acceptance, and the power of kindness through the adventures of colourful blob-like characters. Get creative at the activity area by making your own stop-motion videos, and let the kids have fun at the balancing chair!

5. I WE THEM

I WE THEM is a whimsical installation that transforms everyday surroundings into playful, character-like forms. Designed to spark connection and comfort, families are invited to slow down and share moments together. Babies and toddlers can explore freely in a soft ‘flower bed’ filled with gentle sculptures encouraging sensory and emotional development, while older kids will enjoy giving high-fives to a giant inflatable hand and spinning seven rotating discs of different sizes!

6. Home is Where the Heart Is

Inspired by Mohamed Salehuddin’s Malay House in Malacca in 1960, Home is Where the Heart Is is an imagined neighbourhood that celebrates Singapore’s rich and diverse heritage. This vibrant mural invites children to explore what home means to them through playful, interactive elements. Here, they can ring a doorbell, open a neighbour’s door, or listen to greetings from a cheerful ice cream seller. Parents and grandparents can also share memories of past homes, sparking conversations that connect generations and deepen appreciation for the places we come from.

7. Fantasy

Fantasy is an installation by Malaysia-based art collective Co2_karbondioksida that transforms 130kg of upcycled children’s clothing and nearly 400 donated toys into a dreamy, sustainable space. At its centre hangs a large-scale mobile made from repurposed toys. Soft cubes crafted from donated clothes cover the cushioned floor, providing a safe and cosy area for babies and young children to explore. While playing, visitors are also encouraged to think about waste, overconsumption, and the environment.

8. Imaginary Peach Garden

Imaginary Peach Garden by South Korean artist YeSeung Lee blends technology and storytelling through an interactive installation. Inspired by traditional tazo puzzle cards and animals from Korean and Southeast Asian folktales, children can create their own fantastical creatures in two ways: by piecing together physical foam puzzles or using digital devices to form shapes projected onto the wall.

Programmes and workshops at Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025

Throughout Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025, there will be plenty of kid-friendly programmes and workshops that are mostly free to join! These include storytelling workshops, adventure trails, craft activites and more. Check out the full list of programmes on Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025’s website.

Read more: Kid-Friendly Guide To National Gallery Singapore & Keppel Centre for Art Education

How much are tickets for Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025?

It’s free for Singaporeans and PRs to enter Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025. Simply head down to the National Gallery Singapore to explore these exciting art installations and kid-friendly workshops at Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025.

Read more: Kid-Friendly Guide To National Gallery Singapore & Keppel Centre for Art Education

How to get to Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025

By MRT: Get off at City Hall (7-minute walk from exit B), Clark Quay (10-minute walk from exit E) or Raffles Place (10-minute walk from exit B). More deets here.

By bus: Click here for all the public buses that will take you to the Children’s Biennale 2023.

By taxi/car: The taxi stand and drop-off point is at the Coleman Street entrance. If you’re driving, you will need to use Parliament Place and St Andrew’s Road to access the car park. More deets here.

Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025
When: 31 May 2025 – 29 March 2026
Opening hours: 10am – 7pm daily
Address: National Gallery Singapore, 1 St. Andrew’s Road, Singapore 178957

Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025,National Gallery Singapore, 1 Saint Andrew’s Road, Singapore 178957, Tel: (+65) 6271 7000, nationalgallery.sg

The post Gallery Children’s Biennale 2025 At National Gallery Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Singapore Marathons & Running Events In 2025: Fun Runs, Half Marathons, 10km Runs & More
item.dc:creator: Jessica Fang
item.description:
Looking to reach a new fitness goal or simply support a good cause? We’ve got the lowdown on all the best Singapore marathons and running events taking place, including half marathons, 10km runs, fun runs, kids’ runs and more! It goes without saying that Singapore is a fab place for running, especially with so many […]

The post Singapore Marathons & Running Events In 2025: Fun Runs, Half Marathons, 10km Runs & More appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Looking to reach a new fitness goal or simply support a good cause? We’ve got the lowdown on all the best Singapore marathons and running events taking place, including half marathons, 10km runs, fun runs, kids’ runs and more!

It goes without saying that Singapore is a fab place for running, especially with so many family-friendly parks around. That said, you might be looking to challenge yourself to a full marathon (41.195km), a half marathon (21.1km), or even a 10km run or below. Well, you’re in luck because there are so many running events in Singapore and marathons that take place throughout the year! Many of these Singapore marathons also support good causes, and we love that there are plenty that include fun runs and kids’ dashes for some good family fun.

Read on to find out all the running events in Singapore and Singapore marathons taking place. We’re constantly updating this list, so stay tuned for everything including walkathons, half marathons, night runs, fun runs and more!

Read more: Fun Kids’ Events & Things To Do This Weekend

Guide To Singapore Marathons & Runnings Events In Singapore:

National Vertical Marathon 2025: Vertical marathon in Singapore

If you’re always the one saying, “let’s take the stairs,” then the National Vertical Marathon is for you. The National Vertical Marathon is back for its 2025 edition, and this year, the goal is to race up Guoco Midtown. Attempt the challenge solo, or pair up with a buddy to reach the top of the tower. Gather your best runner buddies for the Teams Open, or take it on as a family!

Singapore marathon race categories: Men’s & Women’s Open (aged 16 and up); Veterans’ Open (aged 45 and up); NTU Alumni; Junior Climbers (aged 10 – 16); Teams Open (4 – 5 runners); Duo Challenge (aged 10 and up); Family Fun Run (3 – 5 family members)
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Kids aged 10 and above may join the vertical marathon.

When: 25 May, 7am – 7pm
Where: Guoco Midtown
National Vertical Marathon entry fee: From $24 – register here.

SAFRA Diaper Dash: Baby run in Singapore

The adorable SAFRA Diaper Dash is back and it promises a tonne of fun for the little ones. This year’s SAFRA Diaper Dash takes on a special SG60 theme, with Pororo Park as its partner. There’ll be Pororo meet-and-greet sessions and sing-alongs, and of course, adorable baby races for little ones as young as 6 months old to 36 months old. There are prizes to be won, so it’s going to be an exciting race!

Singapore marathon race categories: 6 categories for various age groups (6 months – 36 months old)
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes! The SAFRA Diaper Dash is for ages 6 – 36 months old!

When: 29 May – 1 June 2025, 10am – 8pm
Where: Marina Square
SAFRA Diaper Dash entry fee: From $60 – register here (fully registered).

Income Eco Run 2025: Half marathon in Singapore, kids’ run & more

A run for competitive runners, families, kids and even cats and dogs? We’re so here for it! There’s so much happening at the Income Eco Run 2025, and it’s all for a great cause as it shines the spotlight on a zero-waste lifestyle. The Income Eco Run is introducing the 1km Pets Category for the very first time, so bring your good furkids to join the cause. Kids as young as 4 years old can also participate in the Kids Categories. It’s all worth it–because for every kilometre each participant clocks, Income Insurance will donate $1 towards the zero waste movement.

Singapore marathon race categories: 3km, 5km, 10km, 15km, 21.1km runs for adults; 700m & 1km run for kids; 1km pet’s run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes! Kids aged 4 – 12 can join the kids categories, and kids aged 13 and up can join the adult categories. Dogs and cats are also welcome for the pets category!

When: 8 June 2025, 4.30am – 11am
Where: Marina Barrage
Income Eco Run entry fee: From $16 – sign up here.

Smurfs Run 2025 Powered by JomRun: Running event in Singapore

Marina Barrage will see a sea of blue as the Smurfs Run takes over on 28 June. This family-friendly weekend event has two non-competitive race categories: a 2km fun walk and a 4km fun run. Complete the Smurfs Run race and you’ll get your finisher medal, and be sure to collect your race pack beforehand, which includes Smurfs-themed keepsakes.

Singapore marathon race categories: 2km fun walk, 4km fun run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? There is no dedicated kids’ category but junior fit tees from 4 years old and above are available.

When: 28 June 2025, 7am
Where: Marina Barrage
Smurfs Run entry fee: From $58.88 – sign up here by 26 June 11.59pm.

Unlabelled Run 2025: Fun run & competitive run in Singapore

As the conversation surrounding mental health continues, there’s no better way to raise awareness about stigmatisation and discrimination than with those who’ve experienced it themselves. Enter: the Unlabelled Run, which is a call to unite society to be more inclusive, cohesive and compassionate and remove prejudicial labels.

Singapore marathon race categories: 5km run, 10km run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Kids aged 6 and above may join the run.

When: 28 June 2025, 7am
Where: OCBC Square, Singapore Sports Hub
Unlabelled Run entry fee: From $39 – sign up here by 31 May 2025.

Cold Storage and Giant Kids Run 2025: Kids marathon in Singapore

Finally, a kids’ marathon perfect for the energetic little ones who love to run! The Cold Storage and Giant Kids Run is back and kids can take part in both competitive and non-competitive races. Some great prizes are up for grabs, including hampers worth up to $400 and trophies for the top finishers. P.S. Strollers are perfectly welcome if you’re coming with younger kids!

P.S. There is a FREE Breakfast Run for all participants taking place on 31 May 2025 from 8am – 11am at Marina Square. It’s limited to the first 300 participants, so be sure to register early.

Singapore marathon race categories: 1.6km non-competitive run; 1.6km & 2km competitive run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes! Kids aged 6 months to 12 years old can join.

UOB Cardmembers get 10% off all categories.


When: 29 June 2025, 8am – 12pm
Where: Siloso Beach, Sentosa
Cold Storage and Giant Kids Run entry fee: From $50 – register here by 20 June 2025.

Crayon Shinchan Singapore Run 2025: Fun run in Singapore

Go back to your childhood manga days–and bring the kids along–at the Crayon Shinchan Singapore Run 2025 Powered by JomRun. Cop adorable Crayon Shinchan race entitlements, including a cute bucket hat that doubles as a pouch.

Singapore marathon race categories: 2km fun walk, 4km fun run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? There is no dedicated kids’ category but junior fit tees from 4 years old and above are available.

When: 29 June 2025, 7am
Where: Marina Barrage
Crayon Shinchan Singapore Run entry fee: From $58.88 – sign up here by 27 June 2025 11:59pm

Buff Forest Force Run 2025: 20km – 50km run in Singapore

The Buff Forest Force Run is not for the faint of heart, but definitely for those who want to push their limits. Known as the oldest trail race in Singapore, the Buff Forest Force Run has four race categories ranging from 10km to 50km! This running event takes place over the span of three days – the first 10km run having wrapped on 4 May 2025. Runners will be traversing through the likes of Dairy Farm Nature Park.

Singapore marathon race categories: 10km (over), 20km, 30km and 50km runs
Is this a kid-friendly running event? The minimum age for the run is 18 years old as of 18 December 2024.

When: 6 July 2025 (20km) & 21 September 2025 (30km & 50km)
Where: MOE Dairy Farm Adventure Centre, Dairy Farm Road, Singapore 679058
Buff Forest Force Run entry fee: From $78 – register here by 5 July 2025 (20km) & 20 September 2025 (30km & 50km)

Lazada Run 2025: Half marathon in Singapore

The Lazada Run 2025 is back for its second run! Taking place across six countries in Southeast Asia, its Singapore edition will be held on 27 July 2025. You’ll want to train hard for this running event because the winners of the competitive 10km and 21.1km categories can win up to $1,000 and $1,500, respectively! Look forward to other fun events such as the Lazada  x POP MART 5km Run, a Voucher Snatch during the regular 5km fun run, and a Cart Dash shopping showdown.

Singapore marathon race categories: 5km Lazada x POP MART 5km run, 5km fun run, 10km run, 21.1km half marathon
Is this a kid-friendly running event? TBA

When: 27 July 2025, from 4.30am
Where: 200 Stadium Boulevard (outside Decathlon)
Lazada Run Singapore entry fee: From $55 – register here by 22 June 2025.

Running Lab Run 2025: 10km run in Singapore

The Running Lab Run takes place at Marina Barrage this year, with two categories: an easy 5km run and a 10km competitive run. Runners will race through the footpaths along Gardens by the Bay East and Tanjong Rhu for a scenic view en route to scoring that medal.

Singapore marathon race categories: 5km Easy Run & 10km Competitive Run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Kids aged 6 years old and up can join the 5km run, while teens aged 16 years old and up can join the 10km run.

When: 24 August 2025, 5.30am – 10am
Where: Marina Barrage
Running Lab Run 2025 entry fee: From $55 (early bird by 31 May) & $60 (normal) – register here.

Pocari Sweat Run 2025: Running event open to kids

The Pocari Sweat Run 2025 is back this year, with three categories and run workshops. Finishers of this Singapore marathon get cool Pocari Sweat medals as well as race entitlements featuring the isotonic beverage’s branding.

Singapore marathon race categories: 2.4km & 5km runs, 10km competitive run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes! Kids aged 4 and above can join the respective categories.

When: 6 September 2025, 7am
Where: Marina Barrage
Pocari Sweat Run 2025 entry fee: From $38 – register here.

Pink Ribbon Walk 2025: Walkathon to support breast cancer awareness

The Pink Ribbon Walk takes place annually in support of breast cancer awareness. This walkathon helps raise awareness and funds for the Breast Cancer Foundation. Stay tuned for more information as details of Pink Ribbon Walk 2025 have yet to be released.

Singapore marathon race categories: TBA
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes! Kids are welcome at the Pink Ribbon Walk.

When: 11 October 2025
Where: TBA
Pink Ribbon Walk entry fee: TBA – stay tuned for info here.

Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon 2025: Biggest running event in Singapore

Arguably Singapore’s biggest marathon of the year, dating back to 1982, the Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon (also known as the Standard Chartered run) takes place at the end of each year. The Singapore Marathon’s 2025 edition is going to be equally as exciting, and runners of all ages are welcome to join! We’ve seen past years’ marathons with participants decked out in fun costumes, so feel free to add some excitement to your challenge.

Singapore marathon race categories: 42.195km marathon, 21.1km half marathon, 10km run, 5km run, Kids Dash, Ekiden, Double Up Challenge
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes! There is a Kids’ Dash and other suitable categories for young runners at the Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon.

When: 6 – 7 December 2025
Where: TBA
Standard Chartered Singapore Marathon entry fee: TBA – stay tuned for info here.

Read more: Where To Find A Personal Trainer In Singapore

Upcoming Runs & Marathons In Singapore 2025

HomeTeamNS Real Run 2025: Family-friendly run in Singapore

The HomeTeamNS Real Run 2025 is a beginner-friendly marathon in Singapore that welcomes participants of all ages. This annual run includes a Fun Walk that’s perfect for families, seniors included–all in the name of promoting a healthier lifestyle.

Singapore marathon race categories: TBA
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes!

When: TBA
Where: TBA

Great Eastern Women’s Run 2025 (TBA)

The Great Eastern Women’s Run is a yearly event made for women, offering a fun and empowering space to come together in the name of health, wellness, and friendship. Beyond the run, it’s also about giving back—supporting causes like Daughters of Tomorrow and the Singapore Cancer Society.

Singapore marathon race categories: TBA
Is this a kid-friendly running event? TBA

When: TBA
Where: TBA
Great Eastern Women’s Run entry fee: TBA

Skechers Friendship Walk 2025 (TBA)

At the annual Skechers Friendship Walk, you can expect a fun walk and fun activities to support underprivileged children. Details for the Skechers Friendship Walk 2025 have yet to be announced, so stay tuned!

Singapore marathon race categories: TBA
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes!

When: TBA
Where: TBA
Skechers Friendship Walk entry fee: TBA

Yellow Ribbon Prison Run 2025 (TBA)

Held every year, the Yellow Ribbon Prison Run is all about supporting second chances. It’s a meaningful movement that encourages the community to embrace ex-offenders and help them rebuild their lives with dignity and purpose. Last year’s Yellow Ribbon Prison Run had a 10km competitive run, a 5km non-competitive run, and even a Kids Dash measuring 700m!

Singapore marathon race categories: TBA

Where: TBA
Yellow Ribbon Prison Run entry fee: TBA

Run for Hope 2025 (TBA)

Run for Hope is a yearly event by Four Seasons Hotel Singapore and the National Cancer Centre Singapore. Run for Hope aims to bring people together to show support and raise awareness for cancer research—a cause that touches countless lives.

Singapore marathon race categories: TBA
Is this a kid-friendly running event? TBA

When: TBA
Where: TBA
Run for Hope entry fee: TBA

Past runs and marathons in Singapore:

Run for Light 2025: 10km run in Singapore

Run for Light is back for its 10th edition, in support of the visually challenged. At this running event, join the signature 1km blindfold walk, followed by a fun run and competitive run. Some great prizes are up for grabs, including a resort stay, vouchers and more, so train up before this marathon in Singapore!

Singapore marathon race categories: 1km blindfold walk, 5km fun run, 10km competitive run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? The run is open to kids 8 years old and above. Kids aged 14 and above may join the 10km competitive run.

When: 12 April 2025, 5pm
Where: Singapore Marina Barrage
Run for Light 2025 entry fee: From $55 (registration has closed)

Snoopy Run 2025: Running event in Singapore

It’s the 75th anniversary of the beloved Peanuts universe, and its titular character Snoopy takes centre stage. Celebrate this comic book icon at the Snoopy Run 2025 Powered by JomRun. Your marathon race entitlements include plenty of official Snoopy Run goodies, including a keychain, bag, socks, sports towel and more! Note that this run is non-competitive so come for the fitness boost and good vibes.

Singapore marathon race categories: 3km run, 5km run, 10km run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? There is no kids category for the Snoopy Run, however, junior fit tees are available and there is a 3km run available.

When: 13 April 2025, from 6am
Where: OCBC Square, Singapore Sports Hub
Snoopy Run 2025 entry fee: From $58.88 (registration has closed)

SpongeBob Pirate Walk & Run: Kids running event in Singapore

Whether you’re a fan of SpongeBob SquarePants or love pirates (and a dose of fresh air and fun), you need to mark your calendars for the SpongeBob Pirate Walk & Run! Families with kids of all ages can enjoy a 3km interactive walk, while runners can take on the more challenging 7km run. Dress the whole family up in your best SpongeBob pirate-inspired outfits and you may just win some fun prizes (check out where to get costumes in Singapore here). Snag some great SpongeBob pirate-themed merch; you’ll get some great ones with your race pack, too!

Singapore marathon race categories: 3km walk, 7km run
Is this a kid-friendly running event? Yes! Kids of all ages are welcome to join.

When: 26 April 2025, 8am
Where: Waterway Point
SpongeBob Pirate Walk & Run entry fee: From $49 (registration has closed)

2XU Compression Run 2025: Half marathon in Singapore

The 2XU Compression Run 2025 takes place at the F1 Pit Building this year. Perfect for running enthusiasts, the 2XU Compression Run is all about tenacity and courage, so you can expect to turn up bright and early surrounded by a competitive spirit!

Singapore marathon race categories: 5km run, 10km run, 21.1km half marathon
Is this a kid-friendly running event? The 2XU Compression Run is open to kids aged 12 and above.

When: 27 April 2025, 4.15am onwards
Where: F1 Pit Building
2XU Compression Run entry fee: From $60 (registration has closed)

More past running events in Singapore:

  • The Music Run Singapore: April 2025
  • Baby Shark Fun Run: November 2024

  • OSIM Sundown Marathon Singapore: Last held in 2023

Get ready to reach your personal fitness goals, support good causes or simply bond as a family at these runs and marathons in Singapore!
