Brewerkz is a popular Singapore-based craft brewery and restaurant, known for its award-winning beers and casual fare. Their sports bars feature multiple large screens for live sports. You can catch live streaming matches of the IPL 2025 at Brewerkz and enjoy an energetic atmosphere with fellow cricket fans!

Brewerkz, multiple locations in Singapore including Fullerton, Riverside Point and Woodleigh, www.brewerkz.com

Harry’s Bar: Live streaming of IPL 2025 at 4 locations

Harry’s Singapore is a sports bar in Singapore with light bar bites for you to enjoy as you catch your favourite IPL 2025 match. You can also order mains, salads, pizzas and pastas if you’re looking for something more filling. Harry’s Singapore will be live streaming IPL 2025 at four of their locations, including Boat Quay, Cuppage, Changi Airport T1 and Changi Airport T3.

Harry’s Singapore, multiple locations in Singapore including Boat Quay, Cuppage and Changi Airport, www.harrys.com.sg

Chilli & Pepper Restaurant & Bar: Live streaming of IPL 2025 at Little India

Chilli & Pepper Restaurant & Bar is an Indian restaurant in Little India that serves up authentic flavours from Indian cuisine. From Paneer to Chicken Tikka, Naan and more, there’s something for everyone. Catch live action of IPL 2025 with delicious Indian food.

Chilli & Pepper Restaurant & Bar, 85 Rowell Road, Singapore 208016, www.chillipepper.com.sg

The BAR Station at TK: Watch IPL 2025 on a big screen

The BAR Station at TK is a casual, alfresco sports bar in Tanjong Katong that offers Western and North Indian cuisine. Opt for a filling pasta or Chicken Briyani, and complement it with your favourite cocktail. Then sit back and enjoy live coverage of IPL 2025 on the big screen!

The BAR Station at TK, 362 Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore 437122, www.facebook.com/thebarstationTK

IPL 2025 Match Schedule

Want to know when your favourite team is playing? Click here for the full IPL 2025 match schedule, so you can save the date and get your booze and popcorn ready!

Read more:

The post Where To Watch The IPL 2025 In Singapore: Sports Bars With Live Coverage & Match Schedule appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: “I cannot imagine moving back to Singapore now” SG Family Talks About Expat Life in Europe
item.dc:creator: Beate
item.description:
“Parenting in Germany focuses on learning through play. Kids learn to be independent and make their own decisions–life skills difficult to teach in a classroom environment.” Oh Chyi Haur and his wife Aida Oh live in Munich, Germany, with their 14-year-old daughter. Both Chyi Haur and his wife were originally Singaporeans, but Chyi Haur became […]

The post “I cannot imagine moving back to Singapore now” SG Family Talks About Expat Life in Europe appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
“Parenting in Germany focuses on learning through play. Kids learn to be independent and make their own decisions–life skills difficult to teach in a classroom environment.”

Oh Chyi Haur and his wife Aida Oh live in Munich, Germany, with their 14-year-old daughter. Both Chyi Haur and his wife were originally Singaporeans, but Chyi Haur became a Swedish citizen 3-4 years ago, while their daughter Chloe is both Singaporean and Swedish. The family lived in Sweden, Japan, and Indonesia before moving to Munich, where Chyi Haur worked as a Business Navigation Manager at IKEA.

We chat to Chyi Haur about life in Europe and how it differs from Singapore. Chyi Haur shares how kids in Germany learn to be independent and make their own decisions, and there is more work-life balance. We hear how the family has adapted with Chloe learning first Swedish and then German within a few months of moving to each country, and how they stay in touch with their Singaporean roots and the community. Read on for why Chyi Haur can’t imagine moving back to Singapore and what the family miss most from their home country.

Read more Overseas Family Stories here.

When did you move to Germany and what were the reasons you decided to move?

We moved to Munich, Germany, in August 2024 because of my new job with IKEA Germany. We were living in Älmhult in Sweden before this. Älmhult is the birthplace of IKEA and one of the corporate HQ locations in Sweden, where I worked previously.

Your family has lived in a few foreign countries – any favourites?

Yes, we have lived in Sweden for 7 years before moving to Germany. Before Sweden, we were living in Japan for 2 years and prior to that, Indonesia for 13 years. I think each country has its charm. We love each of the countries we lived in – Japan for sushi and onsen, not forgetting the Japanese efficiency, Sweden for IKEA and meatballs, nature and work/life balance and Germany also for nature and historical architecture.

But if we had to select one country, it would be Sweden. We lived there for 7 years. This was also the formation years for Chloe in elementary school education. The nature there is amazing and my daughter also had the opportunity to pick up many life skills and activities (like figure skating, horse riding and piano). Chloe was able to compete in Figure Skating in
several regional domestic competitions during this time. We were also able to take our boat to explore the many small islands in the lake near our house.

As I work for IKEA Chloe had the opportunity to be featured in two IKEA Global video productions–the Global Launch of the BYGGLEK Collection in 2020 ,which was a collaboration between IKEA and LEGO where the video played in all IKEA stores globally–and the other was the promotional video of IKEA Museum in Älmhult. Yes, there is an IKEA Museum! We are extremely proud that a Singaporean child was involved in these two videos.

Favourite aspect about living in Germany?

Munich, where we are living now, is a big city compared to where we came from in Sweden. The convenience of living is here, e.g. malls, restaurants, etc. It’s a safe city with plenty of open spaces, and it’s family-friendly too. A big plus is that Munich is at the centre of Western Europe, so travelling to other parts of Europe is easy. In the short time we have been in Munich, we have made numerous road trips to Switzerland, Austria, Italy, Liechtenstein, Luxembourg and France.

At the same time, Munich is close to the Alps and nature and numerous lakes and can be easily reached within an hour. There is always something fun to do as a family!

And the worst part?

I think the frustrating part of living in Germany is the bureaucracy. Dealing with public authorities means that every “I” needs to be dotted and every “t” needs to be crossed. We have been ‘warned’ before moving, but to experience this first-hand is really frustrating.

I also feel that the language barrier can be challenging. Although English is widely spoken, Munich, being in Bavaria (one of the most conservative states in Germany), people are not as receptive to speaking in English, even if they see you struggling to speak in German. Thus, it is crucial to pick up the German language quickly in order to survive in this environment.

How do you think parenting (and schools) in Germany differs from Singapore? What do you appreciate most about it?

Parenting in Germany, similar to many Western European countries, focuses on learning through play. Academic pressure is much lesser than that in Singapore. Kids in Germany also learn to be independent and make their own decisions within limits, and take responsibility early. Such are life skills which children learn at a young age and are difficult to teach in a typical classroom environment.

There is much more work-life balance. Kids are not burdened with a tremendous amount of homework in Germany. Generous parental leave also allows parents to be able to spend more time with their children.

My wife and I really appreciate such an environment. We see that our daughter, Chloe, grows up happy. This is the most important factor for us.

What do you find is the hardest part of being a parent living in a foreign country?

I think the toughest part is the limited opportunity to be connected to the home country, especially our extended family in Singapore. Physical interactions with our Singapore extended family are generally limited to the summer vacation trips back to Singapore.

Another aspect which we are struggling with is that, as we are also not proficient in the German language, we are not able to support Chloe in some of her schoolwork. This can be frustrating. However, our fears are really unfounded, as we can see Chloe is able to manage new languages (both German and Swedish) on her own.

How do you and your partner juggle work and dividing up family roles?

My wife loves to cook. She is able to prepare many delicious local Singapore dishes like Hainanese Chicken Rice, Laksa, Nasi Lemak, Lodeh, Mee Rebus, Sushi, Tempura and many more! As such, she prepares the meals at home. I do the rest. We also agree that I will monitor Chloe’s schoolwork.

Is there something that you do to keep your child in touch with their Singaporean roots?

Chloe is able to keep in touch with her Singapore roots through the famous Singapore food which my wife cooks and frequent video calls to her grandparents in Singapore.

We also encourage Chloe to use Singapore as a reference or material in her school projects whenever possible.

On raising multilingual children …
It is super important that children are at least bilingual. We are happy that Chloe is able to communicate in English, German and Swedish. We are amazed at how fast she is able to pick up languages.

When we first moved to Sweden, Chloe did not speak any Swedish. From when the school year started in August till after the New Year, we saw Chloe´s Swedish competency improve tremendously.

Now, after moving to Germany, we also have a similar experience. Having no German knowledge when school started in September, after the New Year, Chloe is now able to communicate with her friends comfortably in German.

My wife is Malay and I am Chinese. As we predominantly speak English at home, her exposure to Chinese and Malay is limited. We are trying to expose Chloe to both languages by speaking to her, but it has not been an easy journey.

What is the first thing you do each time you go back to Singapore?

Laksa has always been my comfort food. Whenever we go back to Singapore, I will always have a bowl of Laksa at Changi Airport. Even though it may not be the best Laksa, it is good enough for me at that point in time!

As for my wife, she misses Mee Rebus and thus that will be the first meal she will enjoy when we return.

What do you always bring back from Singapore for yourself and for your child?

Chloe always likes Tapioca Chilli Crackers and Chicken Floss. My wife will bring back seasonings like Prima Taste, Indonesian / Malaysian seasonings. If it is during the festive period in Singapore when we go back, e.g. Chinese New Year or Hari Raya Aidilfitri, then we will also bring back kueh bangkit, pineapple tarts, love letters, etc.

Top five places in or around Munich you would recommend to parents travelling with kids and why.

If you are travelling with kids, here are our top 5 picks to visit in Munich:

1. Deutsches Museum: This is the world´s largest Museum of Science and Technology. It also has a dedicated hands-on area for kids, plus interactive exhibits on space, aviation and physics. It also features real planes, submarines and trains for kids to explore. Definitely fun for all ages.

2. Olympiapark and BMW World: where the 1972 Munich Olympics were held. Today, Olympiapark has boat rides, playgrounds and an abundance of green open spaces for kids to run around. Next to Olympiapark is BMW World is the Global Corporate HQ of BMW, which has many interactive displays of BMW vehicles and also futuristic vehicles.

3. Englischer Garten: One of the largest urban parks in the world. It is even bigger than Central Park in New York. Families can enjoy a picnic with plenty of space for kids to run and play, and there are several beer gardens. It is also possible to rent paddle boats here. One of the quirks in Englischer Garten is definitely Eisbach River, where you can watch people surfing on a river, a unique Munich attraction! People are surfing on this part of the river regardless of the season!

4. Hellabrunn Zoo: This is a highly rated zoo. Many animals are kept in large, natural enclosures and are cageless. There is a petting zoo for kids, interactive exhibits and adventure playgrounds. The zoo is located on the banks of the Isar River, so you can enjoy a scenic walk along the Isar River after the Zoo.

5. Oktoberfest. How not to miss Oktoberfest in Munich? Families with kids can also enjoy the world-famous Oktoberfest if they are visiting in late September. There are family-friendly beer tents offering traditional food like pretzels and apple strudel. There are rides (carousels, Ferris Wheel and mini roller coaster), traditional puppet shows for younger kids, Funfair games and Food Stalls.

What is the local cuisine like and do you eat out a lot or cook at home?

Typical local cuisine consists of Weißwurst (or white sausage) served with Mustard and pretzel; Pork Knuckle served with Potato dumplings and sauerkraut and Kartoffelsalat (Potato
Salad). We generally eat at home as my wife loves to cook (as mentioned above). On important occasions like birthdays, anniversaries or weekends then we eat out.

What’s the one thing you would miss about Germany if you moved away?

We would definitely miss the Christmas markets. German Christmas markets are world-renowned. The Munich Christmas Market is one of the oldest and most famous, dating back to the 14th Century. The atmosphere, especially when it is snowing–the scent and aroma Glühwein (mulled wine), Bratwurst, etc, are something words cannot describe. Some of the Christmas ornaments are so unique that you cannot find them elsewhere.

How do you stay connected with the Singaporean community?

Since we first started living abroad, we have always made an effort to connect with the Singapore Community, either through the Singapore Embassy activities or social media groups. At the same time, we also try to help new Singaporeans moving in by offering advice and recommendations on practicalities to hopefully reduce the stress of moving to a new country.

In Sweden, I was the founding head of my alma mater’s Alumni (Nanyang Technological University, NTU Singapore). I organise gatherings for fellow alumni in Sweden to connect, network and also stay connected with the University in Singapore. For my efforts, NTU Singapore has awarded me the NTU Alumni Service Award 2024.

In Oct 2024, the Swedish King made a state visit to Singapore, I also shared my reflections in the Straits Times Singapore commemorating the visit.

What do you dread and look forward to most if you were to move back to Singapore?

I cannot imagine moving back to Singapore now. The continuous stressful rat-race culture and the hot, humid weather are something which I do not think I will be able to adapt to, especially being away from Singapore for more than 20 years now.

However, the abundance of fantastic local Singapore food is something we do look forward to. Even at 2am, it is still possible to find great food–and all the 24/7 convenience stores like 7-11, Cheers, etc, what a treat!

How do you think Singaporeans can benefit from living overseas?

We feel that it is extremely beneficial for Singaporeans to live overseas if there is an opportunity to do so. The world is so much bigger than our little red dot. Exposure to different global cultures and perspectives may lead to better appreciation and tolerance. We will be so blinded if we are only living in our Singapore bubble, oblivious to the speed of development that the world is going at.

At the same time, this can also lead to appreciating Singapore’s strengths even more (e.g. safety, public infrastructure, public transport system, strong governance, etc), which many Singaporeans take for granted.

Read more Overseas Family Stories here.

The post “I cannot imagine moving back to Singapore now” SG Family Talks About Expat Life in Europe appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Best Swim Schools & Swimming Lessons For Kids, Toddlers & Adults
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Looking for swimming classes near you to help your child develop water confidence? Little and big kids alike will learn how to swim like a fish with these kid-friendly swimming lessons in Singapore! Are you looking for swimming classes near you to help your kiddo fall in love with the water? Swimming isn’t just a […]

The post Best Swim Schools & Swimming Lessons For Kids, Toddlers & Adults appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Looking for swimming classes near you to help your child develop water confidence? Little and big kids alike will learn how to swim like a fish with these kid-friendly swimming lessons in Singapore!

Are you looking for swimming classes near you to help your kiddo fall in love with the water? Swimming isn’t just a fun way to cool off in the heat, it’s also a necessary skill that will help keep kiddos safe when near water (so many condos in Singapore have pools after all)!

So, whether you simply want them to get active, stay safe at pool parties, or be comfortable in the water – that’s how Joseph Schooling’s parents started out! – or turn them into fierce swimming champs, there is a swim school in Singapore that can help. Start by consulting our guide to some of the island’s best swimming schools, which offer swimming lessons for babies, toddlers, and adults.

Read more: All Things Enrichment, Online Tutors and Classes for Kids

Where To Go For Swimming Lessons In Singapore:

Ace Dolphin Swim School: Swimming school with 15 years experience

Is your child afraid of the water? Fret not – the experienced swimming coaches at Ace Dolphin Swim School have been helping little ones overcome their fear of swimming since 2008. They are certified in NROC, Swimsafer and the Tatsuki (TJAP) methodology, which empowers them to plan effective, fun and engaging swimming lessons for kids.

As their motto suggests, your child will blaze through water and glide like a dolphin in no time! Swimming lessons here cater to kiddos from ages 3.5 and up, and pride themselves on over 8,000 graduates over their 15 years of experience as a swimming school! They have classes in heartlands such as Tampines, Sengkang, Pasir Ris and also soon in Punggol, so you’re sure to find a swimming lesson near you.

Quote SassyMaMa to enjoy a free starter kit!

 Ace Dolphin Swim School, multiple locations including Tampines, Sengkang, Pasir Ris Swimming Complexes, www.acedolphin.com

Swim Masters: Unique 3-month swimming programme for kids

Looking for top-notch swimming lessons for kids? Swim Masters offers tailored programmes for kids of all skill levels, so whether your child is a beginner or a seasoned swimmer, there’s a programme that will help them take their swimming techniques to the next level! From skill development to technique enhancement, the experienced swim coaches at Swim Masters will help your child improve their swimming skills and make you proud.

Swim Masters offers a unique accelerated three-month programme designed to boost stamina, refine technique and ignite a passion for the water. With a proven track record of success, their friendly coaches tailor swimming lessons for kids so that they have a blast. Safety is their top priority, so all swimming coaches are Lifeguard Certified. They are also Swim Safer 2.0 Certified and provide make-up lessons in case your child falls ill. Their convenient mobile app lets you can track your child’s progress in swimming. Entrust your child into the hands of Swim Masters, and they’ll be in for a splashing good time!

Sign up for 3 or 6 months of swimming lessons at $100 per month (4 lessons per child) and enjoy your first month free! Use the code SWIMGEAR for the 3-month plan or SWIM1FREE for the 6-month plan. With the 6-month plan, you’ll also get free mandatory equipment (worth $55) and no deposit required.

Swim Masters, Senja Cashew CC & Delta SC locations, Tel: (+65) 9060 1817 / 6709 0018, www.swimmingcourses.sg

Sports Schooling’s Swim Lab: Small swimming class sizes

Sports Schooling’s Swim Lab’s Learn-to-Swim programme helps little ones build water confidence from the get-go. With small class sizes, passionate and certified coaches with ISA – Sports Schooling Certificate of Swim Instruction, and a progressive curriculum that nurtures swimming skills and a child’s physical, emotional, and mental development, this is one swimming school in Singapore to add to your list! This swim school’s Learn-to-Swim programmes are co-created and endorsed by experienced and national athletes, including Olympic gold medalist Joseph Schooling, who also serves as the director of Sports Schooling!

Got a water-loving kiddo who’s ready to take it to the next level? Swim Lab’s competitive arm, X Lab, provides structured training to help young athletes grow. Swim Lab also runs exciting multi-sport holiday camps at the Centre for Movement, where kids can explore new ways to move, build coordination, and stay active during the holidays. All programmes fall under the umbrella of Sports Schooling, a holistic ecosystem that supports a child’s sporting journey from beginner to athlete.

Sports Schooling’s Swim Lab, three locations in Singapore including Yishun, Bukit Timah and Buona Vista, www.theswimlab.com

Able Aquatic School: Swimming lessons for babies

Able Aquatic School offers group swimming lessons at more than two dozen swimming complexes in Singapore, so you’re bound to find a swimming class near you. Their teaching is founded on the internationally recognised Swimsafer and Learn to Swim programme, so you know your kiddos are in safe hands. Baby swimming lessons start from just six months, and they offer private swimming lessons as well!

Able Aquatic School, 34 Tanah Merah Kechil Road, Singapore 465560, www.swim.com.sg

aquaDucks: Swimming lessons with songs & games

Established in 1989 with six locations across the island, aquaDucks is one of Singapore’s most popular swim schools for little ones. Employing a unique blend of European, American and Australian teaching techniques, their swimming lessons for kids focus on water safety using a child-centred approach. With songs and games, it’s all about learning through play!

aquaDucks, multiple locations in Singapore, including Normanton, Pasir Panjang and Queenstown, www.aquaducks.com.sg

Read more: Guide To Baby Classes & Playgroups In Singapore

ElitePro Swim School: Swimming lessons for individuals & small groups

Looking for private swimming lessons or a group swim class? ElitePro Swim School offers swimming lessons in Singapore for babies, toddlers, older children and even adults. Their certified swim coaches teach at more than 100 locations around the island including condos, international schools and private swimming pools.

ElitePro Swim School, multiple locations in Singapore, including Bukit Canberra, Woodlands and Bishan, www.eliteproswimschool.com

Happy Fish Swim School: Swimming school with 300 instructors

This popular swim school in Singapore offers swimming classes for babies and kids at various venues with more than 300 instructors under their watch. Happy Fish also has a heated indoor swimming pool.

Happy Fish Swim School, multiple locations including Stevens, Bukit Timah and Toa Payoh, www.happyfish.sg

Read more: Where To Go For English Tuition In Singapore

Inspire Mum & Baby: Baby swimming lessons

Inspire Mum & Baby is a one-stop holistic centre for women and children. In addition to a wide variety of services for mums & babies, Inspire Mum & Baby offers aqua therapy exercises and swimming lessons for you and your little one. Babies as young as two months old can start building a strong foundation for water confidence and get opportunities for sensory stimulation.

 Inspire Mum & Baby, 188-2 Tanjong Katong Road, Singapore 436990, inspiremumbaby.com

Isplash Swim School: Swimming lessons in the West

Founded in 2015, Isplash Swim School offers swimming lessons in Singapore at multiple locations in the West. The swim coaches who conduct their flagship classes are certified by the National Registry of Coaches and registered with the Ministry of Education to conduct the internationally recognised SwimSafer Programme. They have a special ladies’ swimming lesson, in addition to swimming lessons for kids, adults and toddlers.

Isplash Swim School, multiple locations in Singapore including The Chevrons, Jurong West and Choa Chu Kang, www.swimminglessonscoach.com

Little Fishes: Customised swimming lessons for babies

The swim coaches at this swimming school have years of experience, and they always encourage lots of engagement between parents and children through structured activities, which let little ones develop better motor skills for swimming. They also offer customised swimming lessons in Singapore if your child is an advanced swimmer.

Little Fishes, 22 Sin Ming Lane, #06-76 Midview City, Singapore 573969, www.swimlessons.sg

Little Splashes Swim School: Heated indoor swimming pool

Don’t worry about your littles complaining about cold water because Little Splashes Swim School’s heated indoor mineral water swimming pool – also chlorine-free! – will have your kiddos excited to jump in! Little bubs as young as 3 months old can take swimming classes at this swim school in Singapore.

Little Splashes Swim School, multiple locations including Shaw Plaza, SingPost Centre & Balestier, www.littlesplashes.com.sg

Little Swim School: Swimming lessons with veteran swim coach

Little Swim School’s founder, Garett Lee, is a veteran swim coach with more than 18 years of experience across a variety of age groups and specialisations. This swim school in Singapore has a temperature-controlled, salt-water chlorinated pool that’s the ideal learning environment for infants, toddlers and kids.

Little Swim School, 27 West Coast Highway, Singapore 117867, www.littleswimschool.com

Marsden Swim School: Swimming lessons at temperature-controlled pools

With more than 20 years of experience in Singapore, Marsden Swim School teaches little ones from 4 months of age through to squads and adults. This AUSTSWIM Gold standard school has an international mix of experienced full-time swim coaches. They conduct swimming lessons in heated pools for babies at their main outlet at Bukit Timah, and also at a temperature-controlled indoor pool at GESS – International School, ensuring swim lessons go on whether it’s rain or shine!

Marsden Swim School, three locations in Singapore including Jalan Jurong Kechil, Dairy Farm Lane and Tiong Bahru Road, www.marsdenswimschool.com

Read more: Guide To Baby Classes & Playgroups In Singapore

Pacific Swim Team: Swimming school with competitions

Pacific Swim Team teaches kids as young as three up to adults. Their swimming lessons are very safe with additional lifeguards on patrol. Students can choose to go the competitive route and join competitions such as the Singapore National Age Group Championships.

Pacific Swim Team, multiple locations in Singapore including Tampines Hub, Trilliant Condo and Citylife @ Tampines, www.pacificswimteam.com.sg

Red Dot Penguins Swim School: Swimming lessons for ages 4 months and up

Fam-friendly swim school in Singapore, Red Dot Penguins holds baby swimming lessons with interactive parent-child sessions for little ones aged six months to two years. Each swim session is designed to build your baby’s confidence and skills in the water using songs and games. There are also swim lessons for two-year-olds and swimming lessons for competitive swimmers aged six and up, plus a social swim club, group swimming lessons for adults and private swimming lessons.

Red Dot Penguins Swim School, four locations in Singapore including Orchard, Siglap, Bukit Merah and Toa Payoh, www.reddotpenguins.com

Singapore Swimming Academy: Popular swim school in Singapore

Singapore Swimming Academy is a leading swim school with more than 300 full-time swim coaches and the most ongoing swimming lessons in Singapore. They cater to all public and private pools, bringing classes to every corner of the island. Kids will learn to swim in accordance with the SwimSafer programme, recognised by all Singapore schools. Get in touch with their coordinators, and they’ll match the best suitable time for you or your child’s schedule!

Singapore Swimming Academy, multiple locations in Singapore including Toa Payoh, Yishun and Sengkang, www.singaporeswimming.com

Singapore Swim School: Swimming lessons in the North

If you live in north Singapore and would rather not travel all the way out for swimming lessons, hit up Singapore Swim School, which is headquartered at the Woodlands Swimming Complex. Swim lessons for beginners, intermediate, advanced and competitive levels are available, and lessons can also be conducted at most public swimming complexes and private condo pools.

Singapore Swim School, multiple locations including Woodlands, Bukit Canberra and Punggol, www.singaporeswimschool.com

State Swim: Swimming school with small class sizes

Learning to swim is the best survival skill and State Swim’s aquatic swimming school helps everyone from six months all the way to adults! They ensure small class sizes with hands-on swim coaches who are in the water with swimmers. There’s clear communication and demos of the skills taught, either by the swimming instructor or by short videos on tablets, while gently guiding swimmers physically so they can feel the correct way to swim.

State Swim, two locations in Singapore, Suntec City and Aljunied, www.stateswim.com.sg

SwimRay: Swimming lessons for kids with special needs

SwimRay’s reviews are plenty satisfying, and it’s really no secret why. This swim school in Singapore is entirely inclusive and has swimming lessons for children with special needs too. These private swimming lessons are helmed by the head swim coaches who regularly attend courses such as Psychological First Aid Provider (Children with Water Phobia), Working with Children with ADHD (SSI), Early Intervention for Children with Special Needs (SSI) and Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (SSI).

SwimRay, multiple locations in Singapore, including Sentosa, Woodlands and Hougang, www.privateswimminglesson.sg

SwimShark: Swimming lessons for kids at condos

Coach Matt from the UK founded SwimShark with the desire to help children learn how to swim and stay safe in the water. SwimShark creates a positive and structured learning environment that helps children to have a ton of fun while learning how to swim. The experienced swim coaches will come to your condo and tailor swimming lessons to all ages and abilities. There is a variety of swimming levels based on your child’s goals.

SwimShark, multiple condos in Singapore, including Dakota, D’leedon and Waterbank, swimshark.sg

SWISH! Swimming: Swimming lessons in Dempsey Hill

SWISH! Swimming is nestled in the lush greenery of Dempsey Hill, and they offer baby swimming classes for littlies as young as four months old to get kids acclimatised to the water. Kids will get to splash around in four heated, salt-chlorinated swimming pools, so you know they’ll be safe and comfortable while they learn to swim.

SWISH! Swimming School, 72 Loewen Road, #01-08, Dempsey Hill, Singapore 248848, www.swishswimming.com

Swimwerks: Swimming classes with max 4 kids

If you’re looking for a swimming class with a small class size, Swimwerks has a maximum of four students, so that the coach can focus on each child’s learning progression. The swim coaches are also certified by the National Registry of Coaches (NROC) in Singapore to ensure professionalism and high standards in local sport. Swimwerks offers swimming lessons for toddlers as young as four years old, older kids and adults as well!

Swimwerks, ActiveSG pools islandwide including Sengkang, Woodlands, Yishun and private condos, swimwerks.com.sg

The Starting Block: Private swimming lessons for kids

The passionate team at The Starting Block promises super fun swim lessons which take place at condos. Their swim coaches make it their goal to unlock the aquatic potential in every little swimmer. Small class sizes guarantee your kiddo gets the VIP treatment so they’ll see real progress and will develop a love for this skill.

The Starting Block, multiple locations in Singapore, including Braddell, Khatib and Bukit Panjang, www.thestartingblock.sg

Elite Coach Sports Academy: Swimming lessons for kids aged 2 & up

This swim school in Singapore teaches little ones from the age of two how to swim safely, confidently and independently using the SwimtoFly technique, a proven method that utilises the concept of flying in the water. Their swimming lessons are said to be effective even for aquaphobes and will have little ones swimming on their own after just 10 hours of swim instruction!

Elite Coach Sports Academy, multiple locations including Sentosa, Orchard and Bukit Timah, www.elitecoach.com.sg

SG Condo Coaches: Swimming lessons at condos

Looking for individual swim coaches and swimming lessons near you? Browse through SG Condo Coaches to find a certified swim coach for all age groups. The hassle-free enquiry process can be done entirely online, and you’ll be matched with a coach that suits your family’s swimming needs ASAP.

SG Condo Coaches, multiple locations in Singapore, including Bishan, Sengkang and Choa Chu Kang, www.condocoaches.sg

Want more fun activities and things to do with kids? We’ve got you covered!

The post Best Swim Schools & Swimming Lessons For Kids, Toddlers & Adults appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Women’s Clinics, Gynaecologists & OBGYNs In Singapore & How To Choose One That’s Right For You
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Looking for a gynaecologist for a routine check-up or your pregnancy and delivery? Check out these gynaes in Singapore for all your women’s health needs! Whether you need a routine check-up or are looking for an OBGYN once you find out you are pregnant, it’s so important to find a gynae in Singapore that you […]

The post Women’s Clinics, Gynaecologists & OBGYNs In Singapore & How To Choose One That’s Right For You appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Looking for a gynaecologist for a routine check-up or your pregnancy and delivery? Check out these gynaes in Singapore for all your women’s health needs!

Whether you need a routine check-up or are looking for an OBGYN once you find out you are pregnant, it’s so important to find a gynae in Singapore that you really trust and are comfortable with. With our world-class healthcare system, you’re likely to find some of the best Obstetrics & Gynaecology (OBGYN) care in the world. Consult our list of women’s clinics, OBGYNs and gynaecologists in Singapore to find one that’s right for you!

Read more: Everything You Need to Know About Giving Birth in Singapore

Jump to:
– What to Know Before Choosing Your Gynae
– Recommended OBGYNs & Gynaes in Singapore

What to Know Before Choosing a Gynae in Singapore

  • Which hospitals they are admitted to deliver at: Think about which ones are convenient to where you live. While most of the gynaes on our list below can deliver at multiple hospitals, they might not make it to you in time for your birth if you deliver somewhere other than near their main clinic.
  • Costs: Consider which doctors work with your insurance. Many doctors offer full antenatal packages that cover checkups, scans, and even delivery, but it may work out cheaper to pay on an a la carte basis.
  • Your choice of gynae: Do you prefer a female gynae or are you not fussed? Interestingly, most of the gynaecologists in Singapore considered most “pro-natural birth” are men! And yet almost everyone on Team Sassy Mama had a female gynae (some of our testimonials are below).
  • Wait times. Be sure to ask around about wait times. Doctors at public hospitals (like NUH and KKH) tend to have much longer ones (we’re talking hours). In our experience, it’s always best to try to book the first appointment of the day if you can. The nature of OBGYNs, of course, is that they can get called away to deliver a baby at any time, which then throws their appointment schedules into chaos.
  • Support staff: Who is on your doctor’s support staff? Several gynaes on this list work with midwives who provide an extra layer of care and attention to patients and can be invaluable both during labour and in the postnatal stage.
  • Backup partners: If your OBGYN is away when you give birth, make sure you’re just as comfortable with their alternate.


OBGYNs & Gynaes in Singapore

It is ok to shop around and find the doctor who you feel is the best fit for you. Our list of gynaecologists in Singapore is far from complete, but it’s a great place to start if you want an outstanding doctor for your pregnancy and delivery. Don’t forget to check out our list of questions to ask your OBGYN, and also take the time to educate yourself and have a think about what matters to you concerning interventions, birth plans, costs and more.

Dr. Adrian Woodworth

Closest hospital: Thomson Medical Centre
One of the most noteworthy gynaes in Singapore, Dr. Adrian Woodworth has more than two decades of experience in obstetrics and gynaecology. He prioritises holistic care and has a reputation on mama forums for being friendly and remembering every patient’s name. And while he will patiently answer all of your questions, many mums-to-be report him as being to the point and keeping things brief during appointments. In addition to taking appointments at Thomson Medical Centre, he also sees patients at selected Thomson Women’s Clinic outlets.

Dr. Adrian Woodworth, 339 Thomson Road #03-01, Thomson Medical Centre, Singapore 307677, Tel: (+65) +65 6250 2222, www.thomsonmedical.com/doctor/dr-adrian-woodworth

Dr. Anne Hagarty

Closest hospital: Mount Elizabeth Orchard
One of the few Western female gynaecologists in Singapore, Dr. Hagarty trained in Canada and the UK and has more than four decades of experience in obstetrics & gynaecology. She specialises in infertility treatment and gynaecological surgery and is also a trusted pregnancy doctor. Her clinic is conveniently located at Paragon right on Orchard.

Dr. Anne Hagarty, Women’s Health Professionals Pte Ltd, 290 Orchard Road, #09-01/02 Paragon Medical Centre, Singapore 238859, Tel: (+65) 6736 0951, www.mountelizabeth.com.sg

Professor Arijit Biswas

Closest hospital: NUH
Professor Arijit Biswas has a reputation as a leading specialist for high-risk pregnancies, especially relating to twins. He is head of the Maternal-Fetal Medicine division at NUH and is also the Clinical Director of the department. If you scroll through mama forums, you’ll find plenty of reviews that say he prioritises your peace of mind during pregnancy and isn’t pushy.

Professor Arijit Biswas, NUH Medical Centre, Level 3 (Kent Ridge Wing), 5 Lower Kent Ridge Road, Singapore 119074, appointment@nuhs.edu.sg, Tel: (+65) 6772 2002, www.nuh.com.sg/nuhgynae

Dr. TC Chang

Clinic: Singapore Women’s & Children’s Medical Group
Closest hospital: Thomson Medical Centre & Mount Elizabeth Novena. He is also admitted to deliver at six private hospitals in Singapore
Patients rave about Dr. Chang’s warm demeanour and commitment to supporting a woman’s birth choices. He is a noted specialist in high-risk pregnancies and ultrasound assessment, along with gynaecological laparoscopic surgery. Two other big selling points for Dr. Chang – he has clinics near two different hospitals (TMC and Mt. E Novena) and counts superstar midwife Kiki Porter-Wolff on his staff.

Dr. TC Chang, Thomson Medical Centre, Ground Floor 339 Thomson Road, Singapore 307677, Tel: (+65) 6253 6174 / 6253 4122 or 9446 0595 (Whatsapp during office hours), www.doctor-chang.net

Dr. Chee Jing Jye

Closest hospital: Mount Elizabeth (Orchard)
“Dr. Chee Jing Jye delivered my son nine years ago and I couldn’t have been happier. She is a highly experienced OBGYN, with more than 15 years of practice. Before joining private practice in 2010, Dr. Chee was the Consultant and Head of the Peripartum Unit, Department of Maternal Fetal Medicine, KK Women’s and Children’s Hospital. During her time as Head of the Peripartum Unit, Dr. Chee has overseen the medical management of the KK Hospital Delivery Suite, with over 12,000 deliveries annually. I am a worrier by nature but when it comes to pregnancy, it just took another level. So when we arrived in Singapore and found out we were pregnant, I wanted to find an OBGYN that I could trust. With her background, I knew I would be in good hands. In addition, her calm and sweet personality was the perfect match for me. She accompanied me throughout my pregnancy, reassuring me every step of the way. The delivery went smoothly and I have recommended her to many of my friends since. Oh, and I never had to wait too long for any appointments! –Emilie

Dr. Chee Jing Jye, 3 Mount Elizabeth, Mount Elizabeth Medical Centre, #12-02, Singapore 228510, Tel: (+65) 6732 9882, www.drjjcheegynae.com

Prof. Chong Yap Seng

Closest hospital: NUH
Renowned for introducing water births at NUH, Dr. Chong (often referred to as Professor Chong – he’s also Dean of NUS Yong Loo Lin School of Medicine) has a reputation as one of the most pro-natural birth gynaecologists in Singapore. We have to say we also love his selection of natty bowties.

“Professor Chong is very popular, and NUH is very busy in general, so expect long wait times (I’m talking hours). However, my appointments were never rushed, and Professor Chong was happy to answer all my questions. Professor Chong was very supportive of my birth plan, however, my little one arrived very quickly in the early hours of the morning so he didn’t make it to the hospital in time for the birth.” –Jessica

Dr. Chong Yap Seng, NUH Medical Centre, Level 3 (Kent Ridge Wing), 5 Lower Kent Ridge Road, Singapore 119074, appointment@nuhs.edu.sg, Tel: (+65) 6772 2002, www.nuh.com.sg/nuhgynae

Dr. Choo Wan Ling

Closest hospital: Mount Elizabeth Novena, but she is also able to deliver at Mount Elizabeth Orchard, Gleneagles and Mount Alvernia
In addition to her popular obstetrics practice where she’s a huge advocate for a natural birth, Dr. Choo is well-versed in other gynaecological issues such as infections, endometriosis, fertility challenges and ovarian cysts. She also has a special interest in menopausal care and female sexual dysfunction. If you’re after a female gynaecologist in Singapore who will put you at ease, look no further.

“Dr. Choo and her staff are warm, relaxed and friendly, and she is always happy to answer questions and offer down-to-earth advice. Her office was always buzzing with patients (book early in the day or you may have a long wait ahead of you), but I never felt rushed, and always appreciated her personal touch. When I was pregnant with #2, she let my then-3-year-old daughter sit with her to look at the ultrasound; to this day Maggie still compares all doctors against Dr. Choo! She was completely open to my birth plan and respectful of my desire to pursue a natural, drug-free birth.” –Kate

Dr. Choo Wan Ling, 38 Irrawaddy Road, #10-30 Mount Elizabeth Novena Specialist Centre, Singapore 329563, Tel: (+65) 6262 3060, www.sog.com.sg

Dr. Freda Khoo

Closest hospital: Thomson Medical Centre. She is also credentialed to practice at several other hospitals, including Mount Elizabeth, Gleneagles, Parkway East and Mount Alvernia.
A mother of three herself, Dr. Khoo is a gynae committed to the belief that every woman deserves quality and dedicated women’s healthcare throughout her life, from puberty till menopause and beyond.

“I started out seeing Dr Freda Khoo at KKH and she saw me through my pregnancy till the birth of my second baby, and my husband and I had a wonderful experience with her. Dr Khoo doesn’t just talk to you like a doctor and an expert – she gets to “friend level.” That’s how much she shows she cares: it feels like she’s taken a personal interest in you, your family and your well-being. When Dr. Khoo left to start her own practice at Thomson Medical Centre, as much of a fan of KKH as I was, I went along with her! Dr. Khoo listens to her patients and if anything, her soothing voice alone will calm your nerves in any situation.” –Nadia

Dr. Freda Khoo, Freda Khoo Clinic, 339 Thomson Road, #06-05B Thomson Medical Centre, Millennial Wing Lift Lobby C, Singapore 307677, Tel: (+65) 6259 6964, www.fredakhooclinic.com

Dr. Goh Shen Li

Closest hospital: Mount Alvernia.
A mum of three herself, Dr. Goh is an award-winning doctor who is reported by patients to be extremely gentle and answers all your questions thoroughly. Dr. Goh was previously attached to KKH but now runs her practice out of Mount Alvernia.

Dr. Goh Shen Li, 820 Thomson Road, Mount Alvernia Hospital, Medical Centre D, #05-59, Singapore 574623, Tel: (+65) 6258 8174, www.slgohclinic.com

Dr. Jasmine Mohd

Clinic: WC Cheng & Associates
Closest hospital: Thomson Medical Centre. She also has admitting rights at Mount Alvernia, Gleneagles and Mount Elizabeth Hospitals
In addition to Obstetrics and antenatal medicine, Dr Jasmine’s sub-speciality is in advanced laparoscopy (keyhole surgery), hysteroscopy and robotic surgery, and she previously served as Consultant Colposcopist in the Gynaecological Cancer Centre at KKH. She is a female gynae who’s fully supportive of natural birth and breastfeeding and has even been certified in hypnotherapy techniques. She is currently serving as Vice President of Singapore’s College of Obstetricians & Gynaecologists.

“I started seeing Dr. Jasmine at Thomson Medical Centre from my second trimester onwards. As a first time mum, I liked that she explained what’s next and what to expect to me, as it reduced my anxiety of not knowing what’s to come for labour. She gave useful advice and tips on birth preparation and also respected my wish for a natural birth. Check-up sessions were always a breeze – I didn’t have to wait for long hours. She was very responsive during my panic call in the wee hours before labour. Post labour, her stitches were clean and I healed well.” –Atikah

Dr. Jasmine Mohd, 339 Thomson Road, Thomson Medical Centre, #01-01, Singapore 307677, Tel: (+65) 6253 4122, www.wcca.com.sg

Dr. Kelly Loi

Closest hospital: Mount Elizabeth (Orchard)
A mother of three with a special focus on fertility treatment, IVF and surgery in addition to antenatal and obstetrics care, Dr. Loi was educated in the UK and did further training at some of the top hospitals in the United States. She is incredibly patient and kind and has a beautiful office with state-of-the-art facilities conveniently located on Orchard (she’s also the Medical Director of the Mount Elizabeth Hospital Fertility Centre). As with many of the most popular OBGYNs in Singapore, it’s best to book early appointments to avoid long wait times.

Dr. Kelly Loi, Health & Fertility Centre for Women, 3 Mount Elizabeth, Mount Elizabeth Medical Centre, #15-16, Singapore 228510, Tel: (+65) 6235 5066, www.healthfertility.com.sg

Dr. Lai Fon-Min

Clinic: A Company for Women
Closest hospital: Camden Medical Centre, Mount Elizabeth, Parkway East & KKH.
Due to his non-interventionist, true-to-mama’s-wishes delivery style, Dr. Lai is very popular (and pricey, too). Rumour has it that he’s got the lowest C-section rate in town and that he doesn’t do episiotomies (hallelujah we say!). He’s also the only gynae in Singapore who might even consider home births, which is far from a given these days and has a good relationship with many doulas. Dr Lai specialises in high-risk pregnancies, is frequently sought out to help mamas safely deliver breech babies, and welcomes patients who wish to go for VBAC. He also works alongside Ginny Phang-Davey, a certified birth and postpartum doula who also runs Four Trimesters Birth Sanctuary.

Dr. Lai Fon Min, A Company for Women, Camden Medical Centre 1, Orchard Boulevard, #03-05/06, Singapore 248649, Tel: (+65) 6333 6181, www.acompanyforwomen.com.sg

Prof. Mahesh Choolani

Closest hospital: NUH & Mount Elizabeth Novena
Dr. Choolani is Head of the Obstetrics & Gynaecology Department at NUH Women’s Centre. Considered one of the top high-risk pregnancy doctors in Singapore and also noted for his calm demeanour and support for a natural birth, Dr. Choolani operates a super popular clinic at NUH (he used to have an office at Mount E Novena but no longer does). Expect lengthy wait times for this popular gynae, but his patients rave about him.

Dr Mahesh Choolani, NUH Medical Centre, Level 3 (Kent Ridge Wing), 5 Lower Kent Ridge Road, Singapore 119074, appointment@nuhs.edu.sg, Tel: (+65) 6772 2002, www.nuh.com.sg/nuhgynae

Dr. Paul Tseng

Closest hospital: Thomson Medical Centre
Sought out by natural birthing mamas, Dr. Paul Tseng draws raves for his kind and gentle bedside manner and can be counted on to follow your birth plan as far as he possibly can. We hear he’s particularly great for Singapore ladies seeking VBACs and gives mamas the option to skip scans during appointments if they don’t feel one is strictly necessary. Click here to read two birth stories from mamas who gave birth with Dr Tseng (Tricia and Pooja).

Dr. Paul Tseng, TLC Gynaecology Practice, 339 Thomson Road, #03-02 Thomson Medical Centre, Singapore 307677, Tel: (+65) 6254 2878, www.thomsonmedical.com/doctor/dr-paul-tseng

Dr. Tan Thiam Chye

Clinic: O&G The Women’s Medical Specialist
Closest hospital: Mount Elizabeth Novena & Thomson Medical Centre
With more than 15 years of experience, Dr. Tan Thiam Chye has delivered more than 5,000 babies in Singapore. Before joining O&G, he was Head of Department and Senior Consultant in Obstetrics and Gynaecology and the Urgent O&G Centre at KKH. He is also an Associate Professor of OBGYN at Duke-NUS Medical School, where he’s won numerous awards as both educator and clinician. The O&G Clinic offers telemedicine services, too, so you can skip long wait times and talk to your doctor through real-time video, which is especially useful for post-natal visits.

Dr. Tan Thiam Chye, O&G The Women’s Medical Specialist, 38 Irrawaddy Road, #04-24 Mount Elizabeth Novena Specialist Centre, Singapore 329563, Tel: (+65) 6974 4188 / (+65) 8202 3803, www.ogwomensspecialist.com.sg

Dr. Tony Tan

Closest hospital: Mount Alvernia. He is admitted to deliver at all private hospitals in Singapore.
Along with Drs. Biswas, Chang and Choolani, Dr Tan is another name that frequently comes up when discussing top OBGYNs in Singapore for high-risk pregnancies – these include including twins/multiples, second opinions, genetic disorders and abnormal ultrasound scans. Of course, he also treats low-risk pregnant women, as well as other gynaecological conditions such as fibroids, endometriosis, ovarian cysts, and more. Dr. Tan personally screens foetuses in every trimester and has a full team of medical specialists in his clinic, including a midwife and consultant anaesthetist.

Dr. Tony Tan, 820 Thomson Road, Mount Alvernia Hospital, #07-66 Medical Centre D, Singapore 574623, Tel: (+65) 6972 4497/98 or (+65) 8622 3850 (Whatsapp for appointments only), www.drtonytan.com

Dr. Vanaja Kalaichelvan

Closest Hospital: NUH
Dr. Vanaja has special training in maternal-fetal medicine, including a clinical fellowship in ultrasonography at St George’s Hospital, London. In addition to her position at NUH’s Antenatal Diagnostic Centre and teaching responsibilities, she also jointly runs its O&G Diabetic Clinic.

“Dr. Vanaja made every appointment very comfortable. As a first-time mama, I was clueless a lot of the time, but she helped explain anything I had questions on. She didn’t impose anything on me that I wasn’t open to, and she was very respectful of my plan for a natural delivery without pain relief. Since she was at her other clinic in Jurong, she was absent during a portion of my active labour period but came just in time to deliver the baby. I’m very happy with her service overall! However, due to her popularity, I usually had to wait before seeing her for my appointments – at times it took up to half a day of waiting.” –Syazana

Dr. Vanaja Kalaichelvan, NUH Medical Centre, Level 3 (Kent Ridge Wing), 5 Lower Kent Ridge Road, Singapore 119074, appointment@nuhs.edu.sg, Tel: (+65) 6772 2002, www.nuh.com.sg/nuhgynae

We’ve got plenty more pregnancy and baby must-knows you’ll love!

The post Women’s Clinics, Gynaecologists & OBGYNs In Singapore & How To Choose One That’s Right For You appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Guide To Student Care Centres In Singapore: Locations & Student Care Fees
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Looking for a student care centre in Singapore to make sure your child is well taken care of after school with academic help, enrichment and activities? Here’s our guide, including info on subsidies, locations and student care fees While preschool and kindergarten-aged children have childcare centres, primary school and lower secondary school-going children have student […]

The post Guide To Student Care Centres In Singapore: Locations & Student Care Fees appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Looking for a student care centre in Singapore to make sure your child is well taken care of after school with academic help, enrichment and activities? Here’s our guide, including info on subsidies, locations and student care fees

While preschool and kindergarten-aged children have childcare centres, primary school and lower secondary school-going children have student care centres. Student care centres provide safe, conducive environments for children who don’t have care arrangements at home during after-school hours or school holidays. At student care, children get to fill their afternoons with holistic activities and after-school programmes and more importantly, complete their homework so they won’t have to do it in the evenings at home!

In addition, student care centres provide meals. On top of homework supervision and meals, different student care options provide after-school programmes like music, sports, outdoor play and field trips!

Types of student care centres

All MOE primary schools have a school-based student care centre. These school-based student care centres make it easy for kids to go from their classrooms to student care without leaving the school! Only children from primary school can enrol in the school’s student care.

If your child is already enrolled in a primary school, you can check with the school about the student care application procedure and criteria during orientation or at any time after your child’s confirmed enrolment. A few main operators of school-based student care include NASCANS, Pro-Teach, Big Heart, YMCA, Morning Star and Commit Learning.

Community-based student care centres

If the school-based student care is fully subscribed, you can consider a community-based student care centre near your home or your child’s school. This could mean your child will have to head to the student care centre themselves, but it also gives them the chance to meet and make friends with children from other nearby schools, widening their social circle.

How much are student care fees in Singapore?

Student care fees start from $200 per month. You’re likely to pay less if you qualify for certain subsidies at MSF-registered student care centres under the Student Care Fee Assistance (SCFA) scheme. Check your eligibility here.

Looking for student care centres near you? Read on!

in:genius by NASCANS: Has an AI-powered holistic learning model

in:genius by NASCANS (Global EduHub) is a leading student care centre with over 15 years of experience in running student care centres across nine locations in Singapore. Voted Singapore’s ‘Best Student Care Programme’ for five consecutive years, they offer a unique suite of programmes that help students develop holistically and acquire a strong academic foundation.

They offer academic tuition programmes, fun enrichment programmes like Coding and Chess, and their signature T.I.T.A.N.S. programme that nurtures intelligent thinking habits. In addition, they have a revolutionary learning platform called INFINITY that’s powered by cutting edge AI. This platform tailors the learning journey of every child to reach their fullest potential.

When you drop off your child, you can rest assured that they will be in good hands. The educators at this student care centre in Singapore undergo over 200 hours of training through their rigorous programme, ensuring that each person is equipped to nurture confident and well-rounded young learners.

Monthly student care fees: From $550

in:genius by NASCANS, multiple student care centres in Singapore including Tampines, Bukit Merah, Jurong East, www.ingenius.nascans.com

Agora Colearning Student Care: Parent app with real-time updates

Agora Colearning Student Care offers children a unique after-school experience where children are able to learn, grow and play. This student care centre in Singapore has created an innovative programme, emphasising critical aspects of a child’s development, such as autonomy, learning to learn, personal growth, as well as their well-being. Students can also research, join creative programmes and participate in outdoor activities for a well-rounded development.

Centrally located at HarbourFront Centre, Agora Colearning Student Care spans 20,000 sqft of indoor and outdoor learning spaces with a terrace overlooking Sentosa, so your child can benefit from a variety of learning spaces throughout the day. They can dive into stories at the library, get creative at maker spaces and stay active outdoors.

They recently launched their own Parent App, so you can stay up to date with your child’s academic progress and gain insights about their social development. This student care centre also offers door-to-door transport from a wide number of primary schools, so your child is safe and well cared for.

Monthly student care fees: $689

Agora Colearning Student Care is now open for 2024 registrations! Quote SMM50 during registration to enjoy the early bird pricing.

Agora Colearning Student Care, HarbourFront Centre, #04-01 access via Lobby C, www.agora-colearning.space

Brave Feats Student Care: Open concept & mixed-age grouping 

Brave Feats Student Care is a changemaker in the after-school care space. Brave Feats sees itself as a critical part of the “Village of Care” in raising joyful children into purpose-led adults. They provide a positive and inspiring space with a child-centric and purpose-built environment.

The open concept, flexible furniture, mixed-age grouping and caring adults allow children to feel at home, be themselves and explore confidently beyond school and the classroom. Brave Feats is not only a space for children, but also builds a community with parents through close communication and parenting support.

The after-school programme, designed by experienced educators, is underpinned by the principles of Positive Education and the Montessori pedagogy. Through the programme facilitated by nurturing and committed teachers, Brave Feats children develop both social-emotional competencies and executive functioning skills, which set them apart as confident and joyful children.

Monthly student care fees: Enquire with centre.

Sassy Mama readers enjoy a waiver of registration fees, complimentary seats for the 3-day P1 Transition Programme (3 – 5 Dec 2024) and 1-day Brave Feats Experience Day (9 – 12 Dec 2024, 16 – 20 Dec 2024), and three free Brave Feats t-shirts. This is a total savings of $1,040! Valid until 31 October 2024. Terms & Conditions apply.

Brave Feats Student Care Bedok, 21 Bedok North Street 1, #02-02 Common Ground, Singapore 469659, www.bravefeats.community

Changemakers By Seed Campus: Unique programmes to complement learning

Changemakers by Seed Campus is not a typical, cookie-cutter student care centre in Singapore. Instead of simply getting students to complete their homework and giving them a safe space until their parents pick them up, Changemakers by Seed Campus nurtures essential life skills through a research-backed curriculum that teaches children innovation and communication.

The team that is made up of ex-MOE teachers here encourage students to be responsible in daily routines and take ownership of their own learning. Though academic support is readily available, Changemakers gives students the opportunity to develop essential life skills. Students also benefit from unique programmes including fireside chats with experts, the opportunity to run a mini retail store and more.

With over 3,400 square feet of space, this student care centre in Singapore gives students plenty of room and interactive spaces to learn, grow and explore. Their low staff-to-child ratio of 1:10 gives parents peace of mind knowing that each child can learn and grow at their own pace and receive the support they need.

Quote SASSYCHANGEMAKERS to receive exclusive enrolment savings of up to $2,300. Terms & conditions apply.

Changemakers by Seed Campus, 80 Marine Parade Road, Parkway Parade, #22-08/09, Singapore 449269, www.seedcampus.sg

Curos: After-school care with enrichment programmes

Curos is a student care centre in Singapore that offers a safe, nurturing and dynamic environment where your child can thrive. They provide a holistic after-school care that perfectly balances academics and enriching activities such as STEM, Arts Appreciation and Effective Communicators.

Partnering with Singapore’s top enrichment providers, Learning Point and Hua Cheng, students will be able to join top-tier face-to-face tuition in English, Chinese, Mathematics and Science. This reinforces what your child learns in school and helps them build a strong academic foundation during the week, so they can relax with family on the weekend.

Beyond academics, Curos offers nutritious meals, thrilling excursions and outdoor adventures. By offering time for guided play and homework, learning at Curos is fun and effective. Students look forward to a well-rounded experience that fosters creativity, social skills and character development.

Monthly student care fees: Enquire with centre.

Quote CUROSSM24 to enjoy a registration fee waiver when you sign up. Offer is non-transferable, not exchangeable and not refundable for cash. Only for first-time enrolment and not stackable with other ongoing discounts or promotions.

Curos, 301 Upper Thomson Road, #02-22, Singapore 574408 and 1 Jln Anak Bukit, #02-01D, Singapore 588996, www.curos.com.sg

Elevate After School Care By EtonHouse: Holistic after-school care with enrichment

Elevate After School Care by EtonHouse redefines the after-school experience for primary school children by offering a nurturing home away from home where children can truly thrive. Their kind and nurturing teachers ensure that children feel cherished and supported as they learn and explore through their enriching after-school programme. With a holistic approach anchored on the core pillars of Mind, Body, and Soul, Elevate promotes academic success alongside physical well-being and emotional and social development.

Their programme features tailored academic enrichment, comprehensive homework support, and specialised programmes like Maths Olympiad and Coding, all designed to enhance cognitive abilities and critical thinking skills. To support a healthy lifestyle, they offer balanced, nutritious meals crafted by in-house chefs, engaging fitness activities and thoughtfully designed rest spaces. Holistic modules on stress management, mindfulness, and financial literacy equip children with essential life skills.

Elevate After School Care offers a unique environment that fosters both academic and social growth, providing a safe and enriching space for children to thrive. Explore how Elevate After School Care transforms your child’s after-school hours into a time of meaningful learning and growth.

Monthly student care fees: $1,200

Elevate After School Care, Sengkang Grand Mall, 70 Compassvale Bow, #02-02, Singapore 544692, www.info.theetonacademy.com.sg

Mind Sparks: Tuition programmes in English, Science & Maths by Mind Stretcher

Mind Sparks is the student care brand under the Mind Stretcher Group, one of Singapore’s leading private education providers. This student care centre caters to students aged 7 to 12 years old, and they affectionately call their students “Sparkies”. Their goal is to ignite young minds through a blend of a rigorous academic curriculum and enriching experiences.

Sparkies builds strong academic foundations with Mind Stretcher’s top-quality academic tuition programmes and daily Skills Boosters worksheets for core academic subjects such as English, Maths, and Science. To ensure a holistic development, Sparkies also participate in other enrichment programmes such as Coding and Robotics, Public Speaking, Chess, STEAM, Creative Arts, and Personal Development to foster design thinking and problem-solving skills.

With bright, spacious classrooms and beautiful shared learning spaces like reading nooks, stages and dining rooms, Sparkies always have a blast learning and connecting with their friends. This student centre’s warm and nurturing atmosphere sure makes learning fun!

Monthly student care fees: WhatsApp them at (+65) 8508 9010 to enquire.

Enjoy a complimentary one-week student care trial! T&Cs apply.

Mind Sparks Student Care By Mind Stretcher, four locations in Singapore including Bukit Batok, Toa Payoh, Woodlands and Tampines (upcoming), www.mindsparks.com.sg

Big Heart Student Care: Affordable after school care

Big Heart Student Care is a non-profit, Voluntary Welfare Organisation providing affordable, quality after-school care. Big Heart Student Care works closely with schools, parents and the community to monitor and guide students, while providing fun programmes and activities.

Monthly student care fees: $290 before subsidies

Big Heart Student Care, over 30 student care centres in primary schools islandwide, www.bigheartstudentcare.com

Commit Learning Schoolhouse: Bilingual student care

Commit Learning Schoolhouse is part of Commit Learning Group, which provides bilingual student care, tuition and preschool education for children 4 to 6 years old. Commit Learning Schoolhouse student care integrates the values promoted by MOE into their curriculum. This student care centre has locations all over the island, with branches located in or near primary schools.

Monthly student care fees: From $240 before subsidies

Commit Learning Schoolhouse, 23 student care centres in Singapore, www.facebook.com/CommitLearningAcademy

EduFirst Learning Centre: Has field trips & experiments

EduFirst Learning Centre is a tuition centre and student care centre with a holistic program, with an Integrated Student Development Program (ISDP). Services provided include homework guidance, tuition classes, enrichment activities, field trips and hands-on experiments! Some of their student care centres even have shower facilities and a napping area.

Monthly student care fees: From $380 before subsidies

EduFirst Learning Centre, 15 student care centres in Singapore, www.edufirst.com.sg

Graceland Student Care Centre: Has enrichment classes

Graceland Student Care Centre provides homework supervision, tuition, enrichment courses, hobby-based projects and educational field trips. All their programmes are conducted by well-trained teachers, using methods such as brainstorming and intuitive thinking to engage students in active learning.

Monthly student care fee: From $390 before subsidies

Graceland Student Care Centre, three locations including Bedok, Teck Whye, Jurong West, www.graceland.sg

Little Professors Learning Centre: Healthy meals

Little Professors is a student care centre that has been providing after-school care since 2005. Offering a holistic student care experience, their team of dedicated and diligent staff conduct programmes to keep kids occupied with guidance for homework completion, warm, healthy meals and more.

Monthly student care fees: From $232.32 before subsidies

Little Professors Learning Centre, multiple locations including Jurong East, Ang Mo Kio & Pasir Ris, www.facebook.com/littleprofessorslearningcentre

MindSpace: Student care with weekend enrichment classes

MindSpace provides student care services and weekend enrichment classes for children, incorporating the MindChamps enrichment curriculum that complements the MOE syllabus. MindSpace student care centre reinforces subject-specific knowledge. Their student care centres feature facilities such as quiet reading corners, smart boards, heated shower facilities and more.

Monthly MindSpace student care fees: Enquire with centre.

MindSpace, multiple locations in Singapore including City Square Mall, Raffles Town Club, The Woodleigh Mall, www.mindspace.mindchamps.org

Morning Star Community Services: Theme-based activities

Morning Star Community Services offers a values-centric programme at their student care centres, with interesting curriculum-based learning stations and theme-based activities. This student care centre allows students to hone their cognitive abilities and social skills while nurturing character formation and emotional development.

Monthly student care fees: From $352.05 before subsidies

Morning Star Community Services, multiple locations in Singapore including Hougang, Sengkang, Bedok, www.morningstar.org.sg

PlayFACTO: Coding & robotics curriculum

PlayFACTO School offers premium student care and enrichment. It has a cosy environment, healthy and nutritious meals, low student-to-teacher ratios, academic-focused daily homework assistance and a Coding & Robotics curriculum. PlayFACTO’s student care centres are available islandwide. Read more about PlayFACTO here!

Monthly PlayFACTO student care fees: Enquire with centre.

PlayFACTO School, 50 locations in Singapore, Tel: (+65) 9773 4336, www.playfactoschool.com.sg

Raffles Student Care Centre: After-school care with speech & drama

Raffles Student Care is a child-safe organisation caring for children of all backgrounds and subsidising/ sponsoring learning journeys for at-risk children. Kids are exposed to a variety of indoor and outdoor activities all week and often learn about various cultural practices and celebrations in Singapore.

Monthly student care fees: From $227.25 before subsidies

Raffles Student Care Centre, 20 student care centres within/near primary schools in Singapore, www.rafflesstudentcare.com

Singapore Edusmart Learning Hub: Enriching outdoor activities

Edusmart’s student care programme includes supervised study time to complement the school’s teaching and a holistic approach to play and learning. They are strong advocates for the phrase “It takes a village to raise a child”, and often partner with parents, schools, community and like-minded organisations towards this cause.

Monthly student care fees: From $235 before subsidies

Singapore Edusmart Learning Hub, 11 student care centres in Singapore, www.singaporeedusmart.com.sg

YMCA Student Care Centre: Located near primary schools

YMCA Student Care Centre has been providing after-school care services since 1997. With the belief that every child is unique, the teachers and mentors at YMCA take a keen interest in every student, offering after-school care to kids in over 20 centres islandwide within/near primary schools.

Monthly student care fees: From $260 before subsidies

YMCA Student Care Centre, 23 student care centres in Singapore, www.facebook.com/ymcascc

Read more: 

The post Guide To Student Care Centres In Singapore: Locations & Student Care Fees appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Guide To Geneo @ Singapore Science Park: Food At Geneo & Things To Do
item.dc:creator: Jessica Fang
item.description:
Geneo @ Singapore Science Park is the newest aesthetic spot in town! Head down to check out the stunning architecture, all the things to do in Geneo and food at Geneo for your next family outing. There’s a new aesthetic spot in Singapore turning heads for its grand foyer and urban greenery–and it may very […]

The post Guide To Geneo @ Singapore Science Park: Food At Geneo & Things To Do appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Geneo @ Singapore Science Park is the newest aesthetic spot in town! Head down to check out the stunning architecture, all the things to do in Geneo and food at Geneo for your next family outing.

There’s a new aesthetic spot in Singapore turning heads for its grand foyer and urban greenery–and it may very well be the next reason you go to Kent Ridge. That’s Geneo @ Singapore Science Park, the latest mixed-use development to crop up on our Little Red Dot. Located in a business hub dedicated to life sciences and innovation, Geneo adds a great dose of community-friendly facilities, beautiful spaces, a serviced apartment, co-working spaces, and, of course, food–all packed in this spacious enclave spanning 39,000 square feet.

You’ll bet there’ll be more kid-friendly events taking place at Geneo soon, so check out what this science and business hub has to offer, including food at Geneo and what to do at Geneo with kids. Currently, there are a good number of F&B establishments open, but there will be more retail and food amenities opening in the future.

Jump to:
– Food at Geneo @ Singapore Science Park
– Things to do at Geneo @ Singapore Science Park
– Citadines Science Park Singapore
– How to get to Geneo @ Singapore Science Park

Food at Geneo @ Singapore Science Park

Luckin Coffee: Coffee run at Geneo

Need a quick pick-me-up while innovating (or exploring the photo-worthy spaces of Geneo)? There’s a Luckin Coffee right here, so you can easily get your caffeine fix. Pick up their popular beverages such as the Coconut Latte, or try whatever’s on their daily deals that go as generous as 50%+ off or even 1-for-1!

Luckin Coffee, 1B Science Park Dr, #01-32, Geneo, Singapore 199315, www.luckincoffee.com

PUTIEN Geneo: Michelin-starred Fujian Cuisine

PUTIEN has landed at Geneo, so you can expect a feast of great Fujian cuisine. This Chinese restaurant has previously bagged a 1 Michelin star for 7 years in a row between 2016 and 2023. Go for their signatures such as the Fujian Red Mushroom Seafood Lor Mee, ‘100-Second’ Stewed Yellow Croaker, PUTIEN’s Bian Rou soup and more!

PUTIEN Geneo, 1B Science Park Drive, Geneo, #B1-33, Singapore 119315, www.putien.com

Ha-Jun Korean: Korean food at Geneo

For many of us, Korean food has practically become a daily staple! Well, you can now get your fix of classic Korean fare at Ha-Jun Korean at Geneo, whether it’s comforting Bean Paste Soup, familiar Kimchi Fried Rice, or indulgent Kimchi Chicken Steamboat.

Ha-Jun Korean, 1B Science Park Drive, Geneo, Singapore 119315, www.instagram.com/hajunkorean

Read more: Guide To Korean BBQ Spots In Singapore

Great Nanyang Heritage Cafe Geneo: Kopitiam at Singapore Science Park

Great Nanyang Heritage Cafe has pretty much everything you need to get your Kopitiam fix: half-boiled eggs, toast bread and coffee, as well as Penang dishes, steamed buns, and other satisfying local tastes.

Great Nanyang Heritage Cafe, 1B Science Park Dr, #B1-32, Geneo, Singapore 119315, www.instagram.com/greatnanyang

Grains & Co: Healthy bowls at Geneo

Fancy a nourishing tofu bowl or a bowl for an energy boost? Grains & Co has an array of yummy superfood bowls for those craving a guilt-free meal. Order one of their signature bowls or build your own with your choice of bases, supplements, dressings and protein.

Grains & Co, 1B Science Park Dr, B2-41 Geneo, Singapore 119315, www.grainsandco.sg

Swensen’s Unlimited: Halal buffet at Geneo (Opening soon)

Swensen’s Unlimited has yet to open at Geneo, but it’s great to have another great buffet option in Singapore. Not only do you get access to an unlimited ice cream bar and waffles, but there are also live cooking stations and a spread of hot dishes, seafood and more. Swensen’s Unlimited is also a halal restaurant, so everyone can join in on the feast.

Swensen’s Unlimited, 1 Science Park Dr, #01-06, Singapore 118221, www.unlimited.swensens.com.sg

More food at Geneo @ Singapore Science Park:

Bread Talk: #B2-37/38
Fun Toast: #B2-42/43
Olive & Peach: #01-31
Pasta Express+: #B2-39
Subway: TBA

Things to do at Geneo

The Canopy: Instagrammable event plaza

There are many reasons to be in awe of The Canopy, Geneo’s 3,000-square-metre event plaza. This area at the entrance of Geneo is visually stunning, with mass engineered timber (MET) pillars towering some 27 metres tall, branching off to a louvred glass canopy. It’s also where plenty of events are expected to take place, with a capacity of about 300 pax. On a regular day, though, you can simply hang out at this naturally ventilated space and enjoy the view before you.

The Seed: Outdoor garden at Geneo

Geneo is not lacking in green spaces—case in point: The Seed, a ginger-themed genomic garden. Besides playing host to specially selected ginger plant species, this outdoor garden at Geneo is beautifully landscaped. It features a lily pond and lots of shrubs for a great dose of oxygen.

Fitness Corner at Geneo

Designed by Italian artist Vito Di Bari, the fitness corner (known as MyEquilibria) has perhaps the most interesting fitness system we’ve ever seen. This 7-metre-tall sculpture allows people to do over 500 different types of exercise from nine sports disciplines. You’ll soon be able to find it over at 5 Science Park Drive, just opposite Geneo.

Bicycle facilities at Geneo

Cyclists have plenty of reason to head to Geneo, thanks to its bike-friendly facilities. There are a total of 466 bicycle lots at Geneo, as well as shower and locker facilities, all meant to promote the Singapore Green Plan 2030.

Visit Kent Ridge Park

Kent Ridge Park is just an 8-minute walk from Geneo, making Geneo a great spot to drop by for some food after spending the day outdoors. The park is known to be the site of one of the last WWII battles in Singapore, and now has easy walking paths, ponds, and even a mountain bike trail.

Citadines Science Park Singapore: Serviced apartment & co-working spaces at Geneo

Geneo is now home to the new Citadines Science Park Singapore, a serviced residence. It’s got everything you need for a comfy stay, including a 24-hour fitness centre, an infinity swimming pool with a great view, a launderette and more. There’s also a co-working space here that’s open 24 hours for guests to use.

How to get to Geneo @ Singapore Science Park

By train: The nearest MRT station to Geneo is Kent Ridge MRT with sheltered access to Geneo. Kent Ridge MRT station is just an 8-minute walk from Geneo.

By bus: There are a couple of bus stops outside Geneo: 5 Sc Pk Dr off the AYE and 1a Sci Pk Dr and Ascent on Science Park Drive.

By car: Parking is available at Geneo @ Singapore Science Park. Parking is free on weekends and public holidays and standard charges apply on weekdays between 12am to 5.59pm. Parking is free from 6pm – 11.59pm.

Read more about new shopping mall openings in Singapore: Punggol Coast Mall and The Cathay.

Geneo, 7 Science Park Drive, #1, 5, www.geneo.sciencepark.com.sg

Read more:

The post Guide To Geneo @ Singapore Science Park: Food At Geneo & Things To Do appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Handy List Of Best Nursing Rooms In Singapore To Breastfeed
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
