Younger tots can get hands-on with sensory play at the kinetic sand pit, while older kids can whizz down the slide into a giant ball pit. There’s also a merry-go-round, a rock-climbing wall, role-playing activities and a super cool battery-operated car for a ride around the indoor playground.

Wan To Play indoor playground prices: $18 for a one-hour pass; $35 for a two-hour pass

Wan To Play, Changi Airport Terminal 3, 65 Airport Boulevard, B2 North, #B2-14-18, Singapore 819663, www.wantoplay.sg

7. Jolly Jungle: Affordable indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: Easties, there’s a new affordable playground hidden at the library of Our Tampines Hub! As its name suggests, Jolly Jungle is a rainforest-themed jungle gym concept playground, built for kids to explore. This Tampines indoor playground takes the form of a tree house, complete with slides, hidden corners, tunnels, viewing platforms and nets to climb through.

Inside, you’ll find hidden treats, including suspended zebras and obstacles the kids can roll, jump and climb over. Kids can also let their imagination run wild with the seemingly endless supply of foam building blocks! Be warned: everything in this indoor playground is built kid-sized, meaning Mums and Dads, you’re going to have a workout following them through the jungle gym.

Jolly Jungle indoor playground prices: From $13/hour on weekdays; $15/hour on weekends for 1 child & 1 adult

Jolly Jungle, 1 Tampines Walk #03-02, Enter via Library, Level 2 Our Tampines Hub, www.jollyjungle.sg

8. F3 Theme Park: Farm-themed with longkang fishing

Indoor playground deets: Indoor longkang fishing, corn and soy grinding, digging up (plastic) veggies, wheelbarrows and more–that’s what you can expect at F3 Theme Park at City Gate. This farming-themed indoor playground is definitely unique and has activities for kids of all ages. Besides the farming activities, there’s also a traditional ball pit with a small playground with a slide.

The ball pit offers plenty of good ol’ fun, too, with an inflatable trampoline and other inflatables over the sea of balls. The star of the show at F3 Theme Park is the longkang fishing, but parents, please ensure that your kids walk slowly and are gentle with the little fish! The longkang fishing may not be suitable for younger kids who may just want to splash around in the water.

F3 Theme Park indoor playground prices: From $29.80/hour

F3 Theme Park, 371 Beach Road, #02-16 City Gate, Singapore 199579, www.f3themepark.com

9. VroomTown: Indoor playground with driving circuit

Indoor playground deets: Located in Marina Square, VroomTown is a mega indoor drive-play academy and indoor playground featuring multiple Singapore icons including the Merlion, Gardens by the Bay and Changi Airport! Kids get one hour of play at the pastel-coloured indoor playground which includes a realistic city driving experience with cute traffic lights and a drive-through.

It’s not a go-karting experience per se but kids will need to learn how to operate their vehicles and observe road safety rules. This indoor playground is great for kiddos 5 and up as they’ll be allowed to drive independently while tots below 5 will require parental supervision (in the same car).

VroomTown indoor playground prices: Beginner child entry ($38); licensed child drivers ($49) -includes 1 free adult entry.

VroomTown, Marina Square, #01-208, Singapore Tel: (+65) 8877 4846, www.vroomtown.com.sg

10. The Artground @ GAC: Explore the islands of Singapore & Indonesia

Indoor playground deets: The Artground’s latest play space invites little adventurers to journey across the islands of Singapore and Indonesia, where myths, folklore, and legends come to life. Just opened last week, this new indoor playspace features climbing elements and a sensory path set along the back of a majestic mythical sea dragon!

Kids visiting this unique indoor playground in Singapore can explore and experience firsthand how these imaginative ideas come to life. Do note that all visitors must have a valid ticket before entry, as walk-ins are not allowed. Tickets are released weekly and sold per time slot, so stay updated through the booking link for more details. Don’t forget your non-slip grip socks.

The Artground indoor playground prices: $5/pax on weekdays; $8/child & $5/adult on weekends

The Artground @ GAC, Goodman Arts Centre, Block J, #01-40, 90 Goodman Road, Singapore, www.theartground.com.sg

11. Paragon: Mall indoor playground (FREE!)

Indoor playground deets: In between shopping and cafe-hopping on Orchard Road, stop by Paragon mall to let the kids run around at this free indoor playground on level 5. It’s named ‘The Jungle Adventure Tower’, and little ones will have a blast climbing up the treehouse, whizzing down the slide and having a go at the see-saw. Younger tots can play interactive games on the wall which will spark their curiosity and help them practice their fine motor skills.

Paragon Mall indoor playground prices: FREE!

Paragon, 290 Orchard Road, Singapore 238859, www.paragon.com.sg

12. Smigy at Orchard: Ball pits and trampoline

Indoor playground deets: Calling all fans of Smigy’s indoor playground! Smigy has an outlet in the heart of the city at Forum the Shopping Mall on Orchard Road! Kids will love the all-time favourite play stations like a giant ball pit and trampoline. But that’s not all – Smigy has integrated technology to give kids exciting pretend-play opportunities like working in a supermarket, milking a cow and more.

Smigy indoor playground prices: $23 per hour or $35 for 2 hours. Each indoor playground ticket admits one child and one adult. 

Smigy at Orchard, Forum The Shopping Mall, 583 Orchard Road, B1, Singapore 238884, www.smigy.sg

13. Yooland: Indoor playground at West Gate

Indoor playground deets: One of the largest indoor playgrounds in town, Yooland at Westgate features 7,000 square feet of fun, where kids can dive into a giant ball pit, whizz down slides and bounce away on a trampoline. Younger tots will love the sensory (snow) sand pit, where they can avoid the hyperactive older kids who might be running around!

There’s even a rock climbing wall so kids can get active and get a good workout while strengthening their gross motor skills. Look out for the interactive installations and pretend play opportunities. Dress up like a princess, put on some make-up and cook up a storm in the play kitchen!

Yooland indoor playground prices: $25 per hour and $35 for 2 hours from Monday to Friday. Each ticket admits 1 adult and 1 child (1 – 18 years old). Kids under 1 can enter for free with an accompanying adult ($10 per hour).

Yooland, Westgate, 3 Gateway Drive, #03-36/37, Singapore 608532, www.instagram.com/yooland_sg

14. Pirate Land: Indoor playground at Eastpoint Mall

Indoor playground deets: Pirate Land has just opened a new indoor playground at Eastpoint Mall. Designed for kids aged 6 and below, this indoor playground in Singapore is compact, so you won’t have to worry about losing sight of your kids. Kids can bounce away on trampolines or whizz down a futuristic slide into a ball pit.

There are interactive games on a large digital screen and pretend play rooms. LEGO builders can spend their afternoon at the LEGO table, while tots can crawl and explore at the soft play area. Older kids can try their hand at the VR Zone just outside this indoor playground for $12 per game. Watch our video here.

Pirate Land indoor playground prices: $15.90 per child (0  – 2 yrs old), $28.90 per child (2  – 12 yrs old); Each child ticket comes with one adult entry, $8 for additional adult. Unlimited play during weekdays & three-hour playtime during weekends and public holidays.

Pirate Land, 3 Simei Street 6, Eastpoint Mall, #04-12 /13/14, Singapore 528833, www.piratelandsg.com

15. Wan To Play Sky Castle: Indoor playground in Pasir Ris Mall

Indoor playground deets: Wan To Play has opened a new outlet at the Pasir Ris Mall, and it has something for kids of all ages! This indoor playground is not the largest in scale, but trust us when we say there’s plenty for kids to do. First up, is the huge bubblegum-coloured ball pit from which the little ones can explore a three-storey gym and slide down three slides.

There’s also a trampoline corner. Little ones can also play make-believe at a well-stocked supermarket, complete with cooking stoves. There’s also a make-up corner, dress-up costumes and policeman props. There’s also a sensory sand pit as well as a kinetic sand station.

Wan To Play Sky Castle indoor playground prices: $18 for 1 hour; $35 for two hours (for one adult and one child). Additional adults and kids below 1 year old from $10.

Wan To Play Sky Castle, 7 Pasir Ris Central, #02-58, Singapore 519612, www.facebook.com/Wantoplaysg

16. Whoose Party!: Indoor playground in Tai Seng

Indoor playground deets: This indoor playground in Tai Seng is a child’s wonderland filled with engaging kids’ activities, so mum and dad can finally catch a break! Older kids can get competitive with crazy go-karts and satisfy their need for speed then put on a velcro suit and bounce on a trampoline and stick their bodies on the wall!

The highlight of this indoor playground has to be its 6.25-metre LED-lit mega slide. We love the toddler-friendly space upstairs with smaller slides and toy cars, so you won’t have to worry about your little tot getting trampled on by a bigger kid. Plus, you can even host your kiddo’s next birthday party here to guarantee fun for kids of all ages.

Whoose Party! indoor playground prices: $15 for 1 hour and $25 for 2 hours. $10 for each additional adult.

Whoose Party!, 601 MacPherson Road, Grantral Mall, #02-09, Singapore 368242, www.whooseparty.com

17. The Artground @ One Holland Village: For younger kids

Indoor playground deets: The Artground at One Holland Village has an indoor playspace featuring a unique concept that guarantees fun for little tots (best for crawlers and tots up to 5). The curious garden has a treehouse, toadstools and gnomes that seek to ignite creativity amongst the kiddos. For the fam, there are weekend art-based programmes where parents, grandparents and children can connect through art activities.

The Artground indoor playground prices: $5 per person (including babies in arms). Free admission for Orange & Blue CHAS cardholders.

The Artground, 7 Holland Village Way, #01-20 One Holland Village, Singapore 275748, www.theartground.com.sg

18. SkyPark By Kiztopia: Obstacle courses & more

Indoor playground deets: SkyPark By Kiztopia @ Cineleisure is another indoor playground by Kiztopia for kiddos aged 6 and up. SkyPark By Kiztopia @ Cineleisure offers an action-packed indoor adventure-scape of thrilling challenges including rock climbing and high-element obstacle courses like that at X-SCAP8 also on Orchard Road.

This Kiztopia outlet has a pedal kart, vertical sticky wall, multi-level play structure that gamifies challenges and fosters friendly competition and more! Here’s what to know about Kiztopia SkyPark before you head down.

SkyPark By Kiztopia indoor playground prices: Below 16 years old: $24.80 (1 hour play); $34.80  (2-hours play); Sky Pass (10 sessions). SkyPark By Kiztopia tickets here.

SkyPark By Kiztopia @ Cineleisure, Orchard Cineleisure, 8 Grange Road, #04-04/05, Singapore 239695, www.kiztopia.com

19. 2 Bears Hideout: Indoor playground at T2 transit (FREE!)

Indoor playground deets: Transiting through Changi Airport Terminal 2? Check out 2 Bears Hideout, a tiny indoor playground just beside the row of eateries. It’s a small area where kids can run around, and kids can also get a lovely view of aeroplanes on the tarmac. Mama and Baby Bear have ladders and slides that are perfect for burning off some energy before flights!

2 Bears Hideout indoor playground prices: FREE!

2 Bears Hideout, Changi Airport Terminal 2, Airport Boulevard, 60, Singapore 819643, www.changiairport.com

20. Adventure HQ: Play for older kids

Indoor playground deets: Adventure HQ at HomeTeamNS Khatib is an indoor playground in Singapore that’s actually geared for tweens, teens and adults too! Expect themed rock climbing walls, a ninja course, rope climbing structures and most excitingly the longest slide in Singapore! It’s actually open-air (but sheltered) so it gets hot and humid. Best to wear light sports gear. It’s 2,800 square metres big and four storeys high. Advance booking is required. Watch our video here.

Adventure HQ indoor playground prices: From $40.74. Click here for detailed ticket prices.

Adventure HQ HometeamNS Khatib, 2 Yishun Walk, Singapore 767944, Tel: (+65) 6705 9420, www.hometeamns.sg

Read more: Adventure HQ Review

21. X-SCAP8: High-elements indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: X-SCAP8 is an indoor playground for big kids and adults complete with a three-level high element course over 10m tall and a thrilling X-Warrior Challenge obstacle course! X-SCAP8 (pronounced escapade) also has a Smash Lab where players over a certain age can let loose with a baseball bat and wrench plus there are arcade games and a golfing simulator making this indoor playground in Singapore super for tweens and teens. Read our review of X-SCAP8 here.

X-SCAP8 indoor playground prices: The “X-Warrior” EAT & PLAY ticket (incl. $5 F&B Credit + 5 Arcade Tokens) is $29

X-SCAP8, Orchard Central, 181 Orchard Rd, Singapore 238896, #07-02, www.xscap8.com

22. Kiztopia @ Jewel Changi Airport: Aviation-themed indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: Another indoor playground by Kiztopia, this time within Toys”R”Us in Jewel Changi Airport. This is also Kiztopia’s first-ever aviation-themed playground, so look forward to airplane-themed obstacle courses, a thrilling slide leading into an ocean ball pit, a giant plane structure, and more.

Kiztopia Jewel indoor playground prices: $24.80 for 1 adult and 1 child for 1 hour. $34.80 for 2 hours. $10 for each additional adult.

Kiztopia, Toys”R”Us @ Jewel, 78 Airport Blvd., B1-210 Singapore Changi Airport, 819666, www.kiztopia.com

23. (REOPENED!) AIRZONE: Indoor suspended net playground

Indoor playground deets: After a long closure, Airzone has finally reopened, just in time for the March holidays! AIRZONE is the world’s first indoor suspended net playground – a net of ropes knitted together to turn the mall atrium space between the different floors of City Square Mall into a playground floating in the air! AIRZONE is an elevated playground with different zones – there’s one access (you need to climb up a rope bridge) and one exit (a PVC slide) per floor.

AIRZONE isn’t ideal if you’re scared of heights; for this reason, we think it’s best suited for courageous kiddos aged 4+, maybe even 6 years old and onwards.

AIRZONE indoor playground prices: From $27.90 per single admission.

AIRZONE, 180 Kitchener Road, #02-K4/K10, City Square Mall, Singapore 208539, www.airzone.sg

24. Amazonia: Ice-age themed indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: At Amazonia indoor playground there are climbing structures and slides for little kids and toddlers, plus an ‘Ice World’ theme with a focus on the freezing poles – a nice break from the Singapore heat! Kiddos can bounce on the netted trampolines and try to score hoops, go down a fun wave slide or play in the ‘snow’ ball bit, complete with vacuum ball tubes for added interactive play. There’s a café and soft play playground area for toddlers, conveniently fenced off from the rest of the fun.

Amazonia indoor playground prices: $38.90 (children aged 3 and above); $28.80 (toddlers under the age of 3 on the day of the visit)

Amazonia, 1 Kim Seng Promenade, #03-113, Great World City, Singapore 237994, Tel: (+65)6836 2544, www.amazoniafun.com

Read more: Where To See Dinosaurs In Singapore: Dinosaur Playgrounds, Parks & More

25. AMPED: Trampoline playground for kids

Indoor playground deets: AMPED is more trampoline park than an indoor playground but it’s a great spot to venture to if your kids are already outgrowing traditional indoor playgrounds in Singapore. AMPED is very well-organised as you book your time slot online, preventing it from getting too crazy.

When you arrive, you pop your socks on (you’ll need special grip socks), collect your coloured bracelet and get ready to jump around! On Wednesdays from 10am to 12pm, there’s a special under-5-year-old session for little bouncers.

AMPED Trampoline Park indoor playground prices: $19 per hour

AMPED Trampoline Park, 10 Raeburn Park, Block C, Level 2 02-33, Singapore 088702, Tel: (+65) 9823 8443, www.ampedsingapore.com

Read more: Best Trampoline Parks In Singapore For Kids Of All Ages

26. Better Play: Montessori-inspired play space

Indoor playground deets: Better Play is a Montessori-inspired play area in Singapore that has two distinct spaces – one for littlies and one for confident walkers up to six years of age. Sit down to playtime with your kiddo and dive into a huge range of high-quality toys that encourage focused engagement and learning, or let your older ones do their own thing while you unwind with a cuppa.

Better Play indoor playground prices: $25 for two hours, 1 child & 1 adult (Monday to Thursday); $29 for two hours, 1 child & 1 adult (Friday to Sunday); 10% off for siblings.

Better Play, 451 Joo Chiat Road, #02-11, Katong Point, Singapore 427664, Tel: (+65) 9725 6954 (WhatsApp), www.betterplaysingapore.com

27. Bouncetopia SAFRA Choa Chu Kang: Playground with inflatable

Indoor playground deets: Bouncetopia by Kiztopia is located at SAFRA Choa Chu Kang and consists of 6,400 square feet of Superhero-themed play areas. At this inflatable bouncy castle indoor playground, kids can bounce to their hearts’ content on the myriad of colourful bouncy castles, get competitive at the obstacle courses and satisfy their adrenaline rush at the tallest slide that takes you into a giant ball pit (it’s fun even for adults!)

We’d definitely recommend close parent supervision for younger kids. Also, be sure to wear long pants and long sleeves to protect your skin from slide burns!

Bouncetopia by Kiztopia Choa Chu Kang indoor playground prices: $19.80 per child (1-hour play), $28.80 per child (2-hour play), $12 per adult. Babies under 12 months old can enter with a paying adult.

Bouncetopia by Kiztopia at SAFRA Choa Chu Kang, 28 Choa Chu Kang Drive, #01-04, Singapore 689964, www.kiztopia.com

28. Buds by Shangri-La: Indoor playground at Shangri-la

Indoor playground deets: An indoor playground by the Shangri-La Singapore hotel, this family staycation spot offers tons of fun for kids of all ages (but best for younger ones); think massive ball pit, a bunch of slides, trampolines, a “sand” area (with rice instead of sand – much cleaner!), and a baby and toddler soft play area. Buds also includes activity rooms that offer organised activities (at an extra cost).

Buds by Shangri-La indoor playground prices: The indoor play facilities and classes are open to hotel guests and the public. You’ll have to register upon check-in. $36 per child for 3 hours for hotel/service apartment guests. Public rates: $48 nett per child (Non-Peak Rate, Monday – Friday)/$68 nett per child (Peak Rate, Saturday, Sunday, PH and Singapore School Holidays) for 3-hour play time at buds by Shangri-La and Splash.

Buds by Shangri-La, 22 Orange Grove Road, Shangri-la Singapore, Singapore 258350, Tel: (+65) 6213 4833, www.shangri-la.com

Read more: Best Kid-Friendly Hotels In Singapore For Family Staycations

29. Canopy Park: Giant mirror slide & suspended nets

Indoor playground deets: Kids love airports, so if you’re scratching your head to come up with a new adventure, why not combine a trip to Jewel Changi Airport? Mama gets to shop, you all get to eat some delicious food and then head to Canopy Park for some indoor play!

This is more of an add-on destination while you’re at Jewel rather than an indoor playground to centre your activities around. Suitable for kids aged 18 months to 12 years old, there is a mirror maze, bouncing nets, and giant slides – and it’s a bit of a bargain at $6, with a variety of unlimited play bundle deals currently on offer. Read our full review here.

Canopy Park @ Jewel indoor playground prices: Standard entrance fee of $6 for Singapore Residents

Canopy Park @ Jewel Changi Airport, Level 5, Jewel at Changi Airport, 78 Airport Boulevard, Singapore 819666, www.jewelchangiairport.com

30. Future World @ ArtScience Museum: Play areas within an interactive exhibit

Indoor playground deets: We know, we know! This is officially an art exhibition more than an indoor playground in Singapore, but the FutureWorld exhibit is very interactive and kids can play while they are here so we are allowing it! Created in collaboration with the Japanese art and technology collective teamLab, FutureWorld takes up nearly a quarter of the museum’s total gallery space.

It feels less like an art exhibit, and more like a hands-on interactive play space, for both kids and adults – don’t miss seeing your own drawings come to life on a big screen!

Future World indoor playground prices: Standard entry from $25 adult/$20 child Single Exhibition Ticket

Future World at ArtScience Museum, 6 Bayfront Avenue, Singapore 018974, Tel: (+65) 6688 8888, www.marinabaysands.com

31. Hip Kids Club: Affordable indoor playground at Orchard

Indoor playground deets: While kids up to 120cm tall are allowed to use this indoor playground, it is particularly suitable for little ones. Complete with climbing frames, balance beams, a circus tent, ride-on bikes, a slide, rubber floors and a ball pit, this indoor playground is perfect for toddlers.

Hip Kids Club indoor playground prices: $25 for a one-year membership; $5 for one-time entry

Hip Kids Club, 583 Orchard Road, Forum Shopping Mall, Singapore 238884, www.forumtheshoppingmall.com

32. IKEA Småland: Indoor playground at IKEA Tampines (FREE!)

Indoor playground deets: Enter a magical forest as little ones step foot into this indoor playground Småland at IKEA Tampines and IKEA Småland Alexandra. Jump into the huge semi-circle ball pit or cosy up in the mushroom hut, find a book in the reading area or do some colouring in the arts and crafts corner. There’s also a mini Småland theatre where kids can enjoy a movie. Watch out as weekends are super busy!

IKEA Småland indoor playground prices: FREE! Kids (4-9 years old) can play at Småland for free for an hour per day while mum or dad shops at IKEA.

IKEA Tampines, 60 Tampines North Drive 2, Singapore 528764 and 317 Alexandra Road, Level 1, Singapore 159965, www.ikea.com

33. The Joy of Toys: Indoor playground with toys

Indoor playground deets: A totally unique speciality indoor playground by Clarke Quay, Joy of Toys is fab for babies and toddlers in particular. Instead of your typical giant slides and ball pits, it’s filled with beautiful wooden toys, puzzles and games (which are swapped out on a monthly basis to keep things interesting).

The Structured Play sections, better for slightly older kids, feature manipulatives, construction, developmental toys and puzzles, and even brain teasers. Meanwhile, the Open-Ended Play sections include a kitchen, dollhouse, and miniatures – all perfect for letting littlies’ imaginations run wild.

Joy of Toys indoor playground prices: $19 (toddler play space); $25 (main play space)

Joy of Toys, 6 Eu Tong Sen Street, #03-51, Clarke Quay Central (Yellow Zone), Singapore 059817, www.thejoyoftoys.com.sg

34. Kidodo: Indoor playground at City Square Mall

Indoor playground deets: Kidodo is a small play area at City Square Mall sporting a spiral slide, sand area, ball pit and a mini-trampoline. There are more small slides on a different level, an obstacle course and an activity wall. Remember to wear socks and book ahead!

Kidodo indoor playground prices: One-time entry for one hour of playtime starts from $12 (admits one child and one accompanying adult).

Kidodo Indoor Playground, 180 Kitchener Road, Mall, #02-19A, City Square Mall, Singapore 208539, www.kidodo.sg

35. KidsSTOP @ Science Centre Singapore: Educational indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: A trip to KidsSTOP at the Science Centre in Jurong is probably one of our all-around favourite kids’ things to do in Singapore. Is it an indoor playground or education? Both – that’s the brilliance! It scores big for kids because there are so many different areas to play in – from uncovering dinosaur fossils in the palaeontology sandpit to doing a bit of karaoke and loads more!

KidsSTOP indoor playground prices: $5 – $20 (child) and $5 – $13 (adult)

KidsSTOP, Science Centre Singapore, 15 Science Centre Road, Singapore 609081, Tel: (+65) 6425 2500, www.science.edu.sg

36. Kidz Amaze: Indoor playground at SAFRA

Indoor playground deets: We love the two massive SAFRA spots in Toa Payoh and Jurong – among the largest indoor playgrounds in Singapore. Expect climbing structures aplenty, with ball pits, slides and lots of fun for kiddos (up to 13 years old).

Psssst! There’s also a first-of-its-kind in Singapore indoor water playground at SAFRA Punggol Club with five slides and a themed splash pad, Splash @ Kidz Amaze is just for kids 18 months to 13 years, and spans an amazing 24,000 sqft. There is no reservation required and unlimited playtime applies for all three Kids Amaze indoor playgrounds.

Kids Amaze indoor playground prices: Kids under 12 months enter free at Kids Amaze SAFRA Jurong/babies below 2 months old enter free at Kids Amaze SAFRA Toa Payoh; from $10.10 on weekdays, from $12.15 on weekends; $4.05 for each accompanying adult. Sign up as a Kidz Amaze member to enjoy up to 50% off entrance rates.

Kidz Amaze, multiple locations in Singapore, including SAFRA Jurong, SAFRA Punggol and SAFRA Toa Payoh, www.safra.sg

37. Kiztopia Club Punggol: Safari-themed indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: Hit up Kiztopia at Punggol Town Square for 12 different safari-themed play areas. This Kiztopia outlet lets kids go all out with AR interactive games and jump to their heart’s content at the trampoline. There are slides, obstacle courses, a ball put and more. Kids will also love the roleplay rooms and sandput at this Kiztopia indoor playground.

Kiztopia Punggol indoor playground prices: Single-entrance tickets start from $24.80 (1 hour of play) to $34.80 (2 hours). A ticket includes one child + one adult; additional adults are $12 each.

Kiztopia Punggol, 85 Punggol Central, #01-01/02/03/04, Singapore 828726, www.kiztopia.com

Read more: Kiztopia Marina Square Review

38. Little Bear’s House: Role-play indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: This family-run indoor playground in Serangoon Gardens is geared toward younger kids (primarily 0-5, though kids up to 8 are welcome to join), with lots of high-quality wooden toys, puzzles, and a reading corner full of engaging books.

There’s also a dedicated toddler area for littlies under 18 months with extra padding and age-appropriate toys. You can tell Little Bear’s House is run by a mama, with plenty of comfy sofas that are perfect for nursing mamas.

Little Bear’s House indoor playground prices: $25 per child for two hours on weekdays; $28 on weekends; packages from $238

Little Bear’s House, 21 Lichfield Road, Singapore 556841, Tel: (+65) 6974 6398, www.littlebearshouse.sg.com

39. KidZania Singapore: Kids’ city at Sentosa

Indoor playground deets: KidZania Singapore at Sentosa is like a mini-city made just for kids! Lining kid-sized streets are a police station, fire station, A&E, dentist, hospital, bank, radio station and department store. Kids get to take part in an array of fun activities including being a firefighter, pilot, dentist and more while parents can kick back and relax. Read our full review of KidZania Singapore.

KidZania Singapore indoor playground prices: From $29 (free for babies aged 0 – 1). Full pricing details here.

KidZania Singapore, 31 Beach View Road, #01-01/02 Sentosa Island, Singapore 098008, www.kidzania.com.sg

40. PIP’s PLAYbox: Indoor playground at Esplanade (FREE!)

Indoor playground deets: Located in Esplanade, PIP’s PLAYbox serves as the perfect place for some air-conditioned fun in the heart of the city centre. This children’s art space features a cosy interior with a loft, an arts and crafts area and a reading corner with books by Singapore writers and illustrators. There is also an outdoor play area. The indoor playground also occasionally hosts a range of activities in conjunction with Esplanade, including storytelling sessions and hands-on activities and workshops.

PIP’s PLAYbox indoor playground prices: FREE! Register before your visit.

PIP’s PLAYbox, 1 Esplanade Drive, Singapore 038981, www.esplanade.com

41. PLAY by Kinderplay: Affordable indoor playground at Changi Airport

Indoor playground deets: Perfect for wearing the little ones out before you get on a long flight–or if you live in the East–PLAY by Kinderplay is a Cartoon Network-themed indoor playground. It’s accessible to the public at Basement 2 of Changi Airport Terminal 3. The space isn’t huge, but it gets the job done. And there are plenty of other kid-friendly activities nearby, too!

PLAY by Kinderplay indoor playground prices: $12 (toddlers below 2 years old); $21-$25 (child); 1 adult enters free with each paying child; $6 (additional adult per 30 minute block).

PLAY by Kinderplay, 65 Airport Boulevard, Changi Airport Terminal 3, #B2-14/15/16/17, Singapore 819663, www.facebook.com/play.sgT3

42. Plain as Play by The Makers’ Club: Children-only indoor play

Indoor playground deets: Mamas who want to run errands or sneak in a workout/lunch date can drop off their little ones for playtime. At Plain as Play, children aged 18 months to 6 years are cared for and guided through play sessions by ECDA-qualified preschool educators who will help children embrace a playmaker’s growth mindset.

The studio is inspired by The Maker Movement and the Reggio Emilia approach whereby children are empowered to express themselves through open-ended play. Get hands-on with interactive installations, devise your own creations at the cool tinkering corner, and create your own adventure in small-world play – the options are endless. This play studio also hosts parties, private events and workshops.

Plain as Play indoor playground price: $35 per play session. Maker Experience Sessions are bookable by the hour up to a maximum of four hours.

Plain as Play by The Maker’s Club, 199A East Coast Road, Level 2, Singapore 428902, Tel: (+65) 8044 3254, www.themakersclub.com

43. Pirate Land @ The Centrepoint: Affordable Orchard indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: Ahoy, ye mateys! Pirate Land is the first pirate-themed indoor playground in Singapore! You’ve got your standard pretend play (supermarket, “Kitchen Square”, toys), along with ever-popular trampolines and a bouncing house. You’ll also find a ball pit, giant slide, LEGOs and a pirate-ship climbing structure, as well as a soft play area for babies and toddlers.

But what we’ve heard really sets Pirate Land apart is its laser tag (separately priced), along with a Virtual Reality room for grown-ups! There’s unlimited play on weekdays and three-hour playtime on weekends. Bookings are not necessary but are encouraged.

Pirate Land indoor playground prices: $12.50 for members & $15.90 for non-members (kids under age 2); $23.50 for members & $28.90 for non-members (kids aged 2 to 14)

Pirate Land, 176 Orchard Road, The Centrepoint, #04-08/09/10/11, Singapore 238843, Tel: (+65) 6734 9307, www.piratelandsg.com

44. The Polliwogs: VivoCity indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: This VivoCity indoor playground is a pretty slick operation and hugely popular. We’ve found ourselves at this brightly-coloured, brightly-lit soft play more times than we care to remember. Buy a package if you live nearby, you’ll be back! Highlights include a bouncy castle, tonnes of climbing structures, and huge slides.

The Polliwogs indoor playground prices: From $28.90/child. Click here for detailed ticket bundles

The Polliwogs, 1 Harbourfront Walk, #03-12 VivoCity, Singapore 098585, www.thepolliwogs.com

45. Nekoland: Indoor playground with cat cafe

Indoor playground deets: Felines take centre stage at Nekoland by The Polliwogs! There’s an indoor playground with a ball pit, slides, nets, trampolines and more. If you’ve got a kid aged 3 and above who loves cats, bring them over to the Cat Interaction Zone where the young ones can play with resident kitties and learn how to care for cats. There’s also a cafe onsite where you can wind down in between all the excitement.

Nekoland indoor playground prices: $25 per child + one complimentary adult ticket; $12 per additional adult. Cat interaction zone tickets from $12.

Nekoland, 6 Eu Tong Sen Street #04-63 The Central Singapore 059817, www.nekoland.co

Read more: Cat Cafes In Singapore

46. SMIGY Playground: Indoor playground at United Square

Indoor playground deets: This fairytale-themed indoor playground currently has 3 branches in Singapore with its United Square branch boasting more than eight cool play stations for little ones. Inside, you’ll find a fun trampoline, slides, racing tracks, climbing structures and swings, all set against a pretty pastel background.

SMIGY indoor playground prices: From $23 for one hour.

SMIGY Playground, United Square #B1-01, 1 Thomson Road, Singapore 307591, www.smigy.sg

47. SMIGY Playground: PLQ Mall indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: We love the aesthetic pastel colours at SMIGY Playground at PLQ Mall, suitable for kids aged 2 to 6! Over here, kids can dive into a foam pit and ball pit, and bounce around on trampolines. There are also a fair share of slides they can whizz down, and plenty of swings. Little ones can grab a kiddy car to zoom around the race car track, and those with lots of energy have plenty of structures to climb.

SMIGY indoor playground prices: From $23 for one hour.

SMIGY Playground, PLQ Mall, Level 3, 10 Paya Lebar Road, PLQ Mall #03-05/06, Singapore 409057, www.smigy.sg

48. SMIGY Playground: Tiong Bahru indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: The SMIGY playground Tiong Bahru branch features its must-have ball pit, a double-level play gym, a race track where kids can run around the whole indoor playground, carousel, trampolines and more!

SMIGY indoor playground prices: From $23 for one hour.

SMIGY Playground, 298 Tiong Bahru Road #02-115A, Tiong Bahru Plaza Singapore 168730, www.smigy.sg

49. SMIGY Playground: Indoor playground at Forum The Shopping Mall

Indoor playground deets: SMIGY’s indoor playground in Forum The Shopping Mall has a sandpit, interactive wall games, a space where the kids can pretend play (be a doctor, a chef and more!), a trampoline, and even a unique play area where you can milk a cow!

SMIGY indoor playground prices: From $23 for one hour.

SMIGY Playground, Forum The Shopping Mall, 583 Orchard Rd, B1, Singapore 238884, www.smigy.sg

50. T-Play Bukit Batok: HomeTeamNS indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: With something for kiddos from 6 months of age all the way up to 12 years, T-Play at the amazing 4,200-sqft HomeTeamNS Bukit Batok is the most interactive, transportation-themed indoor playground in Singapore. Designed entirely in Sweden, highlights include ball pits, trampolines, a variety of slides and all manner of interactive play centres.

T-Play Bukit Batok indoor playground prices: From $20 for non-T-play members. Free for babies under 1 year old!

T-Play Bukit Batok, 2 Bukit Batok West Avenue 7, Level 2, Singapore 659003, Tel: (+65) 6705 9494, www.hometeamns.sg

51. T-Play Khatib: Yishun indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: T-Play Khatib at HomeTeamNS Khatib is best for younger kids and is the first Peranakan-themed indoor playground in Singapore. This indoor playground in the Khatib/Yishun area sports spiral slides, kiddie police cars and fire trucks, a foam ball shooting arena and more! We love how Singapore’s rich Peranakan culture is celebrated throughout T-Play Khatib through a mix of audio, visual, and sensory experiences.

T-Play Khatib at HomeTeamNS Khatib prices: From $20 for non-T-play members. Free for babies under 1 year old!

T-Play HomeTeamNS Khatib, Level 1, 2 Yishun Walk, Singapore 767944, Tel: (+65) 6705 9423, www.hometeamns.sg

Read more: T-Play Khatib Review

52. Waka Waka: Safari-themed indoor playground

Indoor playground deets: This safari-themed indoor playground is ideal for kids 2 and up (Safari-themed birthday parties are obviously a huge hit here). There’s climbing fun, slides and a cafe on site for parents. It’s also got some really cool adventure components geared toward slightly older kids (ages 5 to 12), including an obstacle ropes course.

Of course, you’ll also find classic faves in this indoor playground like the giant waves slide, along with a lovely little toddler soft play area.

Waka Waka indoor playground prices: From $27 per entry. Unlimited playtime on weekdays. Pre-bookings are required for playtime.

Waka Waka, 407 Havelock Road, #05-01, Annex@furama, Singapore 169634, Tel: (+65) 6738 7733, www.playwakawaka.com

Read more: Best Kids’ Birthday Party Venues In Singapore

53. Wan To Play Forest: Indoor playground in East

Indoor playground deets: This indoor playground in the East is a forest-themed indoor playground for younger kids with climbing walls and ball pits. Kids can get creative with foam building blocks or enjoy some quiet play in the activity corner.

Wan To Play indoor playground prices: From $35 per entry; $18 for toddlers between 7 – 18 months. Pre-bookings are required for playtime.

Wan To Play, #04-03/04, i12 Katong, 112 East Coast Road, Singapore 428802, www.wantoplay.sg

54. Wan to Play Space: Indoor playground at Kinex

Indoor playground deets: Wan to Play indoor playground at Kinex is a space-themed playground within the mall with bouncy play, sensory sand play and a soft play area.

Wan To Play indoor playground prices: $35 for two hours of play

Wan To Play Space, 1 Tanjong Katong Road, L1 Atrium, Singapore 436990, www.wantoplay.sg

55. Kidztropic: Indoor playground for free play

Indoor playground deets: Kidztropic is all about free play for kids up to 6 years old. The indoor playground comprises slides, trampolines and climbing walls for the little ones to expel all that energy. There are also tools for pretend play and an area with sensory toys.

Kidztropic indoor playground prices: Children 6 and below from $15 per hour

Kidztropic, 51 Upper Serangoon Road, Poiz Centre, #03-12/13, Singapore 347697, kidztropic.com

56. Our Tampines Hub: Basement 1 free indoor playground (FREE!)

Indoor playground deets: There’s a FREE public playground at Basement 1 of Our Tampines Hub! It’s a small space with a small slide, some rockers and space for little ones to run around. This indoor playground is suitable for younger kids aged 2 to 6 and is surrounded by seating areas for parents to watch over the kids.

Our Tampines Hub Basement indoor playground prices: FREE!

Basement 1 Playground at Our Tampines Hub, 1 Tampines Walk, Singapore 528523

57. JEM Play: Indoor playground in Jurong (FREE!)

Indoor playground deets: This honeycomb-themed indoor playground at Level 5 of JEM lets kids climb across a canopy, crawl through fun nests and hammocks and make their own little nest. There’s even some awesome water play, too, so pack a spare change of clothes if you plan to visit.

JEM Play indoor playground prices: FREE!

JEM Play, www.jem.sg

Permanently Closed Indoor Playgrounds in Singapore:

– Aquarius Cove
– Blue House Infant and Toddler Atelier @ UE Square
– Bouncetopia VivoCity
– Bouncy Paradise
– Busy Tables
– The City
– Cool de Sac
– Happy Castle
– eXplorerkid
– Go-Go Bambini
– Kiddles Play
– Kidzland at the Grandstand
– Little Planet Playland
– NERF Action Xperience
– Pasir Ris Inclusive Toy Library
– The Petite Park
– Petite Tayo KidsClub
– PLAYtopia
– Rink @ Punggol East
– Sandy Dandy
– The Rocking Horse Playhouse
– Tots Society

Read more: Family-friendly Guide to JB 2025: Things To Do, Indoor Playgrounds, JB Hotels & Best Cafes

Here’s where to go for more kid-friendly fun and play in SG:

The post UPDATED: 57 Best Indoor Playgrounds In Singapore For Kids Of All Ages appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Students Get Into Their Choice Universities Thanks To This School’s AP Programme (+ $500 Off!)
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Looking to give your teen a head start in university? Learn how the Advanced Placement (AP) Programme can set them up for academic success to thrive in university and beyond. Applying to international universities can be highly competitive, and giving your child a strong academic foundation could be the key to standing out. If you’ve […]

The post Students Get Into Their Choice Universities Thanks To This School’s AP Programme (+ $500 Off!) appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Looking to give your teen a head start in university? Learn how the Advanced Placement (AP) Programme can set them up for academic success to thrive in university and beyond.

Applying to international universities can be highly competitive, and giving your child a strong academic foundation could be the key to standing out. If you’ve been wondering how to help your child stand out, the AP Programme might be just what they need! But what exactly is the AP Programme, and how does it compare to options like the IB?

We break down what the AP Programme is all about, and how International Community School’s (ICS) AP Programme equips students with the critical thinking, time management, and academic confidence they need to shine in competitive international applications.

Is the AP Programme a better fit for my child?

Got a teen excelling in certain subjects and eager to explore them further? The AP Programme offers the perfect opportunity! Students can choose courses that align with their interests and goals, challenging themselves while developing critical thinking skills. Students also get to earn college credits along the way, giving them a head start in their university journey while saving both time and money on their degree.

Although the courses in the AP Programme are more college-level compared to those in the IB Programme, the amount of credit awarded varies by university and course. On the other hand, students in the more holistic IB Programme are awarded credits for high scores in Higher Level (HL) exams, with the threshold often set at a score of 5 or higher. The AP Programme is subject-specific, allowing students to choose individual courses and earn credits based on the number of AP exams taken and their scores.

The AP Programme gives students more flexibility, allowing them to focus on subjects they’re interested in or need for specific university requirements, giving them a smoother transition into university life. Plus, AP courses are designed to match college-level content, pace, and exams, helping students prep for what’s ahead.

How the AP Programme at ICS sets students up for success

At ICS, students can choose from over 20 AP courses across STEM, business, humanities, and the arts. To keep students on track, teachers assign summer work to kickstart the year and use tools like the College Board’s AP Classroom, progress checks, and past exam questions. Regular feedback, small group sessions, and extra support during lunch or after school are also part of the well-rounded approach that ICS takes to ensure students stay ahead. At ICS, AP students have achieved an impressive average score of 4.2 out of 5, earning placements in top universities worldwide, including those in the U.S., U.K., Canada, Europe, and Australia!

Courses here challenge students to analyse, synthesise, and communicate complex ideas and then nurture them into independent learners and effective time managers. Some of the high-achieving courses at ICS, known for strong performance both in exam results and student engagement, include AP Psychology, AP Calculus, and AP English Literature. Students also receive personalised guidance from counsellors to help them choose the right courses that align with their academic goals.

Curious if ICS is the right fit for your child? Join their upcoming virtual open house to find out more!

Join ICS’s Virtual Open Houses to enjoy a $500 waiver on your application fee!

International Community School (ICS), 27a Jubilee Road, Singapore 128575, www.ics.edu.sg

The post Students Get Into Their Choice Universities Thanks To This School’s AP Programme (+ $500 Off!) appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: You Can Now Easily Get High-Quality & Nutritious Ingredients From New Zealand Right Here In SG
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Get ready to ‘Discover A Taste of New Zealand’ because Cold Storage and CS Fresh are bringing the best of Kiwi goodness to Singapore with premium food, live performances and more. As parents, making sure our kids are fed is one thing, but making sure they eat a nutritious, well-balanced meal is another. If you’re […]

The post You Can Now Easily Get High-Quality & Nutritious Ingredients From New Zealand Right Here In SG appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Get ready to ‘Discover A Taste of New Zealand’ because Cold Storage and CS Fresh are bringing the best of Kiwi goodness to Singapore with premium food, live performances and more.

As parents, making sure our kids are fed is one thing, but making sure they eat a nutritious, well-balanced meal is another. If you’re searching for something you can feel good about feeding your family, you’re in luck, because the New Zealand Trade and Enterprise is partnering up with Cold Storage for a campaign where you can experience premium New Zealand products right here in Singapore!

New Zealand Premium Food and Beverage

So, what makes New Zealand produce so special? New Zealand is known for its ethical farming practices that prioritise quality, safety, and sustainability, making sure that every bite is as good as nature intended. These ethical farming practices go hand in hand with New Zealand’s natural advantages such as clean air, lush pastures, fertile soils, and crystal-clear waters – all of which create the perfect conditions for nutritious, delicious food. It’s no wonder New Zealand produce consistently wins international awards!

From free-range poultry, grass-fed beef and lamb to GMO-free fruits, natural manuka honey, premium dairy and indulgent snacks, New Zealand offers food that’s healthier, fresher, and ethically sourced, and are guaranteed to impress the pickiest little eaters in the family!

‘Discover A Taste of New Zealand’ in Singapore

If you’re keen to stock up your pantry with premium New Zealand products, head down to Cold Storage and CS Fresh stores islandwide to experience the best of New Zealand firsthand and learn more about where your food comes from! The three-week campaign (17 April to 7 May 2025) will run across 35 outlets, featuring well-loved New Zealand brands such as Anchor, Cookie Time, Meadow Fresh, Mother Earth, Otis, Rockit Apple, Tegel, Whittaker’s, Zespri, Zeagold and more.

That’s not all, you can also shop from other well-loved New Zealand brands such as Comvita, Nice & Natural, Fourflax and K9 Natural, at Comvita x HoneyWorld stores, Lazada, Ace Asia Pet Care, and Kohepets respectively.

The highly anticipated campaign kicked off with a launch event at Cold Storage Great World City last week, featuring special live cultural performances including a Kapa Haka and Waiata showcase by students from the Australian International School. If you missed the performances, not to worry—mark your calendars and head down to Cold Storage and CS Fresh to discover what makes New Zealand food so special!

Made with Care: New Zealand food is safe, tasty, of premium quality, nutritious and ethical.

‘Discover A Taste of New Zealand’ fair, Cold Storage and CS Fresh stores islandwide, www.facebook.com/DiscoverNew.NZ.SG

The post You Can Now Easily Get High-Quality & Nutritious Ingredients From New Zealand Right Here In SG appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Celebrate Helper Appreciation Month In May
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
We encourage families to think of ways, big and small, to say thank you to your helper this May during Helper Appreciation Month. May is Helper Appreciation Month in Singapore. This celebration of helpers in Singapore is something we at Sassy Mama fully support. The idea for celebrating helpers throughout the month of May began […]

The post Celebrate Helper Appreciation Month In May appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
We encourage families to think of ways, big and small, to say thank you to your helper this May during Helper Appreciation Month.

May is Helper Appreciation Month in Singapore. This celebration of helpers in Singapore is something we at Sassy Mama fully support. The idea for celebrating helpers throughout the month of May began in Hong Kong, where resident Steve Chitty pointed out the month is a natural fit given that it encompasses Labour Day, Mother’s Day and the International Day of Families. Since we began with a one-day celebration and awards ceremony in 2016 to say thank you to helpers and recognise all the amazing ways they support our families, the celebration evolved from large events to show helpers how much we appreciate them to small gestures like holding giveaways.

Here’s how we began to celebrate and recognise helpers’ crucial contributions to our families, plus scroll for lots of helpful resources for your helper, from further education opportunities to Gift Ideas to show your gratitude and appreciation for all your helper’s hard work.

Helper Appreciation May

Education is key to ensuring helpers break the cycle of poverty. Click through below to find out about the wide range of helper education courses available across Singapore – which span financial literacy, cooking, beauty, first aid, and home healthcare.

Everyone deserves good healthcare, yet sadly, many helpers receive the bare minimum of checkups without regard to dental or vision care. Our past Helper Appreciation Month partner, Osler Health, has offered free cervical cancer tests for all domestic helpers of patients. Find out more here. Plus, find out how you can help your domestic worker access basic financial knowledge and education to support her family, plan for her future and retirement, and ensure she avoids common hazards like loan sharks. Click through for information on courses and to find out more about small business success stories from AIDHA in Singapore.

From the top maid agencies in Singapore to tips on onboarding a new helper or preparing your children to say goodbye to your helper, we hear from experts covering all your helper-related questions.

PS: Save the Emergency Contact Card and share it with your helper and friends.

Help your helper have fun on her day off with our roundup of clubs, hobbies, and activities for helpers in Singapore!

The struggle to achieve a work/life balance is real for all of us! But when you work 6 days a week (and live at your workplace) it can be even tougher. Making time for fun can make a big difference to the rest of the week, whether it’s getting some exercise, indulging a creative side, joining a club or getting together with friends. Make sure your helper knows what’s on offer for her in her spare time and on her day off.

Sassy Mama is dedicated to celebrating ALL mothers and families. Here’s how we began to celebrate and recognise helpers’ crucial contributions to our families:

We began with a Helper Appreciation party began back in 2016 recognising helpers for special achievements in childcare, cooking and looking after pets.

Read all about how our Helper Appreciation party, see how the initiative has grown over the years, and help us continue to spread the word across Singapore!

The post Celebrate Helper Appreciation Month In May appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Family-Friendly Rock Climbing & Bouldering Gyms In Singapore
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Check out these kid-friendly places for rock climbing and bouldering in Singapore. Want to take the kids rock climbing or bouldering in Singapore? Rock climbing is such a fun physical family-friendly activity and it’s a great way for kids to develop gross motor skills and build stamina. Need a few recommendations for bouldering (which is […]

The post Family-Friendly Rock Climbing & Bouldering Gyms In Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Check out these kid-friendly places for rock climbing and bouldering in Singapore.

Want to take the kids rock climbing or bouldering in Singapore? Rock climbing is such a fun physical family-friendly activity and it’s a great way for kids to develop gross motor skills and build stamina. Need a few recommendations for bouldering (which is a form of climbing without ropes) or kids’ rock climbing? We round up a few cool spots with themed climbing walls, augmented reality areas and more! Loads of these rock climbing and bouldering gyms are also open for younger kiddos – some even host birthday parties. All you have to do is come in sportswear and bring covered sports shoes with socks. You can rent special climbing shoes if needed, along with any other necessary equipment, from the rock climbing or bouldering gyms directly. Do note that you’ll need to check minimum age/weight requirement,s and you have to factor in rental on top of rock climbing entry fees. Keep scrolling to find out all the best rock climbing and bouldering gyms in Singapore!

Difference between Bouldering and Rock Climbing:

Bouldering is a type of rock climbing that doesn’t require a rope or harness. Bouldering walls are thus not very high since you only climb 3-5 metres. There will usually be a soft landing pad under a bouldering wall for you to land on if you fall. You’ll need to learn the correct bouldering techniques and how to return to the floor safely. Rock climbing (also called rope climbing) requires a rope and harness, and you frequently climb more than 9 metres off the ground. With rock climbing, many centres use an auto belay – an automatic electro-mechanical or mechanical climbing belay system. It replaces the need for someone to hold your rope and tighten it as you climb, as the auto-belay automatically retracts the climbing rope, taking up the slack as you climb. Kids can easily learn how to do this, but for safety, you should check that new climbers are locked in every time they climb. With bouldering, no such equipment is needed. Our kids have found rock climbing more fun as many of the climbing walls are themed, and they like the challenge of climbing high, which you don’t get with bouldering. Also, with bouldering, to come down from your climb, you need to jump to the crash pad. With rock climbing, kids get to rappel (abseil) back down safely with the auto-belay system, which is pretty fun!

Read more: Where to Go for Kids’ Gymnastics Classes

Best Rock Climbing & Bouldering Gyms in Singapore:

1. Ark Bloc: Bouldering Gym

Ark Bloc in Punggol Container Park is a huge bouldering gym and fitness space for strength training and callisthenics. The bouldering gym is open to kids aged 5 and above with an accompanying adult. Over here, you can solve an array of bouldering challenges!

Ark Bloc Punggol prices: From $28 for a full day pass.

Ark Bloc, Punggol East Container Park, 6 Tebing Lane, #01-05, Singapore 828835, arkbloc.com

2. Outpost Climbing: Rock Climbing & Bouldering

Outpost Climbing (previously called T-Hall) is a family-friendly indoor rock climbing and bouldering gym in Singapore with two zones. It’s probably our favourite rock-climbing spot in Singapore. Start at the Fun Zone if you are new to rock climbing or have kids. This rock climbing area has a cutting-edge augmented climbing wall, which uses motion-sensing tech to transform into various games where you’ll climb up, down and even sideways. There are fun-themed rock climbing walls that kids will love, from a Lego Wall to a Rubik’s Cube wall and even a glow-in-the-dark wall inside a dark tunnel! Kids as young as 4 years old (with a minimum weight of 15 kgs) can learn to climb her,e and you’ll get a safety briefing to learn how to use the auto-belay system before you can proceed to the rock climbing walls. The Climb Zone in a separate room is its own rock climbing and bouldering centre in itself! This huge rock climbing and bouldering space (the biggest we have seen in Singapore) lets you build your bouldering techniques, and also offers various certification programmes.

Outpost Climbing rock climbing prices: Entry to the Fun Zone is from $28 (with a $10 add-on for accompanying non-climbing adults), and this includes rock climbing equipment. The Climb Zone rates start from $18 for youths & $28 for adults with rock climbing equipment rental on top.

Outpost Climbing (previously T-Hall), 464 Crawford Lane, Singapore 190464, www.outpostclimbing.sg

3. Climb@T3: Bouldering & Rock Climbing

Climb@T3 is a new sport climbing attraction in Changi Airport! Managed by The Rock School Singapore, the indoor rock climbing wall features an 8m-tall High Wall (spanning Basements 2 and 3!) and a 12m-long bouldering wall. Fun fact: the climbing wall was constructed by the official wall provider for the 2020 and 2024 Olympic Games! The 2.5-metre-high Boulder Wall is best for younger and budding boulderers before they move on to the High Wall. There’s even a programme called The Rock Tots, designed for children aged two to six, filled with rock climbing and bouldering activities and games aimed at helping children get comfortable with bouldering!

Rock climbing prices: From $19 for unguided sessions & from $38 for guided sessions.

Climb@T3, Changi Airport Terminal 3,#B3-01/02, Singapore 819663, www.climbt3.sg

4. Adventure HQ: Bouldering & Rock Climbing

Adventure HQ at HomeTeamNS Khatib is an indoor playground that’s actually geared for teens and adults, too! Expect themed indoor rock climbing walls, a bouldering wall, a ninja course, rope climbing structures and the longest indoor slide in Singapore! Adventure HQ at HomeTeamNS Khatib is open-air (but sheltered), so it gets hot and humid (dress in light sports gear). There is a section for bouldering and rock climbing with a range of walls with varying difficulty levels. With 8 climbing lanes, from Classic Top Rope or Automated Belaying climbing plus 24 interactive climbing elements. Children must be at least 1.25 m tall to climb.

Rock climbing prices: If you wish to access only the Boulder + Rock Climb & Urban Climb areas, you can purchase a Fun Wall Pass from $20 or a Rock Pass from $14.

Adventure HQ HometeamNS Khatib,2 Yishun Walk, Singapore 767944, www.hometeamns.sg/khatib/adventurehq

5. Boulder Movement: Bouldering Gym

This capacious bouldering gym in Singapore is popular because of its natural light and range of bouldering walls, which cater to climbers of different abilities. The staff keep an extra sharp eye out for everyone and are always willing to go the extra mile to help. But what climbers laud about Boulder Movement is the fact that the bouldering gym also works to foster a good-hearted community that’s friendly for advanced climbers and beginners.

Bouldering prices: From $35 per entry pass.

Boulder Movement, multiple locations in Singapore, www.boulderm.com

6. Boulder Planet: Bouldering Gym

This bouldering gym in Singapore has a weekly kids’ bouldering class – the BP Rocketeers – that’s in-depth and guided, so kids can improve their climbing skills. Led by trained coaches, your tot will gain all the necessary bouldering knowledge while developing good gross motor skills. Boulder Planet runs a trial bouldering class for kids ($45 for 1 hour), and adults can join the various route setting workshops and adults-only bouldering classes, too.

Bouldering prices: $16 for a youth pass (for ages 18 and below; from $33 for an individual pass.

Boulder Planet, multiple locations including Sembawang Shopping Centre & Grantral Mall (Tai Seng), www.boulderplanet.sg

7. Climb Central: Bouldering & Rock Climbing

Climb Central offers bouldering and rock climbing for kids who are at least 4 years old, with a weight of more than 20kg and a minimum height of 1.1 metres. All kids must be supervised by an adult (max of two kids per adult). If you’re looking for a spot with some of the highest rock climbing walls in Singapore, Climb Central has it all.

Bouldering & rock climbing prices: From $19.62 (child add-on entry pass); from $21.80 (youths); from $27.25 (adults).

Climb Central, multiple locations in Singapore including Kallang Wave Mall, Novena Square, Funan and i12 Katong, www.climbcentral.sg

8. Fit Bloc: Rock Climbing & Bouldering

Expect one rock climbing wall and three bouldering sections that are suitable for climbers of all ages at this bouldering gym in Singapore! Other than bouldering and rock climbing, you’ll also find a sauna, spin bikes, a basic gym and a swimming pool if you want to cool off afterwards. You can rent the required harness, climbing shoes and an equipment bundle here, too.

Rock climbing and bouldering prices: From $28

Fit Bloc, Kent Ridge and Depot Heights Shopping Center, www.fitbloc.com

9. Ground Up Climbing: Rock Climbing & Bouldering

Rock climbing for kids in Singapore is a breeze at Ground Up Climbing. Their progressive indoor rock climbing classes for kids are suitable for kids aged 5 and up, and include climbing skills and techniques, challenges, games and all sorts of competitions. Children will also focus on mastering balance and movement, and will be taught by coaches who are Singapore Mountaineering Federation and first aid certified. There’s also a bouldering gym with lower heights.

Rock climbing and bouldering prices: From $17/adult; Starter sets from $29/adult & $22/youth

Ground Up Climbing, Civil Service Club, Level 2, 60 Tessensohn Road, Singapore 217664; www.groundupsg.com

10. boulder+: Bouldering Gym

After opening their first bouldering gym in Aperia Mall, Boulder+ opened the biggest bouldering gym in Singapore at The Chevrons. This Singapore bouldering gym has multiple climbing walls and various boulder problems of different difficulties. Boulder+ is open to all climbers aged 7. From beginners to those looking for a challenge, head to the bouldering wall with angles as low as 70 degrees or check out the 60-degree overhang wall for some vertical hang! If you need a shot of caffeine before you climb, there’s a cafe on site.

Bouldering prices: $18 for kids’ pass; $35 parent-child pass; day pass $28.

boulder+, Aperia Mall, 12 Kallang Avenue & The Chevrons, 48 Boon Lay Way, Singapore, www.boulderplusclimbing.com

11. Kinetics Climbing: Rock Climbing & Bouldering

Sign your kids up for the Tiny Tots programme at this rock climbing and bouldering gym in Singapore! Suited for kids aged 6 to 9, the programme lets them try their first steps in rock climbing or bouldering under the proper guidance of a friendly coach. The interactive environment will let your child build their strength and core muscles, improve balance and stability and master patience, confidence and concentration. Class ratios are kept at 1:4, and kids will get to progress upwards to Kinetics’ Junior Team too!

Rock climbing and bouldering prices: $16.50 (off-peak) & $21 (peak)

Kinetics Climbing, 511 Serangoon Road, Singapore 218153, www.kineticsclimbing.com.sg

12. My Little Climbing Room: Kids’ Rock Climbing

This indoor rock climbing playground is geared toward kids and welcomes littles as young as 3. They’ve got an excellent drop-off programme where kids are guided through the rock climbing session by experienced facilitators. They’ll get to play all sorts of fun games and climbing activities as they build all the right skills to grow in strength. There’s also a trial class available ($38).

Rock climbing and bouldering prices: $33/child for a 60-minute session

My Little Climbing Room, Promenade @Pelikat,183 Jalan Pelikat, #B1-101 Singapore, www.mylittleclimbingroom.com

13. Oyeyo Boulder Home: Bouldering Gym

Oyeyo Boulder Home is a small bouldering space with a bouldering wall of about 3 metres so it’s a good one to get started with if you are daunted by big heights! Serious climbers look out for their 180-degree climbing wall! There is an option for private bouldering coaching, too, for kids aged 4 to 12 at three levels – Taster, Basic and Intermediate – where kids will learn what to look out for when on the wall, climbing techniques and more.

Bouldering prices: $20 for a single-entry pass

Oyeyo Boulder Home, 148 Mackenzie Road, Singapore 228724, www.oyeyoboulderhome.com

14. SAFRA Yishun: Highest Outdoor Rock Climbing

SAFRA Adventure Sports Centre boasts some great outdoor climbing walls for serious adrenaline junkies. Don’t miss the 25m-tall outdoor rock wall. There are also 15m sport climbing walls, a 18m slab wall, and 18m chimney and crack walls. There are two indoor bouldering walls, but the main draw here is the whopping 25-metre outdoor climbing wall, which will really test your climbing skills and agility; however, do note that you’ll need a level 1 SNCS certification and be 7 years old or older to climb here.

Rock climbing & bouldering prices: Prices for SAFRA members from $12.95; non-members from $17.85.

SAFRA, Yishun, 60 Yishun Avenue 4, Singapore 769027; www.safra.sg

15. BFF Climb:  Bouldering Gym + Kids Zone

BFF Climb is a beginner-friendly bouldering gym with lower walls, so it’s great to get smaller kids started on bouldering. There’s also a Play Zone for kids with a slide to zoom down and a foam pit to jump into. No minimum age is required–kids just need to be at least 11kg.

Rock climbing & bouldering prices: $35 for a guided session at Bendemeer & Our Tampines Hub outlets; Single entry from $17.44

BFF Climb, three locations at Bendemeer, Our Tampines Hub & Tampines Yoha, www.bffclimb.com

16. Project Send: Bouldering Gym in Singapore

Project Send is one of the newest bouldering gyms in Singapore, located in Esplanade Mall. Their holistic gym offers a variety of fitness classes besides bouldering, and even has a cafe on-site (their Full Day Experience passes include a drink and pastry to go with your climb!). This Singapore bouldering gym often hosts 10-week Kids Track programmes throughout the year, so keep your eyes peeled for their next one on their socials.

Bouldering prices: From $35/pax for a Full Day Experience; $40 for a parent-child Buddy Climb (kids 7-12 years old with a parent/guardian)

Project Send, 8 Raffles Avenue, #02-29 Esplanade Mall, Singapore 039802, www.projectsend.co

17. VertiClimb Singapore: Gamified Rock Climbing

Singapore’s first gamified indoor rock climbing gym, VertiClimb offers detailed levels of planning and automation controls so your immersive climbing experience challenges you both physically and mentally. Littlies can try their hand at rock climbing with a coaching class taught by a national climber. There’s no height limit as all the walls are easy for kids to reach. Equipment is provided too, so all you need to bring is a good pair of socks and deck your kid out in appropriate sportswear. The indoor bouldering centre is only open on weekends and advanced bookings are a must.

Rock climbing prices: Prices available upon request.

VertiClimb Singapore, 200 Pandan Gardens, #01-02, Singapore 609336, www.singaporerockclimbing.com

18. SuperPark Singapore: Climbing & Activities

This one’s not a bouldering gym per se, but SuperPark Singapore does have a cool Augmented Reality wall with various integrated digital aspects. These allow your kiddo to climb to their heart’s content, as the wall has different kinds of games to increase the challenge for climbers!

SuperPark prices: Tickets from $30.90 for 100cm and above; $22.90 for below 100cm

SuperPark, 3 Temasek Boulevard, Suntec City Mall, #02-477 (North Wing), Singapore www.superpark.com.sg

Boulder World: Bouldering Gym (Closed)

Step into this bouldering gym in Orchard, where you’ll encounter more than 100 boulder problems with different challenge levels. The facilities here also include fully functional fitness rooms, training boards and showers so you can head straight to brunch afterwards! Boulder World can host birthday parties, too, if you’d like some bouldering fun with friends.

The Rock School: Rock Climbing & Bouldering (Closed)

This indoor rock climbing and bouldering gym in Our Tampines Hub offers guided intro rock climbing lessons or join their rock climbing camps. Open to tots as young as 2 years right up till age 12, the well-kitted-out rock climbing centre follows structured lesson plans, and your little one will be scaling up their 8-meter walls in no time.

Clip ‘n Climb: Bouldering & Rock Climbing (Closed)

Clip ‘n Climb has a bouldering space and 19 walls to rock climb, each decked out in different colours and themes with different levels of difficulty, so it’s challenging for everyone. There’s the Morse Code with flashing lights, the Dry Ice wall where you need ice picks, the double-sided Face-to-Face wall and the Spaghetti Junction with dangling ropes for extra difficulty. It’s a full sensory experience and keeps the fun stakes high. There is no age minimum (just weight; kids must be 10kg or above).

There’re loads of fun things to do with kids in SG! Here are a few ideas to get you started:

The post Family-Friendly Rock Climbing & Bouldering Gyms In Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Revamped Museum Of Ice Cream Singapore With Kids: Are the Tickets Worth It?
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Thinking about getting tickets to the Museum of Ice Cream Singapore? Here’s our Museum of Ice Cream review of what to expect at the revamped MOIC in Dempsey when visiting with kids. In case you missed it, the Museum of Ice Cream just had a snazzy revamp. This whopping 60,000 square feet kids’ museum opened […]

The post Revamped Museum Of Ice Cream Singapore With Kids: Are the Tickets Worth It? appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Thinking about getting tickets to the Museum of Ice Cream Singapore? Here’s our Museum of Ice Cream review of what to expect at the revamped MOIC in Dempsey when visiting with kids.

In case you missed it, the Museum of Ice Cream just had a snazzy revamp. This whopping 60,000 square feet kids’ museum opened in Dempsey on 19 August 2021 and it just had a refresh in April 2025. Here are all the deets about the Museum of Ice Cream including ticket prices, whether you can indeed get FREE ice cream, and more!

Read more: Best Places For Gelato & Ice Cream In Singapore

Museum of Ice Cream in Dempsey

The Museum of Ice Cream property at Dempsey features over 14 never-before-seen installations that “celebrate the joy that ice cream brings”. Expect a whole lot of pink- raid your friends’ wardrobe so you can match for your best IG selfies – it’s all about the gram after all!

Ice cream treats are part of your Museum of Ice Cream ticket

If you thought the Museum of Ice Cream was all about eating ice cream, you’re not too far off. Ticket holders will get to enjoy ice cream treats (by names such as Denzy Gelato and Ben & Jerry’s, with vegan and allergen-friendly options) as they are guided through the 60- to 90-minute experience by the Museum of Ice Cream staff.

And when we say ice cream treats, we mean unlimited servings of ice cream! There are 19 flavours and eight toppings to choose from, including favourites such as Chocolate Chip Cookie Dough and Strawberry Speculoos. There are also other cool treats such as ice cream sandwiches, ice cream tacos and more.

Dragon Playground at MOIC Singapore

One of the highlights at the Museum of Ice Cream is the fully functional, Singapore-inspired “Dragon Playground” that’s actually a unicorn design with an area to climb up and a small slide to whizz down. There are banana swings and some basketball hoops to shoot while you are there.

The whole place is designed for lots of posing for Instagram – it’s pink, pink and more pink. Look out for the red, orange, pink and yellow wall of 10,000 bananas that leads to a craft area for kids to make a little pink ice cream truck out of paper.

New highlights at the Museum of Ice Cream

  • Carnival: Kids and adults can both enjoy old-school games here.
  • Bouncy Castle & Infinity Mirror Party Zone: There’s a massive pink bouncy castle the little ones will love, plus a mirror world with dance music for them to burn even more energy off.
  • Banana Maze: Making an appearance for the first time in Singapore, this maze is simply bananas! Get lost in the colourful fruity maze and snap loads of photos along the way.
  • The largest MOIC Sprinkle Pool ever created: It’s filled with multi-coloured giant plastic sprinkles to jump into (and it’s surprisingly relaxing to do so!)
  • MOIC Passport: 
  • MOIC workshops: Included in the price of your ticket are free workshops! Join an ice cream-making workshop, make keychains, create squishy paintings and craft edible slime from 3 to 25 May 2025.

How much does the Museum of Ice Cream cost?

Tickets cost $35 per entry for Singapore Residents and $43 for General Admission. Kids aged 2 and below enter free. Premium MOIC tickets cost from $44, which gives you access to five exclusive ice cream flavours, extra toppings and a complimentary drink.

Singapore Residents get 10% off weekday General and Premium tickets from now till 30 May with the code SGSPRINKLE10 at checkout online. Get tickets to MOIC here.

So are tickets to the Museum of Ice Cream worth it?

We asked our two kiddos if they liked the experience. They said it was 10 out of 10. Unlimited ice cream will do that to kids. We found the price a little steep, but rest assured the kids will have a ball of a time especially if you’re out of ideas of what to do with the kids.

Where is the Museum of Ice Cream Singapore?

Find the Museum of Ice Cream Singapore at 100 Loewen Road, Dempsey, Singapore 248837
Opening Hours: Friday – Tuesday 10am – 7pm; Wednesday 10am – 3pm; Thursday 10am – 2.30pm
www.museumoficecream.sg

Read more: 

The post Revamped Museum Of Ice Cream Singapore With Kids: Are the Tickets Worth It? appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Telltale Signs Your Child May Need Speech Therapy & What To Do Next
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Stuttering, speech delays, articulation struggles – sound familiar? Here’s how to spot the signs your child might need speech therapy, and how the therapists at Ray of Joy Therapy can help! Parents, are you noticing that your child is not meeting certain communication milestones or seems to be falling behind their peers? Whether they’re struggling […]

The post Telltale Signs Your Child May Need Speech Therapy & What To Do Next appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Stuttering, speech delays, articulation struggles – sound familiar? Here’s how to spot the signs your child might need speech therapy, and how the therapists at Ray of Joy Therapy can help!

Parents, are you noticing that your child is not meeting certain communication milestones or seems to be falling behind their peers? Whether they’re struggling with speech delay, having trouble engaging in conversations or finding it hard to pronounce words, these challenges can impact their confidence.

But here’s the good news–early intervention can make all the difference! Here are some signs that your child might need speech therapy, and how the MOE-experienced therapists at Ray of Joy Therapy can help.

Read more: Guide to SPED Schools, Early Intervention Centres, Inclusive & Special Needs Schools in Singapore

Common signs that your child may need speech therapy

Communication challenges can impact your child in the long run, but how can you tell if they need professional help? While it’s important to keep in mind that children develop at their own pace, certain signs may indicate the need for early intervention.

One of the most common challenges is speech delay. You might notice your child falling behind their peers when it comes to speaking or understanding language. Some children also face difficulty forming complete sentences or using incomplete phrases. Most kids begin speaking around 1 year old and start forming sentences by 2. If your child isn’t hitting these milestones, it might be a good idea to seek support.

Other common signs to look out for include trouble following instructions, struggling with articulation, unintelligible speech and stuttering. Parents should also observe if their child has difficulty maintaining conversations, making friends or understanding social cues, which may be accompanied by frustration when trying to communicate.

Why early detection is important

Communication challenges can impact your child in the long run, making it harder for them to build self-confidence, make friends, express their feelings and even succeed in school.  Early intervention is essential in helping your child communicate effectively, which in turn supports their emotional and social development.

Speech therapists are beneficial at addressing these challenges and ensuring your child gets the support they need. At Ray of Joy Therapy, the team, made out of three founders, brings extensive MOE school and preschool experience, offering unique insights into the communication skills children need. Therapy sessions can be held at their One Holland Village space or at your home. These sessions are designed to help parents understand how communication skills impact children at every educational stage – from playground interactions to classroom participation – providing therapy that prepares children for real-world communication challenges.

Get a free speech therapy consultation for your child

Still unsure if your child needs professional help? Ray of Joy Therapy offers a free 15-minute consultation call to discuss your concerns and determine what’s best for your child’s needs. They also provide a free online milestone tracker on the website, where you can monitor your child’s progress with expert guidance. Book a speech therapy session to start your child’s journey toward confident communication today!

Flash this article to receive 10% off your child’s first therapy session! Offer is limited to the first ten families only!

Ray of Joy Therapy, Super Co @ One Holland Village. (5th floor, via Lift Lobby B), 7 Holland Village Way, Singapore 275748, Tel: (+65) 8093 4773, www.rayofjoytherapy.com

The post Telltale Signs Your Child May Need Speech Therapy & What To Do Next appeared first on Sassy Mama.

item.title: Guide To SPED Schools, Early Intervention Centres, Inclusive & Special Needs Schools In Singapore
item.dc:creator: Sassy Mama
item.description:
Looking for an inclusive or SPED school, early intervention centre or special needs school in Singapore? Consult our list to find the right one for your child. Special education schools in Singapore (SPED) are part of a quickly evolving landscape, as 2019 marked the first year that Singaporean students with moderate-to-severe special needs were required […]

The post Guide To SPED Schools, Early Intervention Centres, Inclusive & Special Needs Schools In Singapore appeared first on Sassy Mama.
item.content:encoded:
Looking for an inclusive or SPED school, early intervention centre or special needs school in Singapore? Consult our list to find the right one for your child.
